summary: Enables OSPF 1583 compatibility mode.
synopsis: This command enables OSPF 1583 compatibility mode, which is enabled by default. If all OSPF routers in the routing domain are RFC 2328 compliant, this mode should be disabled.

syntax: [sequence-number] {deny | permit} {every | {protocol srcip srcmask | any | host srcip} [{range | eq | neq | lt | gt} {portkey | 0-65535} {dstip dstmask | any | host dstip} [{range | eq | neq | lt | gt} {portkey | 0-65535}] [icmp-type icmp-type [icmp-code icmp-code] | icmp-message igmp-type] [fragments] [precedence precedence | tos tos [tosmask] | dscp dscp]} [time-range time-range-name] [log] [assign-queue queue-id] [{mirror | redirect} {unit/slot/port | lag lag-group-id}] [rate-limit rate burst-size]
summary: Creates a new rule for the current IP access list.
synopsis: This command creates a new rule in the current IP ACL, specifying whether to deny or permit traffic based on defined conditions. The minimum requirements involve designating either the 'every' keyword or specific protocol, source, and destination addresses. An implicit deny rule finalizes the access list.

syntax: aaa accounting {exec | commands | dot1x} {default | list-name} {start-stop | stop-only | none} method1 [method2…]
summary: Creates an accounting method list for user sessions and commands.
synopsis: This command establishes accounting settings in Global Config mode, allowing for user EXEC sessions, command tracking, or DOT1X commands while defining the method of tracking (start-stop, stop-only, or none). Up to five lists can be configured per type, with specific support limitations for DOT1X accounting.

syntax: aaa authentication dot1x default {ias | local | none | radius}
summary: Configures authentication methods for port-based access to the switch.
synopsis: This command sets the default authentication methods for 802.1X port-based access. It includes options like 'ias' for internal database, 'local' for local username, 'none' for no authentication, and 'radius' for external RADIUS servers.

summary: Sets authentication for accessing higher privilege levels.
synopsis: This command establishes the method list for enabling access to higher privilege levels, allowing for various methods such as enable, local, and none. The presence of 'none' at the end signifies that no authentication is required if all prior checks fail.

summary: Configures authentication methods for user login.
synopsis: This command specifies the authentication methods, including local, radius, tacacs, and none, to be used when a user logs in. Using 'none' as the last method ensures that login proceeds without further authentication if all prior methods fail.

summary: Configures command and exec authorization method lists.
synopsis: This command sets up authorization methods for user EXEC terminal sessions (exec) or all user-executed commands (commands). If TACACS or RADIUS is used, command authorization is sent to the respective servers for validation.

summary: Adds a user to the internal user database for network access.
synopsis: Use this command in Global Config mode to add a specified user to the internal user database, which facilitates local authentication for network access through IEEE 802.1X. This command switches the context to AAA User Config mode.

summary: Enables Change of Authorization (CoA) functionality.
synopsis: This command allows configuration of the switch for dynamic authorization with RADIUS, enabling the management of client access dynamically through authorization changes.

summary: Specifies the session-id usage for AAA services within a session.
synopsis: This command allows the configuration of session-id behavior in Global Config mode, determining whether the same session-id is used for all AAA service types or if each type has a unique session-id. The default is 'common'.

summary: Adds an absolute time entry to a time range.
synopsis: This command specifies a fixed time period during which an ACL rule is active, allowing finer control over when rules take effect based on specific start and end times.

syntax: access-list 100-199 {remark comment} | {[sequence-number]} [rule 1-1023] {deny | permit} {every | {{eigrp | gre | icmp | igmp | ip | ipinip | ospf | pim | tcp | udp | 0 -255} {srcip srcmask |any | host srcip} [range {portkey | startport} {portkey | endport} {eq | neq | lt | gt} {portkey | 0-65535} {dstip dstmask | any | host dstip} [{range {portkey | startport} {portkey | endport} | {eq | neq | lt | gt} {portkey | 0-65535}] [flag [+fin | -fin] [+syn | -syn] [+rst | -rst] [+psh | -psh] [+ack | -ack] [+urg | -urg] [established]] [icmp-type icmp-type [icmp-code icmp-code] | icmp-message icmp-message] [igmp-type igmp-type] [fragments] [precedence precedence | tos tos [tosmask] | dscp dscp]}} [time-range time-range-name] [log] [assign-queue queue-id] [{mirror | redirect} {unit/slot/port | lag lag-group-id}] [rate-limit rate burst-size]
summary: Defines an IP extended ACL to permit or deny network traffic based on specified criteria.
synopsis: The access-list command is used to create a list of rules for filtering network traffic. Rules are indicated by sequence numbers, which determine their order. Criteria such as source and destination IP addresses, protocols, and TCP flags can be specified to allow or block packets. Additionally, comments can be added to enhance clarity. Some functionalities have limitations, such as port range matching and rate limiting for egress ACLs.

summary: Applies accounting method list to a line configuration.
synopsis: This command is used in Line Configuration mode to set the method list for user EXEC sessions or commands executed over specific line types, like console or telnet.

summary: Enables ACL trap mode.
synopsis: This command activates the ACL trap mode, allowing the switch to generate notifications for specific ACL events, facilitating monitoring and management of access control.

summary: Adds a port to the port-channel (LAG).
synopsis: This command allows you to add one port to a configured port-channel. You can include a range of ports in the command when in Interface Config mode. Ensure the physical mode of the port is set prior to adding it to the port-channel.

summary: Sets an address prefix and its lifetime for address assignment.
synopsis: This command defines a specific IPv6 address prefix to be used in assignments and can set valid and preferred lifetimes for those addresses. If no lifetimes are specified, defaults are applied.

summary: Configures how an application runs on the switch.
synopsis: This command specifies how an executable file must start an application on the switch. It allows for preconfiguration of a command for an executable file not yet present on the switch. Execution will only take effect once the file is present.

summary: Starts a specified application on the switch.
synopsis: This command initiates the execution of a specified application that must be previously installed on the switch. The application needs to be present to be started.

summary: Configures the default cost for a stub area.
synopsis: This command sets the cost for routing through a specified stub area in OSPF, impacting routing decisions based on path cost.

summary: Configures the specified area-id to function as an NSSA.
synopsis: This command designates the specified area as a Not-So-Stubby Area (NSSA) where external routes can be imported while still maintaining some restrictions.

summary: Configures the default route advertised into the NSSA.
synopsis: This command configures the metric and type for the default route advertised into the NSSA. The metric can be specified, with a range of 1 to 16777214, and can be either comparable or non-comparable.

summary: Prevents external routes from being redistributed into the NSSA.
synopsis: This command modifies the NSSA Area Border Router (ABR) settings so that any external routes learned will not be redistributed into the NSSA.

summary: Prevents summary LSAs from being advertised into NSSA.
synopsis: This command stops the advertisement of summary Link-State Advertisements (LSAs) into the NSSA, preserving its intended isolation.

summary: Configures the translator role of the NSSA.
synopsis: This command sets the translator role for the NSSA; 'always' enables immediate role assignment, while 'candidate' allows participation in translator elections.

summary: Configures the translator stability interval for the NSSA.
synopsis: This command sets the stability interval for the NSSA translator, which determines how long the elected translator continues to function after its status changes.

syntax: area area-id range ip-address netmask {summarylink | nssaexternallink} [advertise | not-advertise] [cost cost]
summary: Configures a summary prefix advertised by an area border router.
synopsis: This command establishes a summary prefix for an area which an area border router utilizes when advertising routes, including options for metrics and advertisement control.

summary: Creates a stub area for the specified area ID.
synopsis: This command designates an area as a stub where AS External LSAs are not permitted, thus streamlining routing and reducing the link state database.

summary: Disables summary LSAs in an OSPF stub area.
synopsis: This command configures the OSPF process to disable the generation of summary LSAs for the stub area, helping to reduce routing table size and overhead.

summary: Creates an OSPF virtual link to the specified neighbor.
synopsis: This command sets up a virtual link through a designated neighbor router, identified by its Router ID, to connect non-contiguous OSPF areas.

syntax: area area-id virtual-link neighbor authentication {none | simple key | encrypt key keyid}
summary: Configures the default authentication type for the OSPF virtual interface.
synopsis: This command sets the authentication method for OSPF virtual links, specifying type (none, simple, or encrypt) and relevant key parameters. The key must be 8 bytes or less for simple and up to 16 bytes for encrypt. Default is none.

syntax: area area-id virtual-link neighbor dead-interval seconds
summary: Configures the dead interval for the OSPF virtual interface.
synopsis: This command configures the dead interval for the OSPF virtual interface on the virtual interface identified by area-id and neighbor. The neighbor parameter is the Router ID of the neighbor. The range for seconds is 1 to 65535.

syntax: area area-id virtual-link neighbor hello-interval seconds
summary: Configures the hello interval for the OSPF virtual interface.
synopsis: This command configures the hello interval for the OSPF virtual interface on the virtual interface identified by area-id and neighbor. The neighbor parameter is the Router ID of the neighbor. The range for seconds is from 1 to 65535.

syntax: area area-id virtual-link neighbor retransmit-interval seconds
summary: Configures the retransmit interval for the OSPF virtual interface.
synopsis: This command configures the retransmit interval for the OSPF virtual interface on the virtual interface identified by area-id and neighbor. The neighbor parameter is the Router ID of the neighbor. The range for seconds is 0 to 3600.

syntax: area area-id virtual-link neighbor transmit-delay seconds
summary: Configures the transmit delay for the OSPF virtual interface.
synopsis: This command configures the transmit delay for the OSPF virtual interface on the virtual interface identified by area-id and neighbor. The neighbor parameter is the Router ID of the neighbor. The range for seconds is 0 to 3600.

summary: Manages ARP settings and configurations.
synopsis: This command is used to configure various ARP settings, including cache settings and dynamic renewals, to manage how the network associates IP addresses with MAC addresses.

summary: Enters ARP Access-List configuration mode.
synopsis: This command allows entry into the ARP Access-List configuration mode from the Global Config mode, enabling configuration of ARP filtering.

summary: Configures the ARP cache size.
synopsis: This command sets the ARP cache size to a platform-specific integer value, allowing for configuration of how many ARP entries can be held. Default sizes will vary by platform.

summary: Enables automatic renewal of dynamic ARP entries.
synopsis: This command allows the ARP component to automatically renew dynamic ARP entries when they age out, sending ARP requests to update entries rather than deleting them.

summary: Removes specified IP address from ARP cache.
synopsis: This command removes the specified IP address from the ARP cache, affecting only dynamic or gateway entries. An optional interface parameter specifies where to remove the entry from.

summary: Configures ARP request response time-out.
synopsis: This command sets the ARP response timeout period, which determines how long the system will wait for a reply before timing out. Executed in Global Config mode.

summary: Configures the maximum count of ARP request retries.
synopsis: This command sets the maximum number of requests for retries when an ARP request fails, with a valid range of 0 to 10 retries. The default is 4 retries.

summary: Configures ARP entry ageout time.
synopsis: This command sets the duration in seconds after which ARP entries are considered stale and removed from the cache. Executed in Global Config mode.

summary: Specifies a hardware queue for traffic handling matching the rule.
synopsis: The `assign-queue` parameter is used in ACL rules to designate a specific hardware queue for processing traffic that matches the rule, enabling fine-tuned control over how traffic is managed and prioritized in a network environment.

summary: Specifies the authorization type for RADIUS clients.
synopsis: This command sets the type of authorization required from RADIUS clients, with the default being 'all'. The switch will reject any client that does not match the specified attributes.

summary: Enables authentication on the device.
synopsis: This command is used to enable authentication on the device, ensuring that only authorized users can access device features and configurations.

summary: Sets the order of authentication methods.
synopsis: This command defines the order of authentication methods that should be used when verifying user identities, allowing for flexibility in security measures.

summary: Sets the priority for authentication methods.
synopsis: This command assigns a priority level to specified authentication methods, helping to control which method is attempted first when a user tries to log in.

summary: Restarts the authentication process.
synopsis: This command restarts the authentication process on the device, which can be useful when configuration changes have been made that affect authentication.

summary: Sets the time-out duration for authentication.
synopsis: This command configures the authentication time-out period, indicating the maximum time in seconds (between 60 to 600) that a client has to enter valid credentials before they must re-attempt access to the network.

summary: Enables command authorization for each command execution attempt.
synopsis: This command applies command authorization to the line config mode for console, telnet, and SSH lines based on the specified list-name, enhancing security by ensuring users are authorized before executing commands.

summary: Applies a command authorization list to an access method for Privileged EXEC mode.
synopsis: By applying a specified command authorization method list, users can enter Privileged EXEC mode without needing to use the enable command, streamlining access management in console, telnet, and SSH environments.

summary: Applies the default exec authorization list for access methods.
synopsis: This command assigns the default method list for exec authorization to console, telnet, or SSH access. Users are not required to issue the enable command to access Privileged EXEC mode if they have proper authorization.

summary: Enables VLAN assignments from the RADIUS server.
synopsis: This command configures the switch to accept VLAN assignments sent by the RADIUS server, allowing for dynamic VLAN assignment based on RADIUS responses.

summary: Configures the OSPF link cost based on interface bandwidth.
synopsis: By default, OSPF computes the link cost of each interface from the interface bandwidth. The auto-cost command allows you to change the reference bandwidth (in Mbps) for OSPF routing decisions.

summary: Enables Auto-DoS on the switch.
synopsis: This command activates all denial of service (DoS) checks. When a DoS attack is detected, the switch copies offending packets to the CPU, shuts down the port, and moves it to a diagnostically disabled state. Manual reactivation of the port is required.

summary: Enables automatic negotiation of interface settings.
synopsis: This command configures the specified interface to automatically negotiate speed and duplex settings with its directly connected peer, optimizing link performance.

summary: Enables automatic negotiation for all interfaces.
synopsis: This command activates automatic negotiation for all interfaces on the device, simplifying configuration management across multiple ports.

summary: Enables RIP auto-summarization.
synopsis: The 'auto-summary' command enables the automatic summarization of routes in RIP, allowing the router to create and send summarized route information.

summary: Configure auto VoIP mode based on protocol or OUI.
synopsis: This command enables auto VoIP mode, which prioritizes voice data based on the layer 4 port used for voice sessions or the known OUI of the phone. Active sessions are cleared if protocol-based auto VoIP is disabled.

summary: Configure an OUI for Auto VoIP prioritization.
synopsis: This command assigns the highest priority to traffic from devices identified by the specified OUI prefix. The OUI is defined using three octet values and an associated description.

summary: Configures global priority for OUI-based Auto VoIP.
synopsis: This command sets the 802.1p priority value for traffic that originates from devices matching the configured OUIs, ensuring VoIP traffic receives appropriate treatment.

summary: Configure global protocol-based auto VoIP priority or traffic-class.
synopsis: This command sets the 802.1p priority for VoIP traffic based on detected call-control protocols. The traffic is marked with the specified priority for consistent treatment across the network.

summary: Configure the global Auto VoIP VLAN ID.
synopsis: This command specifies the VLAN ID for segregating VoIP traffic, ensuring that all traffic matching the OUI list is directed to this VLAN.

summary: Enables AutoState for a VLAN routing interface.
synopsis: AutoState changes the state of a VLAN routing interface automatically based on link state events (up or down). By default, AutoState is disabled; this means a VLAN routing interface can remain up even if the link is down.

summary: Customize the background color of the Captive Portal authentication page.
synopsis: Use this command to set the background color of the Captive Portal authentication page using a well-known color name or RGB value. The color-code can be a valid color name or an RGB hex-code like #FF0000, and it ranges from 1 to 32 characters. Default color is #BFBFBF.

summary: Set interface bandwidth for OSPF cost calculations.
synopsis: This command specifies the bandwidth of an interface in kilobits per second to influence the OSPF link cost calculation, impacting routing decisions without altering actual interface speed.

summary: Blocks all traffic for a captive portal configuration.
synopsis: This command blocks all network traffic for the captive portal, preventing users from accessing anything on the network until they are authenticated.

summary: Enables Bonjour on the switch.
synopsis: This command activates Bonjour service, allowing the switch to advertise its services via the Bonjour protocol. It must be executed in Global Config mode.

summary: Enables stack firmware synchronization.
synopsis: This command activates the automatic synchronization mechanism for firmware across stack members, ensuring they match the version running on the stack manager, which can lead to upgrades or downgrades of firmware.

summary: Enables firmware downgrades on stack members if necessary.
synopsis: Activating this command allows the stack member to downgrade its firmware version if the version on the stack manager is older, ensuring compatibility across the stack.

summary: Enables sending SNMP traps for firmware synchronization events.
synopsis: This command configures the switch to send SNMP traps related to stack firmware synchronization, allowing network management systems to be notified of synchronization status.

summary: Start or stop the AutoInstall process on the switch.
synopsis: This command allows you to operationally start or stop the AutoInstall process on the switch. It is non-persistent and does not save changes in the startup or running configuration file.

summary: Enable automatic reboot after successful image download.
synopsis: With this command, the switch will automatically reboot after successfully downloading an image, requiring no administrative action.

summary: Automatically save the downloaded configuration file to startup-config.
synopsis: Use this command to enable the automatic saving of the downloaded configuration to the startup-config file. If disabled, manual saving is required.

summary: Enable AutoInstall for the next boot.
synopsis: This command enables AutoInstall on the switch for the next reboot cycle, saving the command to NVRAM without affecting the current configuration.

summary: Set the number of attempts to download a configuration file from the TFTP server.
synopsis: Use this command to specify how many times the switch should attempt to download a configuration file from the TFTP server, with a number argument ranging from 1 to 3. The default is 3 attempts.

summary: Activate the specified image for subsequent reboots.
synopsis: This command activates a chosen image as the active-image for future reboots while marking the current active image as the backup-image.

summary: Specifies the default boot image for a DHCP client.
synopsis: This command allows the configuration of the boot file name that the DHCP client will use to initiate its boot process.

summary: Enables the circuit ID option mode for BootP/DHCP Relay.
synopsis: This command turns on the circuit ID option mode for BootP/DHCP relay functionality on the switch, allowing it to include circuit ID options in relay messages.

summary: Configures the maximum allowable relay agent hops for BootP/DHCP Relay.
synopsis: This command sets the maximum allowable relay agent hops for BootP/DHCP Relay on the system, where hops can be a value ranging from 1 to 16.

summary: Configures the minimum wait time for BootP/DHCP Relay.
synopsis: This command sets the minimum wait time in seconds for BootP/DHCP Relay on the system, which affects how the relay agent decides whether to relay a request based on the client's boot time.

summary: Configures the forwarding database address aging timeout.
synopsis: This command sets the duration in seconds for how long to retain entries in the MAC forwarding database before considering them inactive. Valid input ranges from 10 to 1,000,000 seconds.

summary: Check the cable connection status on a specified port.
synopsis: The cable status command checks the connection status of a selected port. It reports various statuses like Normal, Open, Short, or Test Failed. Also provides cable length if supported by the PHY. Link activity may be disrupted during the testing.

summary: Enables Opaque Capability on the router.
synopsis: This command allows the router to handle Opaque LSAs, which can be used for additional information distribution in OSPF, setting the default to enabled.

summary: Enters the Captive Portal Configuration Mode.
synopsis: Use this command to access the Captive Portal Configuration Mode where various captive portal settings can be configured.

summary: Deauthenticates a specific captive portal client.
synopsis: This command deauthenticates specific clients from captive portal configurations. You can specify a captive portal configuration ID and/or a MAC address. If no parameters are provided, all clients are deauthenticated from all configurations.

summary: Sets the maximum size for captured pcap files.
synopsis: This command specifies the maximum size limit for pcap files, allowing capture persistence across reboots, where the size can range from 2 to 512 KB.

summary: Enables wrapping of packets in line capture mode.
synopsis: This command allows for continued capture in line mode once packet capacity is full, preventing data loss by wrapping captured packets.

summary: Configures the TCP port for remote capture.
synopsis: This command sets the TCP port number for capturing packets remotely, with valid IDs between 1024 and 49151, ensuring persistent configuration across reboots.

summary: Starts capturing CPU packets.
synopsis: This command begins capturing packets for packet trace in one of three modes: all traffic, received traffic only, or transmitted traffic only. The capture isn't persistent across reboots.

summary: Manually stops capturing CPU packets for packet trace.
synopsis: This command is used to stop packet capture that was initiated earlier, allowing users to halt the packet trace process manually.

summary: Sets a filename on USB for CPU packet capture.
synopsis: This command designates a filename on a USB device for saving captured CPU packets, facilitating easy data retrieval.

summary: Configures file capture options persistently across reboots.
synopsis: This command allows configuration of various capture modes. 'file' stores data in NVRAM, 'remote' sends packets to an external PC running Wireshark, 'line' displays packets in the CLI, and 'usb' saves capture files to a USB device.

summary: Creates an instance of a class definition within the specified policy.
synopsis: This command creates an instance of a class definition within the specified policy for defining treatment of the traffic class. The classname argument is the name of an existing DiffServ class.

summary: Defines a DiffServ class of type match-all.
synopsis: This command defines a DiffServ class that matches all of its specified conditions. If used without match conditions, it enters class-map mode for a new or existing class. The class-name must be unique and is case sensitive.

summary: Renames an existing DiffServ class.
synopsis: This command allows changing the name of a DiffServ class to a new unique identifier, while ensuring that the new name adheres to the naming constraints.

summary: Maps 802.1p priority to an internal traffic class.
synopsis: This command allows you to configure a mapping between 802.1p user priority values (0-7) and internal traffic class values (0-6), which manage traffic prioritization. Can be used in Global or Interface Config modes.

summary: Maps an IP DSCP value to an internal traffic class.
synopsis: This command allows configuration of a mapping between specified IP DSCP values (0-63 or keywords) and internal traffic class values (0-6) to prioritize packet treatment based on DSCP markings. Available in Global Config mode.

summary: Sets the CoS trust mode on an interface.
synopsis: This command configures the trust mode for an interface to either Dot1p, IP DSCP, or untrusted, determining how packets are interpreted for prioritization. Applicable in Global or Interface Config modes.

summary: Resets the captive portal configuration to default values.
synopsis: This command restores the captive portal instance's configurations to their default values, effectively wiping out any custom settings previously applied.

summary: Clears active IAS client users from the system.
synopsis: The 'clear aaa ias-users' command is utilized to remove currently active users from the Internet Authentication Service (IAS) database on the device.

summary: Clears all accounting statistics.
synopsis: This command resets the accounting statistics related to user sessions and command executions, helping to maintain accurate tracking over time.

summary: Clears the ARP cache on the device.
synopsis: This command purges all entries from the ARP cache, forcing the device to re-learn MAC address mappings, which can be useful for troubleshooting connectivity issues.

summary: Clears the contents of the switch's ARP table.
synopsis: This command clears the contents of the switch’s ARP table that contains entries learned through the Management port. After executing this command, you should verify success by pinging from a remote system and checking the ARP entries with the show arp switch command.

summary: Clears the authentication history log for an interface.
synopsis: This command removes all stored authentication history for a specified interface or for all interfaces, which can be useful for clearing out old logs or after a significant configuration change.

summary: Clears the authentication statistics on an interface.
synopsis: This command is used to reset the authentication statistics for a specified interface or for all interfaces on the switch, effectively allowing you to start fresh in monitoring authentication attempts and successes.

summary: Deletes all entries of captive portal users.
synopsis: This command clears all captive portal user entries from the switch's configuration, effectively removing all local user accounts that were created.

summary: Clears the statistics for the checkpointing process.
synopsis: This command resets all checkpoint statistics to zero, useful for starting fresh monitoring after significant network changes or for troubleshooting purposes.

summary: Resets the switch configuration to factory defaults.
synopsis: The clear config command resets the current configuration on the switch to factory default values, prompting for confirmation before proceeding. This does not power off the switch.

syntax: clear counters {unit/slot/port | all | vlan vlan-id | lag lag-intf-num}
summary: Clears statistics for specified switch components.
synopsis: The clear counters command resets the statistics for a specified unit, slot, port, VLAN, LAG, or for all ports, helping network administrators to monitor and manage performance.

summary: Clears keep-alive statistics on interfaces.
synopsis: This command resets statistical counters related to keep-alive packets for interfaces, allowing for fresh monitoring.

summary: Resets DHCP L2 relay statistics on the specified interface.
synopsis: This command clears the statistics related to DHCP Layer 2 relay functionality for a specified interface, aiding in troubleshooting and monitoring DHCP relay performance.

summary: Clears authentication history for all or a specified interface.
synopsis: This command clears the authentication history table for 802.1X, which logs successful and unsuccessful authentication attempts on specific interfaces or all interfaces.

summary: Resets the 802.1X statistics for specified ports or all ports.
synopsis: This command clears the authentication statistics related to 802.1X for a particular port or all ports on the switch, allowing for fresh measurements of authentication attempts.

summary: Clears the system event log.
synopsis: This command purges the event log, which records various system events, alerts, and notifications, thus resetting historical records for maintenance or troubleshooting purposes.

summary: Reset green Ethernet mode statistics.
synopsis: This command clears the EEE LPI event count, LPI duration, and cumulative power-savings estimates for specified ports or for all ports. Parameters like EEE statistics will be reset for accurate monitoring.

summary: Clears the host information from the device.
synopsis: This command removes all host entries from the device memory, which can be useful for managing host tables or resolving network issues related to outdated or incorrect entries.

summary: Clears IGMP snooping state or statistics.
synopsis: This command resets the IGMP (Internet Group Management Protocol) snooping configurations or states, allowing for new group management and multicast traffic monitoring.

syntax: clear ip access-list counters {{acl-id | acl-name} | rule-id}
summary: Resets counters for specified IP access-list entries.
synopsis: This command enables network administrators to clear the statistics associated with specific rules or the entire IP access-list, aiding in troubleshooting and monitoring.

summary: Clears the detected address conflict status.
synopsis: This command resets the internal state of the switch regarding IP address conflicts, thus clearing the information on previously detected conflicts.

summary: Resets the statistics for Dynamic ARP Inspection on all VLANs.
synopsis: This command is used to reset the statistics for Dynamic ARP Inspection (DAI) across all VLANs. It provides a fresh start for monitoring ARP traffic and potential security violations.

summary: Clears DHCP bindings.
synopsis: This command removes existing DHCP binding entries, allowing for the reassignment of IP addresses to clients and resolution of connectivity issues.

summary: Clears DHCP conflict entries.
synopsis: Using this command will reset any detected IP address conflict entries within the DHCP configuration, facilitating smooth address assignments.

summary: Clears statistics for the DHCP server.
synopsis: This command clears accumulated statistics for the DHCP server operations, providing a fresh starting point for performance monitoring.

syntax: clear ip dhcp snooping binding [interface unit/slot/port]
summary: Clears all DHCP Snooping bindings.
synopsis: This command clears all DHCP Snooping bindings across all interfaces or targets a specific interface, effectively resetting the binding state.

summary: Resets DHCP snooping statistics.
synopsis: This command clears all statistical data related to DHCP snooping processes, allowing for a new assessment of DHCP operations and potential snooping attacks.

summary: Resets DHCP relay statistics to zero.
synopsis: This command clears the statistics shown by the 'show ip helper statistics' command, allowing for the tracking of DHCP relay statistics from a fresh start.

summary: Clears IP multicast route entries from the routing table.
synopsis: This command removes all or specified multicast route entries from the IP multicast routing table. It can delete either all entries or those matching a specific group address or both group and source addresses.

summary: Resets OSPF processes.
synopsis: This command clears ongoing OSPF (Open Shortest Path First) processes on the device, which can help in the re-evaluation of OSPF routing updates.

summary: Resets the OSPF configuration to factory defaults.
synopsis: This command clears the existing OSPF configuration, reverting the settings to their original default states.

summary: Resets OSPF statistics counters.
synopsis: By executing this command, accumulated OSPF statistics will be cleared, allowing for a fresh count and evaluation of OSPF routing performance.

summary: Drops the adjacency with all OSPF neighbors.
synopsis: This command drops the adjacency with all OSPF neighbors. It sends a one-way hello on each neighbor’s interface, allowing adjacencies to be re-established. To drop adjacencies with a specific router ID, specify the neighbor’s Router ID.

summary: Drops adjacency with neighbors on a specific interface.
synopsis: This command drops adjacency with all neighbors on a specified interface. To target a specific router ID on that interface, include the optional parameter neighbor-id.

summary: Clears OSPF redistribution settings.
synopsis: This command resets the redistribution configurations for OSPF routes, allowing for review or modification of route distributions between different routing protocols.

summary: Forces OSPF to exit stub router mode due to resource limitations.
synopsis: This command is used in Privileged EXEC mode to compel OSPF to exit stub router mode if it was automatically entered due to resource constraints or if it was configured to start in that state.

syntax: clear ip route {all | counters | ospf [ip-address subnet-mask [interface unit/slot/port]] | rip [ip-address subnet-mask [interface unit/slot/port]]}
summary: Resets IPv4 routing table counters or removes specific routes.
synopsis: This command allows users to clear all dynamic routes, reset routing table event counters, or specifically remove OSPF or RIP routes based on provided address and interface parameters.

summary: Clears VRRP interface statistics.
synopsis: This command resets the statistics for VRRP (Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol) on specific interfaces, helping in the monitoring of high availability mechanisms.

summary: Resets counters for specified IPv6 access-list entries.
synopsis: This command clears the statistics associated with specific rules or the entire IPv6 access-list, useful for monitoring IPv6 traffic and security.

syntax: clear ipv6 dhcp {statistics | interface unit/slot/port statistics}
summary: Clears DHCPv6 statistics for all or a specific interface.
synopsis: This command is used to reset the DHCPv6 statistics either globally for all interfaces or specifically for a defined interface by providing its unit/slot/port parameter.

summary: Deletes a DHCP binding entry from the server database.
synopsis: This command removes an automatic address binding from the DHCP server database. If an ipv6-address is specified, only that specific client's binding is deleted; otherwise, all bindings are cleared.

syntax: clear ipv6 dhcp snooping binding [interface unit/slot/port]
summary: Clears all DHCPv6 Snooping bindings on specified interfaces or globally.
synopsis: Use this command to remove all DHCPv6 Snooping bindings from the device. You can target specific interfaces or apply the command to all interfaces, effectively resetting dynamic bindings and enforcing new DHCP assignments.

summary: Clears all DHCPv6 Snooping statistics.
synopsis: This command is used to reset all statistics related to DHCPv6 Snooping, allowing for a fresh start in monitoring the security violations and counters for untrusted ports on the switch.

summary: Resets the MLD counters to zero on the specified interface.
synopsis: This command allows you to clear all MLD statistics, effectively resetting the count of packets and errors reported for the specified interface.

summary: Clears all MLD traffic entries.
synopsis: This command removes all entries in the MLD traffic database, allowing for the reset of traffic monitoring and statistics tracking.

summary: Deletes all or specified IPv6 multicast route entries.
synopsis: This command removes dynamic entries from the multicast routing table, but does not clear static routes. Use '*' to delete all entries or specify a group-address and optional source-address to clear specific entries.

summary: Clears the IPv6 neighbor table entries.
synopsis: This command removes all entries from the IPv6 neighbor table or clears entries for a specific interface by specifying the unit/slot/port. It is used to refresh the neighbor cache, which can help in troubleshooting connectivity issues.

summary: Disables and re-enables OSPF.
synopsis: This command is utilized to clear the OSPF process, effectively resetting the routing protocol, which can be helpful in troubleshooting or reinitializing OSPF.

summary: Resets the OSPF configuration to factory defaults.
synopsis: This command restores the OSPF configuration to its original state, erasing all custom settings and returning the OSPF setup to defaults, which may be necessary for reconfiguration.

summary: Resets global and interface statistics for OSPF.
synopsis: Use this command to clear the OSPF counters, allowing for a fresh start in performance monitoring and troubleshooting by resetting all operational statistics.

summary: Drops adjacency with all OSPF neighbors.
synopsis: This command closes the OSPF neighbor relationships and forces the routers to send one-way hello packets, enabling the possibility of re-establishing connections.

syntax: clear ipv6 ospf neighbor interface [unit/slot/port | vlan vland-id] [neighbor-id]
summary: Drops adjacency on a specific interface.
synopsis: This command terminates OSPF neighbor relationships on a specified interface, which can be chosen via physical routing interface parameters or VLAN IDs, and optionally by neighbor ID.

summary: Flushes all self-originated external LSAs and reapplies redistribution.
synopsis: This command clears all self-originated external Link State Advertisements (LSAs) from OSPF to enable a fresh redistribution process, ensuring updated route advertisements.

summary: Forces OSPF to exit stub router mode.
synopsis: This command is used to terminate OSPF stub router mode, only if it was entered due to resource limitations or at startup, allowing for regular routing operations to resume.

summary: Resets IPv6 routing table counters to zero.
synopsis: This command clears the event counters for the IPv6 routing table, as displayed by the show ipv6 route summary command. It does not reset counters that show the current number of routes of each type.

summary: Clears the counters for the IPv6 RA guard host mode.
synopsis: This command resets the IPv6 snooping counters associated with the router advertisements and router redirects that have been dropped due to the RA guard host mode.

syntax: clear ipv6 statistics [{unit/slot/port | loopback loopback-id | tunnel tunnel-id}]
summary: Resets IPv6 statistics for specified interfaces or all interfaces.
synopsis: Use this command to clear IPv6 statistics for all interfaces or for a specific interface, including loopback and tunnel interfaces. If no specific interface is provided, all IPv6 traffic statistics reset to zero.

summary: Clear ISDP counters.
synopsis: This command resets the counters for the ISDP (Intelligent Switch Discovery Protocol), which can help in analyzing ISDP effectiveness.

summary: Clears entries in the ISDP table.
synopsis: This command removes all entries from the ISDP table, effectively resetting the ISDP neighbor information currently held by the switch.

summary: Deletes all information from the LLDP remote data table.
synopsis: This command removes all entries from the LLDP remote data table, including any MED-related information, which can help in clearing outdated or incorrect entries.

summary: Resets all LLDP statistics.
synopsis: This command is used to reset all LLDP statistics, including those related to Media Endpoint Devices (MED), ensuring that all statistics start from zero for monitoring purposes.

summary: Clears buffered logging.
synopsis: This command resets the buffered system startup and operation logs, effectively removing all entries stored in the buffer.

summary: Resets email alerting statistics back to zero.
synopsis: This command clears all email alerting statistics, allowing for a fresh start to monitor the email alerting performance from this point on.

summary: Clears counters for specified MAC access-list entries.
synopsis: Similar to the IP version, this command resets the statistics for specified MAC access-list rules, helping in traffic management and security oversight.

syntax: clear mac-addr-table {all | vlan vlan-id | interface unit/slot/port | macaddr [macmask]}
summary: Clears dynamically learned MAC addresses from the MAC address table.
synopsis: This command removes learned MAC address entries from the forwarding table, which can be for all entries, a specific VLAN, a particular interface, or a specific MAC address (optionally using a mask).

summary: Deletes all MLD snooping entries from the MFDB table.
synopsis: This command quickly removes all MLD Snooping entries from the Multicast Forwarding Database, effectively resetting the MLD snooping state on the switch. It can be useful for troubleshooting or when making configuration changes.

summary: Clears MMRP statistics.
synopsis: Resets the MMRP (Multicast Media Registration Protocol) statistics, allowing for fresh monitoring of multicast registrations.

summary: Clears the MVRP database.
synopsis: Deletes all entries in the MVRP (Multiple VLAN Registration Protocol) database, facilitating a fresh start for VLAN registrations.

summary: Clears DHCPv6 statistics on the network management interface.
synopsis: This command resets the DHCPv6 statistics recorded on the network management interface, allowing for a fresh start in monitoring.

summary: Erases CA certificates used for validating OpenFlow controllers.
synopsis: This command deletes the stored certificate authority certificates, automatically disabling and re-enabling OpenFlow, with certificates reloaded upon the next connection.

summary: Resets user passwords to factory defaults.
synopsis: The clear pass command resets all user passwords to the default values, requiring confirmation before execution, ensuring access control is restored effectively.

summary: Clears and resets all port-channel and member flap counters.
synopsis: This command allows for the resetting of all counters associated with port-channels, supporting comprehensive monitoring and diagnostics.

summary: Clears counters for a specified port-channel.
synopsis: Resets the performance counters and error logs associated with a specific port-channel or member interface, often used to clear historical data.

summary: Clears all global and interface PFC statistics.
synopsis: This command removes all PFC statistics, allowing a fresh view of PFC operations. It is executed in Privileged EXEC mode.

summary: Reset RADIUS statistics.
synopsis: Clears the collected statistics related to RADIUS (Remote Authentication Dial In User Service), facilitating user authentication monitoring.

summary: Clears DHCPv6 client statistics on the service port interface.
synopsis: This command clears the statistics specific to DHCPv6 clients operating on the service port, helping in resetting and monitoring client performance.

summary: Clears the SNMP trap log.
synopsis: Executing this command removes all entries in the SNMP trap log, which can be useful for resetting monitoring programs or starting fresh analysis.

summary: Resets VLAN configuration parameters to factory defaults.
synopsis: The clear vlan command restores VLAN configuration to factory defaults, affecting dynamic VLANs and GVRP/MVRP settings, which may remove static VLANs and restore GVRP settings.

summary: Configures the dynamic authorization client IP or hostname.
synopsis: This command allows the specification of an IP address or hostname for the dynamic authorization client. It includes an optional server key for secure communication.

summary: Specifies a unique identifier for a DHCP client.
synopsis: This command assigns a unique hexadecimal identifier for a DHCP client, necessary in some systems, and follows a recognized format for media type concatenation.

summary: Specifies a name for a DHCP client.
synopsis: This command sets an identifiable name for a DHCP client, which can consist of standard ASCII characters, for easier management.

syntax: clock set hh:mm:ss | clock set mm/dd/yyyy
summary: Sets the system time and date.
synopsis: This command updates the system clock to the specified time in 24-hour format and also allows for setting the date. The date must be in the mm/dd/yyyy format, enabling accurate timekeeping.

syntax: clock summer-time date {date month year hh:mm date month year hh:mm} [offset offset] [zone acronym]
summary: Sets summer-time offset to UTC.
synopsis: This command configures a summer-time offset based on specific dates and times, accounting for changes in local time, with options for defining an additional offset and displaying a zone acronym.

syntax: clock summer-time recurring {week day month hh:mm week day month hh:mm} [offset offset] [zone acronym]
summary: Sets recurring summer-time parameters.
synopsis: This command establishes the recurring summer-time settings based on defined weeks and days, allowing for the proper application of daylight saving time parameters, including offsets and acronym displays.

summary: Sets the timezone offset from UTC.
synopsis: This command specifies the difference in hours and optionally minutes from Coordinated Universal Time (UTC), allowing proper time zone definitions for accurate timekeeping.

summary: Configures cloud-management settings.
synopsis: Enables or configures options for managing the device via a cloud management platform.

summary: Enters the Captive Portal Instance Mode.
synopsis: This command allows you to enter configuration mode for a specific captive portal instance, identified by a CP ID number ranging from 1 to 10, enabling specific configurations for that instance.

summary: Enters Global Config mode for device configuration.
synopsis: This command provides access to configure system settings including user accounts. From Global Config mode, you can enter additional command modes such as Line Config mode.

summary: Defines the conform-color class map for traffic policing.
synopsis: Use this command to enable color-aware traffic policing and define the conform-color class map. It is used in conjunction with the police command where the fields for the conform level are specified.

summary: Enables support debug display.
synopsis: This command activates the display of support debug information within the session, which can be critical for troubleshooting and system diagnostics.

summary: Uploads and downloads files to/from the switch.
synopsis: The copy command manages file transfers to and from the switch. It supports multiple protocols including FTP, TFTP, and SCP. Users can upload or download various configuration files, images, and logs, specifying the source and destination paths.

summary: Specifies minimum bandwidth guarantees for interface queues.
synopsis: This command sets minimum bandwidth guarantees as percentages for each supported queue on an interface. The total must not exceed 100%, and it can be used in Global or Interface Config modes.

summary: Activates weighted random early discard (WRED) for specified queues.
synopsis: This command enables WRED on specified queues for interfaces. In Global Config mode, it applies to all interfaces; in Interface Config mode, it affects a single interface. Up to n queue IDs can be specified, where n is the total number of queues supported.

summary: Activates strict priority scheduling for queues.
synopsis: This command configures specified queues to use strict priority scheduling, ensuring high-priority traffic is processed first. Can be applied in Global or Interface Config modes.

summary: Generates a self-signed certificate for HTTPS.
synopsis: This command triggers the creation of a new self-signed SSL certificate with a specified lifespan, linked to the device's lowest IP address.

summary: Generates a DSA key pair for SSH.
synopsis: Use this command to generate a DSA key pair for SSH. The new key files will overwrite any existing generated or downloaded DSA key files.

summary: Generates an RSA key pair for SSH.
synopsis: Use this command to generate an RSA key pair for SSH. The new key files will overwrite any existing generated or downloaded RSA key files.

summary: Enables IP event dampening on a routing interface.
synopsis: This command configures the dampening of unstable interfaces based on specific thresholds and penalties for flapping. The half-life period, reuse threshold, and suppress threshold values can be tuned for network stability.

summary: Configures class of service settings for Dante.
synopsis: This command sets the IGMP snooping querier interval to 30 seconds and applies specific DSCP mappings and QoS settings. This command is used in Global Config mode and is disabled by default.

summary: Applies Dante class of service settings to a specified VLAN.
synopsis: This command configures QoS parameters for all member ports within a specified VLAN, ensuring consistent QoS treatment across the VLAN. The VLAN ID ranges from 1 to 4093 and is used in Global Config mode.

summary: Enables debugging of User Manager accounting.
synopsis: This command allows detailed tracing of the accounting process in the User Manager, useful for troubleshooting issues related to service accounting.

summary: Enables debug tracing for AAA authorization.
synopsis: This command activates detailed debugging for authorization processes within User Manager, allowing users to diagnose issues related to command and exec authorizations.

summary: Displays debug information for the dynamic authorization server process.
synopsis: This command provides internal debug information about the dynamic authorization process on the switch, useful for troubleshooting and monitoring CoA functionality.

summary: Displays disconnect message packets.
synopsis: This command enables debugging for disconnect messages, allowing network administrators to see packets related to disconnections, which can aid in troubleshooting.

summary: Enables debugging of ARP requests and replies.
synopsis: This command provides real-time insights into Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) events, useful for troubleshooting IP address to MAC address mappings on the network.

syntax: debug authentication packet {all | event} interface unit/slot/port
summary: Displays debug trace for authentication events on an interface.
synopsis: This command shows either the debug trace for all authentication events or just a single event for a specified interface. It's important to enable the 'debug console' command to see the debug output.

summary: Enables debug messages for Auto VoIP.
synopsis: This command activates debug messages for Auto VoIP and allows tracing of H323, SCCP, SIP, and OUI packets. It needs 'debug console' to display traces.

summary: Disables all previously enabled debug traces.
synopsis: This command clears any active debug traces that have been enabled, allowing for a fresh start on debugging.

summary: Enables display of debug trace output in the current session.
synopsis: This command must be activated to view debug traces on the console. The effect is temporary and lasts only for the duration of the login session.

syntax: debug crashlog {proc | verbose | deleteall | [kernel] crashlog-number [upload url] | data crashlog-number [download url | upload url | component-id item-number additional-parameter]} [unit unit]
summary: Views information in the crash log file.
synopsis: Utilize this command to access detailed crash log information regarding system resets or failures, including memory status and process data. Requires enabling 'debug console' to view.

summary: Download or upload the debug-config.ini file.
synopsis: This command allows the user to download or upload a debug configuration file that executes predefined CLI commands on specified events. The debug config file must be manually created before use.

summary: Display debug information for DHCPv4 client activities.
synopsis: This command shows detailed information about DHCPv4 packets sent and received by the local DHCPv4 client, helping to troubleshoot interactions and issues. The command is disabled by default.

summary: Enables debugging for dot1x packets.
synopsis: This command activates debugging for dot1x packets, useful for monitoring authentication behaviors. 'debug console' must be enabled for trace visibility.

summary: Enables debug messages for dynamic ports.
synopsis: This command enables debug messages related to dynamic ports, which are combo ports capable of detecting the media type (either SFP for fiber or RJ45 for copper). It is executed in Privileged EXEC mode.

summary: Displays error logs related to environmental conditions.
synopsis: In Privileged EXEC mode, this command shows error logs including temperature readings, reset counts, and power module failures since the last reboot.

summary: Displays core dump features support.
synopsis: This command provides information regarding the support for various core dump features, aiding in diagnostics and configuration verification of exception management on the switch.

summary: Displays health and statistics of the I2C bus.
synopsis: Provides detailed information about the operational status and statistics of the I2C bus for a specified unit in the switch.

summary: Enables tracing of IGMP Snooping packets.
synopsis: Activates debugging for IGMP Snooping packets transmitted and received by the switch, contingent on enabled snooping on the device and interfaces. 'debug console' is needed for output.

summary: Enables tracing of received IGMP snooping packets.
synopsis: This command allows the switch to trace and display details of IGMP snooping packets that are received. The output includes details about the interface, source and destination MAC and IP addresses, and the type of IGMP packet received. This information is vital for troubleshooting IGMP snooping operations.

summary: Enables tracing of transmitted IGMP snooping packets.
synopsis: This command allows the switch to trace and display details of IGMP snooping packets that are transmitted. It includes information such as the interface, source and destination MAC and IP addresses, and the type of IGMP packet sent. The output is crucial for diagnosing IGMP snooping issues.

summary: Enables debug of IP Protocol packets matching the ACL criteria.
synopsis: This command allows the user to enable debug for IP protocol packets that match specified ACL criteria, providing visibility into the packet processing. The debug display requires the debug console command to be enabled.

summary: Enables tracing of DVMRP packet reception and transmission.
synopsis: This command allows tracing of DVMRP (Distance Vector Multicast Routing Protocol) packets, where the user can specify to trace either received or transmitted packets. It provides vital information like source and destination addresses and packet types.

summary: Enables tracing of IGMP packet reception and transmission.
synopsis: This command enables tracing for IGMP packets, with options to either trace received or transmitted packets. It provides detailed information about packet flow and types which is essential for diagnosing IGMP-related issues.

summary: Enables tracing of MDATA packet reception and transmission.
synopsis: This command allows the user to trace MDATA packets, specifying whether to trace received, transmitted, or both types of packets. It displays significant information that aids in monitoring MDATA traffic effectively.

summary: Trace PIMDM packet reception and transmission.
synopsis: This command allows tracing of PIMDM packets. The 'receive' keyword traces only received packets, while 'transmit' traces only transmitted packets. If neither keyword is used, all PIMDM packet traces are displayed. Important information like source and destination addresses, control packet type, packet length, and interface are shown.

summary: Trace PIMSM packet reception and transmission.
synopsis: Enable tracing of PIMSM packets with this command. Using 'receive' will trace only received packets and 'transmit' only transmitted ones. If neither is specified, all packet traces are dumped displaying vital information about each packet.

summary: Enables VRRP debug protocol messages.
synopsis: This command activates debugging for VRRP (Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol), providing detailed output of protocol messages essential for monitoring and troubleshooting VRRP setup.

summary: Displays debug information about DHCPv6 client activities.
synopsis: This command enables tracing of DHCPv6 packets exchanged by the local DHCPv6 client, providing crucial insight into client operation for troubleshooting and monitoring.

summary: Enables tracing of MDATAv6 packet reception and transmission.
synopsis: This command allows for tracing of MDATAv6 packets, specifying options for received, transmitted, or both. It displays important information to facilitate troubleshooting of MDATAv6 traffic.

summary: Traces MLDv6 packet reception and transmission.
synopsis: This command enables debugging for MLDv6 packets, giving insights into the reception and transmission processes, crucial for multicast listener function operations.

summary: Enables IPv6 OSPFv3 packet debug trace.
synopsis: This command activates tracing for OSPFv3 packets over IPv6, aiding in the troubleshooting of OSPF-related issues by providing essential diagnostic information.

summary: Traces PIMDMv6 packet reception and transmission.
synopsis: This command enables the tracing of PIMDMv6 packets for monitoring their receipt and transmission, helpful for diagnosing multicast routing over IPv6.

summary: Trace PIMSMv6 packet reception and transmission.
synopsis: This command allows tracing PIMSMv6 packets, with options to filter the trace output based on direction (receive or transmit) or display all.

summary: Enables tracing of ISDP packets processed by the switch.
synopsis: This command allows monitoring of ISDP packets for a specific interface, with the requirement of ISDP being enabled on the device and the interface. The debug console command must be enabled to display the debug trace.

summary: Enables tracing of LACP packets received and transmitted by the switch.
synopsis: This command allows for monitoring LACP packet traffic on the switch. The debug console must be enabled to view the output. By default, the feature is disabled.

summary: Trace MLD snooping packet reception and transmission.
synopsis: This command enables tracing of MLD snooping packets received and transmitted by the switch. The receive keyword traces only received MLD packets, and the transmit keyword traces only transmitted MLD snooping packets. If neither keyword is used, all traces are dumped.

summary: Enables debug tracing of MVR packets.
synopsis: This command activates debug tracing for MVR packets, allowing you to specify whether to trace received or transmitted packets.

summary: Enables MVR debug tracing.
synopsis: This command starts MVR debug tracing, allowing detailed insight into MVR process activities, which is useful for troubleshooting.

summary: Enables tracing of OSPF packets received and transmitted by the switch.
synopsis: This command allows for monitoring OSPF packet traffic through the switch, showcasing detailed packet information. The debug console must be enabled to view the output, and by default, this feature is disabled.

summary: Enables tracing of ICMP echo requests and responses.
synopsis: This command allows for detailed tracking of ICMP pings, showing request and response details across network and service ports. The debug console must be enabled to access output, and it is disabled by default.

summary: Turns on tracing of RIP requests and responses.
synopsis: Enables monitoring for RIP packets, providing detailed logs for requests and responses. The debug console must be enabled to view the logs, and by default, this is disabled.

summary: Enables sFlow debug packet trace.
synopsis: This command, executed in Privileged EXEC mode, turns on tracing for sFlow packets. It's useful for analyzing sampled packets from network traffic and needs a debug console enabled for output.

summary: Enables tracing of spanning tree BPDUs.
synopsis: This command allows the monitoring of spanning tree protocol Bridge Protocol Data Units (BPDUs) that are received and transmitted by the switch, which is essential for diagnosing spanning tree issues.

summary: Enables tracing of spanning tree BPDUs received by the switch.
synopsis: This command specifically focuses on monitoring the incoming BPDUs of the spanning tree, requiring the relevant interfaces to be enabled. The debug console must be activated to view traces, and is off by default.

summary: Enables tracing of transmitted spanning tree BPDUs.
synopsis: This command allows monitoring of spanning tree BPDUs being sent by the switch, requiring spanning tree to be enabled on the device and the relevant interface.

summary: Enables TACACS+ debugging.
synopsis: This command activates debugging for TACACS+ protocol operations, which can include debugging for packet transmission, reception, and the accounting and authentication processes.

summary: Enables debugging for file transfers.
synopsis: This command activates file transfer debugging in Privileged EXEC mode, which captures detailed logs regarding file upload and download operations to assist in diagnosing file transfer issues.

summary: Enables debugging for UDLD events.
synopsis: This command turns on debugging for the events related to UDLD (Unidirectional Link Detection). To see the debug trace, the debug console command must also be enabled.

summary: Displays received UDLD packets.
synopsis: This command provides debugging information about received UDLD packets, facilitating the identification of link status and potential problems.

summary: Displays transmitted UDLD packets.
synopsis: This command shows debugging details for UDLD packets sent from the device, aiding in the understanding of link detection capabilities.

summary: Controls the advertisement of default routes in RIP.
synopsis: The 'default-information originate' command is used to configure the advertisement of a default route in RIP, allowing the router to inform other routers about the default gateway.

summary: Sets a default metric for distributed routes in RIP.
synopsis: The 'default-metric' command sets a specified default metric value (from 0-15) for routes distributed via the Routing Information Protocol (RIP), impacting route selection.

summary: Specifies the default router list for a DHCP client.
synopsis: This command allows for the configuration of up to eight valid IP addresses that serve as default routers for the DHCP clients, enhancing their connectivity.

summary: Delete a specified image file from permanent storage.
synopsis: This command removes image1 or image2 from the permanent storage. It can specify a unit for member switches or execute on all members in the stack.

summary: Deletes a port from the port-channel (LAG).
synopsis: This command removes one or multiple ports from a specified port-channel. The interface specified can be an individual port or a range, and must be a part of an existing port-channel.

syntax: deny ip-source ip-address [mask {mask | prefix-length}] [service service] [priority priority]
summary: Sets deny conditions for the management access list based on the source IP address.
synopsis: Options for specifying a subnet mask, service type, priority, or a combination of these are available in Management access-list configuration mode. Each rule requires a unique priority.

summary: Prevents packets with specified priority.
synopsis: This command denies forwarding of packets based on their assigned priority, allowing for traffic shaping and management.

summary: Sets deny conditions based on access protocol.
synopsis: This command sets deny conditions for the management access list based on the access protocol, requiring a unique priority for the rule.

summary: Assigns a description to an interface.
synopsis: You can use this command to provide an alphanumeric description for better identification of an interface.

summary: Configures vendor ID option for DHCP client.
synopsis: This command sets the vendor ID option in DHCP requests sent by the client, providing additional identification for DHCP servers.

summary: Sets the DHCP Vendor Option-60 string.
synopsis: This command sets the string for the DHCP Vendor Option-60, which is included in the requests sent to the DHCP server.

summary: Enables the DHCP Layer 2 Relay agent for specified interfaces.
synopsis: This command sets the switch to operate as a DHCP Layer 2 relay agent to relay DHCP requests. It must be executed in Global or Interface Configuration mode to enable L2 relay functionality.

summary: Sets the DHCP Option-82 Circuit ID for a VLAN.
synopsis: This command configures the DHCP Option-82 Circuit ID for a specified VLAN. The interface number is added to DHCP requests as a Circuit ID when this option is enabled.

syntax: dhcp l2relay remote-id remoteid-string subscription-name subscription-string
summary: Sets the Option-82 Remote-ID string for a given service subscription.
synopsis: Configures the Option-82 Remote-ID string to be added to all Client DHCP requests matching the specified subscription-string. This is important for identifying service subscriptions in a network.

syntax: dhcp l2relay remote-id remote-id-string vlan vlan-list
summary: Sets the DHCP Option-82 Remote ID for a VLAN.
synopsis: This command configures the DHCP Option-82 Remote ID for a specified VLAN, allowing the Remote ID to be included in DHCP packets for that VLAN.

summary: Enables relaying DHCP packets for a specified service subscription.
synopsis: This command activates the relaying of DHCP packets that match a specified service subscription, identified by the subscription string, under the interface configuration.

summary: Configures an interface as trusted for Option-82 reception.
synopsis: This command designates a specified interface or range of interfaces as trusted to receive Option-82 DHCP packets, enhancing security and legitimacy of incoming requests.

summary: Enables the DHCP L2 Relay agent for specified VLANs.
synopsis: This command enables the DHCP L2 Relay functionality for a specified range of VLANs, processing all DHCP packets arriving on interfaces configured within those VLANs.

summary: Enables Differentiated Services for traffic management.
synopsis: This command enables Differentiated Services, which provides a mechanism for classifying and managing network traffic to ensure that critical applications receive the necessary bandwidth and priority.

summary: Lists the files in flash.
synopsis: This command provides a directory listing of files stored in the flash memory of the device, showing file types, sizes, and timestamps for better file management.

summary: Displays USB device contents and memory statistics.
synopsis: This command lists all files stored on the USB device, showing filenames, file sizes, and memory usage statistics such as total size, bytes used, and bytes free.

summary: Closes active HTTP, HTTPS, Telnet, or SSH sessions.
synopsis: Use this command to terminate current sessions either by specifying a session ID or by closing all active sessions at once. For session IDs, refer to the show loginsession command.

syntax: distance ospf {intra-area preference | inter-area preference | external preference}
summary: Sets route preference values for OSPF route types.
synopsis: This command modifies the administrative distance of OSPF routes, with lower values preferred, helping to prioritize routing decisions for intra-area, inter-area, and external types.

summary: Sets RIP administrative distance.
synopsis: This command sets the administrative distance for RIP (Routing Information Protocol) routes to manage OSPF vs. RIP protocols in routing decisions.

summary: Specifies an access list to filter routes received from a source protocol.
synopsis: This command defines a filtering mechanism for controlling which routes are permitted for redistribution into the OSPF process, based on specified access lists.

summary: Specifies the IP servers available to a DHCP client.
synopsis: This command specifies the IP servers available to a DHCP client. Address parameters must be valid IP addresses, each consisting of four decimal bytes ranging from 0 to 255. The address 0.0.0.0 is invalid.

summary: Executes Privileged EXEC commands from any configuration mode.
synopsis: The do command allows users to run Privileged EXEC mode commands from various configuration modes, facilitating command execution without needing to exit current configuration mode.

summary: Specifies the domain name for a DHCP client.
synopsis: This command configures the domain name that is issued to the DHCP client when it is allocated an IP address by the DHCP server. The specified domain name will be sent to the client.

summary: Enables sending the domain name to a RADIUS server.
synopsis: This command allows the switch to send the domain name to a RADIUS server, along with an optional username if provided. This is formatted as 'domain-name\username'.

summary: Specifies the domain name of a DNS server for RADIUS authentication.
synopsis: This command sets the domain name that the switch sends to the RADIUS server for authentication purposes. It should be used with the 'domain-name enable' command.

summary: Enables Denial of Service protection checks globally.
synopsis: This command activates all Denial of Service prevention checks for the switch, providing a comprehensive defense against various forms of attacks. The default state is disabled.

summary: Enables Minimum TCP Header Size Denial of Service protection.
synopsis: This command activates protection against denial of service attacks that exploit minimum TCP header sizes. It performs actions based on incoming packets’ TCP header sizes, ensuring that packets lower than the configured size are dropped.

summary: Enables ICMP Fragment Denial of Service protection.
synopsis: This command activates Denial of Service prevention for fragmented ICMP packets. If enabled, matching packets will be dropped.

summary: Enables Maximum ICMPv4 Packet Size Denial of Service protection.
synopsis: This command activates Denial of Service prevention for ICMPv4 Echo Request packets larger than the specified size. By default, it is disabled with a size limit of 512 bytes.

summary: Enables Maximum ICMPv6 Packet Size Denial of Service protection.
synopsis: This command activates Denial of Service prevention for ICMPv6 Echo Request packets larger than the specified size. By default, it is disabled with a size limit of 512 bytes.

summary: Enables L4 Port Denial of Service protections.
synopsis: This command activates protection against attacks exploiting identical source and destination Layer 4 ports, dropping packets with matching port numbers when the mode is enabled.

summary: Enables SIP = DIP Denial of Service protection.
synopsis: This command allows the switch to drop packets where the Source IP address equals the Destination IP address. If enabled, incoming packets with matching SIP and DIP will be discarded.

summary: Enables SMAC = DMAC Denial of Service protection.
synopsis: This command provides protection against packets that have the same source and destination MAC addresses. If enabled, such packets will be dropped.

summary: Enables TCP FIN, URG, and PSH with SEQ = 0 checking Denial of Service protections.
synopsis: This command safeguards against TCP packets that have the FIN, URG, and PSH flags set, while also ensuring that the sequence number is zero. If conditions are met, these packets will be dropped.

summary: Enables TCP Flag Denial of Service protections.
synopsis: This command enables safeguards against TCP packets that exhibit specific flag combinations. If enabled, packets with chance conditions (like SYN flag and a low source port) will be dropped.

summary: Enables TCP Flag and Sequence Denial of Service protections.
synopsis: This command enables enhancements against various TCP packet conditions, dropping packets based on specific flag settings and sequence numbers when the mode is enabled.

summary: Enables TCP Fragment Denial of Service protection.
synopsis: This command activates protection against TCP fragment attacks by dropping packets that have a TCP payload size less than the minimum required TCP header size, provided the protection mode is enabled.

summary: Enables TCP Offset Denial of Service protection.
synopsis: This command provides protection against denial of service attacks that utilize incorrect TCP header offsets, dropping packets if the header offset is equal to one.

summary: Enables TCP L4 source = destination port number Denial of Service protection.
synopsis: This command protects against denial of service attacks where the source and destination TCP port numbers are the same. If activated, matching packets will be dropped.

summary: Enables TCP SYN and L4 source = 0-1023 Denial of Service protection.
synopsis: This command protects against TCP SYN packets when the source port is within the 0 to 1023 range. Packets that trigger this condition will be dropped if enabled.

summary: Enables TCP SYN and FIN DoS protection.
synopsis: This command drops any TCP packets that have both SYN and FIN flags set, primarily to prevent certain anomalous traffic patterns that could indicate an attack.

summary: Enables UDP L4 source = destination port number Denial of Service protection.
synopsis: This command activates protection against UDP packets with equal source and destination port numbers. When enabled, these packets will be dropped.

summary: Enables the switch to create VLANs dynamically upon RADIUS-assigned VLAN requests.
synopsis: This command allows the switch to create VLANs dynamically when a requested VLAN by the RADIUS server is not already configured on the device, providing flexibility in handling user access.

summary: Enables EAPOL flood support on the switch.
synopsis: This command configures the switch to allow EAPOL (Extensible Authentication Protocol over LAN) flooding, which is typically needed for proper 802.1X authentication in specific network scenarios.

summary: Sets the guest VLAN for unauthenticated users.
synopsis: Specifies a VLAN for guest users who do not authenticate successfully to the network.

summary: Initializes dot1x configurations.
synopsis: Begins the process to configure dot1x settings on the device, preparing the system for authentication.

summary: Enables MAC Authentication Bypass on the interface.
synopsis: This command allows devices that do not support 802.1X to connect by using their MAC addresses for authentication when MAC-based mode is active.

summary: Specify maximum number of authentication requests.
synopsis: Sets the maximum number of authentication requests that can be sent to a client before the port is disabled.

summary: Sets the maximum number of concurrent dot1x users.
synopsis: Limits the number of users that can authenticate via dot1x at any one time on the device.

summary: Sets the port's dot1x role.
synopsis: This command configures the port to function as either a supplicant or authenticator, defining its role in the dot1x authentication process.

summary: Set port control mechanism.
synopsis: Configures the port control mechanism to manage how traffic is allowed on the port based on 802.1X authentication.

syntax: dot1x port-control all {force-unauthorized | force-authorized | auto | mac-based}
summary: Sets the authentication mode on all ports.
synopsis: This command allows the user to specify the port control mode for all interfaces: 'force-unauthorized', 'force-authorized', 'auto' (default), or 'mac-based' for MAC-based authentication.

summary: Begins the reauthentication sequence on the specified port.
synopsis: This command initiates a reauthentication process for the specified interface, provided it is in either auto or mac-based control mode.

summary: Enables reauthentication of the supplicant for the specified interface.
synopsis: This command activates reauthentication for clients connected to the specified port, enhancing security by requiring periodic validation.

summary: Configures the number of attempts to find an authenticator.
