synopsis: This command sets the maximum number of attempts (1-10) that a supplicant will make to locate an authenticator before deciding it doesn't exist, defaulting to 3 attempts.

summary: Sets the port's authorization state.
synopsis: This command specifies the authorization state of the port for dot1x, allowing for manual control or automatic authorization, essential for managing port access during authentication.

summary: Configures the authentication period timer interval.
synopsis: This command establishes how long the supplicant waits for a challenge from the authenticator during the authentication process, influencing overall connectivity timing.

summary: Configures the held period for retries on authentication failure.
synopsis: This command specifies the duration to wait after a failed authentication before reattempting, critical for managing repeated authentication attempts.

summary: Configures the start period timer for EAP identity request.
synopsis: This command allows setting the timer for the initial waiting period (1-65535 seconds) for the EAP identity request from the authenticator, with a default of 30 seconds.

summary: Maps a user to the port.
synopsis: This command allows the administrator to associate a specific user with a port for authentication purposes.

summary: Enables 802.1X authentication support on the switch.
synopsis: This command activates the 802.1X authentication system on the switch. Though configuration can still occur when disabled, it will not take effect until this command is issued.

summary: Enables 802.1X monitor mode for troubleshooting.
synopsis: This command allows the switch to enter monitor mode, which permits network access to hosts even when they fail the 802.1X authentication process, aiding in troubleshooting.

syntax: dot1x timeout {{guest-vlan-period seconds} |{reauth-period seconds} | {quiet-period seconds} | {tx-period seconds} | {supp-timeout seconds} | {server-timeout seconds}}
summary: Sets timeout values for 802.1X operations on interfaces.
synopsis: This command configures various timer settings for the authenticator state machine, affecting guest VLAN behavior, reauthentication timing, and suppression intervals.

summary: Configures the unauthenticated VLAN for interfaces.
synopsis: This command specifies an unauthenticated VLAN ID, allowing devices to access the network under certain conditions if they do not authenticate successfully.

summary: Adds a user to the access list for a port or all ports.
synopsis: This command permits the specified user to authenticate and access the network through the designated port or all ports.

summary: Specifies that packets for the associated traffic stream are dropped at ingress.
synopsis: This command ensures that all incoming packets for the specified traffic stream will be discarded, impacting the overall flow of packets defined by the class instance.

summary: Configures the ethertype for the specified interface.
synopsis: This command sets the ethertype for Double VLAN tagging on an interface, allowing differentiation of customer traffic in a Metro Core. Valid values include 802.1Q (0x8100), vman (0x88A8), or a custom value from 1 to 65535.

summary: Associates a TPID with the next available TPID register and sets it as primary if specified.
synopsis: This command allows configuration of a new TPID and associates it with the next available register, setting it as the default TPID if the primary-tpid keyword is used.

summary: Enables a cloud management agent.
synopsis: This command administratively activates the cloud management agent, allowing it to perform operations and initiate network requests to its cloud server. Note that enabling this mode does not automatically start the agent, which must be installed separately.

summary: Specifies the authentication method list for accessing higher privilege levels.
synopsis: This command is used to set the authentication method list when accessing a higher privilege level from remote interfaces. You can specify either a default method list or a user-defined list created with the aaa authentication enable command.

summary: Configures a password for privileged EXEC mode.
synopsis: This command allows administrators to set a password for accessing the privileged EXEC mode of the switch, with options for specifying the encryption type and providing either plain or encrypted passwords.

summary: Configures the link layer encapsulation type for an interface.
synopsis: This command allows the selection between Ethernet or SNAP encapsulation types for packets transmitted on a given interface. The default encapsulation is Ethernet and should be set within interface configuration mode.

summary: Configures the system to operate in a quiet mode, reducing fan noise.
synopsis: This command adjusts the fan settings of the device to a quieter operation mode, reducing the noise produced by the cooling system, which can be beneficial in noise-sensitive environments.

syntax: environment temprange min temperature max temperature
summary: Sets allowed temperature range for operation.
synopsis: Use this command to define the minimum and maximum temperature limits for operational status, ensuring the device operates within safe thermal conditions.

summary: Configures environment status traps for various components.
synopsis: This command is used in Global Config mode to enable or disable the sending of traps for specified environmental statuses including fan, power supply, and temperature events.

summary: Erases an executable application file from the switch.
synopsis: This command deletes an executable application file stored in the non-volatile memory of the switch.

summary: Erase stored factory default configuration.
synopsis: This command erases the factory default configuration file kept in non-volatile memory, removing the default settings.

summary: Erase the stacking configuration file.
synopsis: This command clears the stacking configuration file, which cannot be erased with the 'clear config' command.

summary: Erase the startup configuration file from non-volatile memory.
synopsis: This command erases the text-based configuration stored in non-volatile memory. If no startup-config is found during boot, AutoInstall starts automatically.

syntax: errdisable recovery cause {all | arp-inspection | bpduguard | dhcp-rate-limit | sfp-mismatch | udld | ucast-storm | bcast-storm | mcast-storm | bpdustorm | mac-locking | denial-of-service | link-flap}
summary: Enables auto recovery for specific error causes on interfaces.
synopsis: This command allows for the configuration of auto recovery for interfaces that have been placed in an error-disabled state due to specified errors. If enabled, the interface will be re-enabled when a preset recovery interval expires.

summary: Enables autorecovery of interfaces from keep-alive loops.
synopsis: This command allows interfaces that have been troubled by a loop to automatically recover, as per the specified keep-alive settings.

summary: Configures the auto recovery period for error-disabled interfaces.
synopsis: This command sets the time interval for auto recovery when the switch attempts to bring interfaces back into service after an error, with a configurable range from 30 to 86400 seconds.

summary: Configures a prefix for core file names.
synopsis: This command defines a prefix for generated core dump file names, based on specified parameters like hostname or timestamp.

summary: Enables compression mode for core dumps.
synopsis: This command activates the compression feature for core dump files being generated by the switch.

summary: Configures a file-path for core file dumps.
synopsis: This command allows the configuration of a specific file path used to store core dump files either on TFTP, FTP, NFS, or USB.

syntax: exception dump ftp-server ip-address [{username user-name password password}]
summary: Configures a remote FTP server for core file dumps.
synopsis: This command allows specification of an FTP server's IP address for core dumps; optional credentials are also supported for authentication.

syntax: exception dump stack-ip-address add ip-address netmask [gateway]
summary: Adds a static IP address for a unit's service port after a crash.
synopsis: This command specifies a static IP address, netmask, and optionally a gateway for a unit's service port that will be used after a crash for core dump purposes.

summary: Configures the protocol for service port IP address after a crash.
synopsis: This command allows the administrator to specify whether dynamic (DHCP) or static addressing will be used for a unit's service port following a crash.

summary: Removes the dump of stack IP addresses.
synopsis: Use this command to remove the existing dump of stack IP addresses, thereby clearing any previously stored information related to the stack's IP settings.

summary: Displays the TFTP server dump.
synopsis: This command outputs the details of the TFTP server dump, providing information useful for troubleshooting TFTP configuration issues.

syntax: exception protocol {nfs | tftp | ftp| usb | none}
summary: Specifies the protocol for storing core dump files.
synopsis: This command allows the administrator to choose the protocol for storing core dump files generated by the switch, with options including NFS, TFTP, FTP, USB, or none.

summary: Enable or disable switch-chip-register dump on exception.
synopsis: This command configures the switch-chip-register dump to occur only for the master in case of an exception, allowing monitoring of the switch's state.

summary: Configures the OSPF exit overflow interval.
synopsis: This command sets the time the router will wait before leaving the overflow state after exceeding its LSDB limit. A setting of 0 prevents leaving the overflow state without a restart.

summary: Configures the external LSDB limit for OSPF.
synopsis: Limits the number of nondefault AS-external-LSAs in OSPF's database. When reached, the router enters overflow state. Range: -1 to 2147483647. Default is -1 (no limit).

summary: Configures the IP address, subnet mask, and gateway for the switch management CPU.
synopsis: This command initiates an interactive utility that guides users through setting the management CPU's IP address, subnet mask, and other essential settings in a user-friendly manner.

summary: Enables digital signature verification during file transfers.
synopsis: This command sets the digital signature verification policy for images and configuration files downloaded to the switch. It can verify both types, only images, disable verification, or specifically verify configuration scripts.

summary: Displays the description of a specified file.
synopsis: Use this command to view the description of a specific file, aiding in identifying files and their purposes within the system.

summary: Enable symmetric or asymmetric flow control on the switch.
synopsis: This command configures the flow control mode for the switch, allowing you to manage how the switch responds to PAUSE frames and control traffic flow in various scenarios.

summary: Customize the foreground color of the Captive Portal authentication page.
synopsis: Use this command to set the foreground color of the Captive Portal authentication page using a well-known color name or RGB value. The color-code can be a valid color name or RGB hex-code like #FF0000, ranging from 1 to 32 characters. Default color is #999999.

summary: Enable EEE low-power idle mode on an interface.
synopsis: This command enables both send and receive sides of the link to disable some functionality for power saving when lightly loaded. The transition does not change the port link status.

summary: Configures the EEE transmit idle time on the specified interface(s).
synopsis: This command sets the amount of time a port waits before transitioning to low-power idle mode, measured in microseconds, which helps optimize power-saving during inactivity.

summary: Configures the EEE transmit wake time on the specified interface(s).
synopsis: This command defines how long the switch must wait before returning to active state from low-power idle mode after receiving a packet for transmission.

summary: Configures the global maximum samples for EEE LPI history collection.
synopsis: This command sets the maximum number of samples to retain for EEE LPI history globally across all interfaces, optimizing memory use and data analysis capabilities.

summary: Configures the global EEE LPI history sampling interval.
synopsis: This command sets the interval at which the switch collects LPI history data, enabling better analysis of energy savings and power efficiency on all interfaces.

summary: Enables energy-detect mode on the specified interface(s).
synopsis: This command enables energy-detect mode, allowing a port to save power by automatically powering down when no link is detected and periodically waking to check for link pulses.

summary: Assigns a group ID to the captive portal configuration.
synopsis: This command specifies a group ID, which must be provided for each captive portal configuration. The ID falls within a range of 1 to 1024, with 1 as the default.

summary: Configures a 40G QSFP port on the APM402XL port card.
synopsis: This command configures a 40G QSFP port on the APM402XL port card to operate either in 1x40G mode or 4x10G mode. The configuration is retained regardless of port status but is applied only when the port is in the attached state. Default mode is 1x40G. Executed in Interface Config mode.

summary: Specifies the hardware address of a DHCP client.
synopsis: This command specifies the MAC address of the DHCP client, consisting of 6 bytes in dotted hexadecimal format. The type indicates the protocol of the hardware platform.

summary: Specifies the IP address and network mask for a manual binding to a DHCP client.
synopsis: This command specifies the IP address and network mask for a DHCP client. The address and mask must be valid IP addresses and cannot be 0.0.0.0.

summary: Sets the system's host name.
synopsis: This command assigns a new host name to the system, changing the prompt accordingly. The name can be up to 64 alphanumeric characters and is case-sensitive. Used in Privileged EXEC mode.

summary: Configure acceptance of host routes
synopsis: This command determines how host routes are managed by the device, allowing for finer control over routing decisions.

summary: Configures an additional HTTP port.
synopsis: This command allows the configuration of an extra HTTP port, excluding standard ports 80 and 443. Default is 0 for no additional port.

summary: Set HTTPS port
synopsis: This command configures the port for HTTPS access, ensuring secure management and monitoring capabilities over the network.

summary: Configures idle timeout for the captive portal.
synopsis: This command allows you to set the idle timeout for a captive portal configuration in seconds. A value of 0 means that no timeout is enforced.

summary: Configures the switch to ignore the server key.
synopsis: This command modifies the switch's settings to ignore the server key, which can be useful in testing or specific authorization scenarios.

summary: Ignore the session key
synopsis: This command allows the device to bypass the session key verification, which can be helpful in troubleshooting or specific configuration settings.

summary: Forces the backup unit to become the management unit and perform a warm restart.
synopsis: This command allows the backup unit to take over as the management unit while preserving hardware tables, enabling applications to apply checkpointed data from the former management unit. If conditions aren’t suitable for a warm restart, the command fails with a warning message.

summary: Associates an interface with a captive portal configuration.
synopsis: This command allows the association of a specific interface to a captive portal configuration, enabling the application of the captive portal rules to traffic passing through that interface.

summary: Configure Link Aggregation Group (LAG)
synopsis: This command sets up Link Aggregation Groups, enabling the combination of multiple physical links for improved bandwidth and redundancy.

summary: Enters Interface Config mode for a loopback interface.
synopsis: This command allows you to configure a loopback interface identified by loopback-id, which ranges from 0 to 7, serving as a reliable source for packet generation.

summary: Enters Interface Config mode for a tunnel interface.
synopsis: This command allows you to configure a tunnel interface specified by tunnel-id, which can range from 0 to 7, enabling further configuration of the tunnel settings.

summary: Enters Interface configuration mode for a specified VLAN.
synopsis: This command allows access to the configuration mode for a specific VLAN ID, facilitating the configuration of its routing parameters.

syntax: ip access-group {accesslistnumber | name} {{control-plane| in | out} | vlan vlan-id {in | out}} [sequence 1-4294967295]
summary: Applies an IP access control list (ACL) to an interface or VLAN.
synopsis: This command associates an IP access control list, identified by accesslistnumber or name, with a range of interfaces or VLANs. It supports sequence numbers for precedence and control-plane options for managing traffic, essential for specific IPv4 control packets.

summary: Creates an extended IP Access Control List (ACL).
synopsis: This command creates an extended IP Access Control List (ACL) identified by name, with classification fields for the IP header of an IPv4 frame. If an ACL with the same name exists, it enters IPv4-Access_List config mode for updates.

summary: Changes the name of an existing IP ACL.
synopsis: This command modifies the name of an IP Access Control List (ACL). The new name must not already exist; it should be a unique alphanumeric string of 1 to 31 characters.

syntax: ip access-list resequence {name | id} starting-sequence-number increment
summary: Renumbers the sequence of entries for a specified IP ACL.
synopsis: Use this command to change the sequence numbers of ACL rules in a specified IP access list, starting from a defined number and incrementing by a specified value. The changes are temporary and not saved in startup configurations.

summary: Configures an IP address on an interface.
synopsis: This command sets a primary or secondary IP address on an interface. It supports RFC 3021 for 31-bit prefixes, applicable only on routing interfaces.

summary: Enables DHCP client on an interface.
synopsis: This command allows an interface to obtain network parameters automatically from a DHCP server, simplifying IP address management.

summary: Triggers active IP address conflict detection.
synopsis: This command activates the address conflict detection feature, which sends gratuitous ARP packets to identify conflicting IP addresses among connected devices.

syntax: ip arp inspection filter acl-name vlan vlan-list [static]
summary: Set ARP ACL to filter invalid ARP packets on specified VLANs.
synopsis: Configures an ARP Access Control List (ACL) to validate ARP packets based on the defined VLAN ranges. If 'static' is included, non-permitted packets are dropped without checking DHCP bindings.

syntax: ip arp inspection limit {rate pps [burst interval seconds] | none}
summary: Configure rate limit and burst interval values for an interface in Dynamic ARP Inspection.
synopsis: Sets the rate limit in packets per second and burst interval for the interface involved in Dynamic ARP Inspections. Default values are 15 pps and 1 second. A value of 'none' disables the rate limit.

summary: Configures an interface as trusted for DAI.
synopsis: This command marks the specified interface or range of interfaces as trusted, allowing ARP packets to bypass some validation checks.

summary: Enables additional validation checks for ARP packets.
synopsis: This command configures the switch to perform additional checks on received ARP packets for source MAC, destination MAC, and IP address validation.

summary: Enables Dynamic ARP Inspection on specified VLANs.
synopsis: This command activates Dynamic ARP Inspection (DAI) for the specified VLAN range, helping to secure the network by filtering invalid ARP packets.

syntax: ip arp inspection vlan vlan-list logging
summary: Enables logging of invalid ARP packets for specified VLANs.
synopsis: With this command, you can configure the switch to log invalid ARP packets on the specified VLANs for monitoring and troubleshooting.

summary: Sets the priority for packets destined for a specific IPv4 address.
synopsis: This command sends all packets with a specified destination IPv4 address to a higher priority queue (5) than the default queue for data packets and unicast packets to the CPU.

summary: Configures a default gateway for the switch.
synopsis: This command sets the primary gateway for traffic leaving the switch when no specific route exists, serving as the next hop for outbound packets.

summary: Enables automatic configuration of DHCP for BOOTP clients.
synopsis: This command configures the device to automatically provide DHCP services to BOOTP clients, allowing them to receive IP addresses and other configuration parameters.

summary: Enables logging of DHCP conflicts.
synopsis: This command enables the logging of IP address conflicts detected by the DHCP server, assisting in troubleshooting and network management.

summary: Excludes specified addresses from DHCP allocation.
synopsis: This command configures specific IP addresses to be excluded from being assigned by DHCP, ensuring certain devices retain static IP addresses.

summary: Enables sending ping packets for DHCP leases.
synopsis: This command configures the DHCP server to send ping packets to verify that assigned IP addresses are not in use, preventing address conflicts.

summary: Configures a DHCP address pool name and enters DHCP pool configuration mode.
synopsis: This command is used to create and configure a DHCP address pool on the switch, allowing for management of IP address assignments for clients.

summary: Enables DHCP snooping globally.
synopsis: This command activates DHCP snooping, a security feature that helps prevent unauthorized DHCP servers from providing clients with invalid IP addresses.

syntax: ip dhcp snooping binding mac-address vlan vlan-id ipaddress interface interface-id
summary: Configures DHCP Snooping binding.
synopsis: This command is used to configure a static DHCP Snooping binding for a device, linking the MAC address and IP address to a specific VLAN and interface.

summary: Configures the location of the DHCP Snooping database.
synopsis: This command sets the DHCP Snooping database's persistent location, either as a local file or a remote file on a specified TFTP server.

syntax: ip dhcp snooping database write-delay seconds
summary: Sets the write delay for the DHCP Snooping database.
synopsis: This command configures the interval in seconds for how often the DHCP Snooping database is updated, allowing a range between 15 to 86400 seconds.

syntax: ip dhcp snooping limit {rate pps [burst interval seconds]}
summary: Controls the rate of DHCP Snooping messages on an interface.
synopsis: This command sets a rate limit for incoming DHCP Snooping messages on interfaces, with a range from 0 to 300 packets per second, plus the ability to specify a burst interval.

summary: Enables logging of invalid DHCP messages.
synopsis: This command allows the logging of invalid DHCP messages received on an interface, which can assist in monitoring and diagnosing network issues.

summary: Marks a port as trusted for DHCP.
synopsis: This command designates an interface as trusted for DHCP traffic, allowing DHCP responses from a DHCP server while preventing rogue servers from providing leases.

summary: Enables verification of source MAC address in DHCP messages.
synopsis: This command configures the switch to verify that the source MAC address corresponds to the client's hardware address in received DHCP messages.

summary: Enables DHCP snooping on a VLAN.
synopsis: This command enables DHCP snooping for a specific VLAN, helping to prevent unauthorized DHCP requests and responses within that VLAN.

summary: Defines a list of default domain names for unqualified names.
synopsis: Use this command to create a list of default domain names for hostname resolution. The default domain name will only be used when this list is empty, allowing up to 32 entries in the list.

summary: Enables the DNS client.
synopsis: This command activates the DNS client functionality on the device, allowing it to resolve domain names to IP addresses. By default, this feature is enabled.

summary: Defines a default domain name for the switch.
synopsis: This command sets a default domain name that the switch uses to complete unqualified host names. If an unqualified hostname is provided, a DNS query is sent to resolve it using the specified default domain.

summary: Specifies the number of DNS query retries.
synopsis: This command configures how many times the system should attempt to resend a DNS query in the event of a timeout, with a configurable range of 0 to 100.

summary: Specifies wait time for DNS query responses.
synopsis: This command sets the timeout duration, in seconds, for how long to wait for a DNS server's response, allowing configuration of responsiveness.

summary: Activates DVMRP on the router.
synopsis: This command sets the administrative mode of Distance Vector Multicast Routing Protocol (DVMRP) in the router to active, enabling multicast routing functionality.

summary: Configures the metric for DVMRP interfaces.
synopsis: This command allows the specification of a metric value between 1 and 31 for an interface or range of interfaces, determining the cost to reach the associated network in DVMRP messages.

summary: Configures DVMRP SNMP trap notifications.
synopsis: This command sets which events will trigger SNMP traps for DVMRP, allowing for better monitoring and alerting of multicast events.

summary: Enables the relay of UDP packets on the router.
synopsis: This command allows for temporary disabling of the IP helper feature without deleting configured IP helper addresses. It broadly affects relay of all protocols configured with an IP helper address.

syntax: ip helper-address {server-address | discard} [dest-udp-port | dhcp | domain | isakmp | mobile-ip | nameserver | netbios-dgm | netbios-ns | ntp | pim-auto-rp | rip | tacacs | tftp | time]
summary: Configures relay of UDP broadcast packets received on a specific interface.
synopsis: This command can be invoked multiple times on a routing interface to specify multiple server addresses for a given port number or multiple port numbers handled by a specific server. The server address cannot be on the interface where the relay entry is configured.

summary: Maps a hostname to an IPv4 address.
synopsis: Defines static hostname-to-IP address mapping in the host cache. The host name can include 1–255 alphanumeric characters and special symbols, with spaces enclosed in quotation marks.

summary: Enables HTTP/HTTPS command accounting.
synopsis: This command configures command accounting for commands executed via HTTP or HTTPS, aiding in tracking user actions and improving security.

summary: Specifies authentication methods for HTTP server users.
synopsis: This command defines the authentication methods for users accessing the HTTP server. The methods will be applied in the specified order, using additional methods if the previous fails.

summary: Configures the port for the HTTP server.
synopsis: This command specifies the TCP port number on which the HTTP server will listen for incoming connections, allowing custom configurations.

summary: Configures the port for the HTTPS server.
synopsis: By using this command, you can define the TCP port that the HTTPS server will utilize, enabling secure communications on a specified port.

summary: Enables the secure HTTP server.
synopsis: This command activates the secure server capabilities for HTTP, ensuring that management traffic is encrypted to improve security.

summary: Configures hard time-out for secure HTTP sessions.
synopsis: This command specifies the maximum time a secure HTTP session can remain active before requiring re-authentication, with a minimum range of 1 to 168 hours without an option for infinite timeout.

summary: Limits the maximum number of secure sessions.
synopsis: This command defines the maximum number of simultaneous secure HTTP sessions that the device will allow, helping to manage resources effectively.

summary: Sets soft timeout for HTTPS sessions.
synopsis: This command configures a soft timeout for HTTP secure sessions that gives a grace period before session termination, allowing connected users to continue working.

summary: Enables HTTP access to the switch's web interface.
synopsis: This command makes the switch accessible through the web interface, allowing users to log in. Disabling access takes effect immediately.

summary: Configures hard time-out for unsecure HTTP sessions.
synopsis: This command sets a maximum duration for unsecure HTTP sessions, forcing re-authentication after the specified time. Setting it to zero gives an infinite timeout.

summary: Limits the number of concurrent unsecure HTTP sessions.
synopsis: This command restricts the number of HTTP sessions that can be active concurrently, where the maximum is configurable between 0 to 16.

summary: Configures soft time-out for unsecure HTTP sessions.
synopsis: This command sets a timer for unsecure HTTP sessions that forces re-authentication after the specified number of minutes, with a minimum configurability of 1 to 60 minutes.

summary: Configures HTTPS authentication methods.
synopsis: This command specifies authentication methods for HTTPS server users, supporting multiple methods with a fallback mechanism, ensuring reliability even if the primary method fails.

summary: Enables or disables ICMP echo replies.
synopsis: This command controls whether the device will reply to ICMP echo requests (ping), which can be useful for security and network visibility.

summary: Limits the rate of ICMP error messages sent.
synopsis: This command allows you to limit the rate at which IPv4 ICMP error messages are sent, using a token bucket with burst-size and burst-interval parameters. To disable, set burst-interval to zero.

summary: Enables IGMP on the system.
synopsis: This command sets the administrative mode of IGMP in the system to active on an interface, range of interfaces, or on all interfaces. Default is disabled.

summary: Enables header validation for IGMP messages.
synopsis: This command activates checking of IGMP message headers to ensure they are constructed correctly, enhancing network integrity and security.

summary: Sets the last-member query count for IGMP.
synopsis: This command sets the number of Group-Specific Queries sent by the interface before the router assumes there are no local members. Count can range from 1 to 20.

summary: Configures the response time for Group-Specific Queries.
synopsis: This command adjusts the Maximum Response Time for responses to Leave Group messages, impacting how quickly the router responds to multicast group status changes.

summary: Sets the query interval for IGMP Host-Query packets.
synopsis: This command configures how often IGMP Host-Query packets are sent on the specified interface, which can affect multicast membership discovery.

summary: Configures maximum IGMP query response time.
synopsis: This command configures the maximum response time interval for the specified interface, which is the maximum query response time advertised in IGMPv2 queries on this interface. The time interval is specified in deciseconds, ranging from 0 to 255, with a default of 100 deciseconds.

summary: Configures robustness for expected packet loss.
synopsis: This command configures the robustness value to adjust for expected packet loss on a subnet. If high packet loss is anticipated, the robustness variable can be increased, with the number argument ranging from 1 to 255. The default robustness value is 2.

summary: Sets the number of startup IGMP Queries.
synopsis: This command configures the number of IGMP Queries sent out on startup, separated by the Startup Query Interval. The number argument can range from 1 to 20, with a default value of 2.

summary: Sets the interval for startup IGMP Queries.
synopsis: This command configures the interval between General Queries sent on startup for a specified interface; the time interval is defined in seconds, with a range from 1 to 300 seconds, and a default of 31 seconds.

summary: Sets the IGMP version for an interface.
synopsis: This command configures which version of IGMP (1, 2, or 3) to use on a specific interface, influencing multicast group management behavior.

summary: Enables IGMP Proxy on an interface.
synopsis: This command activates IGMP Proxy functionality on the specified interface, allowing the system to act as a proxy for multicast traffic on behalf of hosts connected to that interface.

summary: Resets the host interface status parameters of the IGMP Proxy.
synopsis: This command is used to clear and reset the current status parameters associated with the IGMP Proxy interface, which can be helpful for troubleshooting.

summary: Sets the unsolicited report interval for the IGMP Proxy.
synopsis: Configures the time interval in seconds at which the IGMP Proxy interface sends unsolicited group membership reports, which helps in managing multicast traffic more effectively.

summary: Enables Router Discovery on an interface.
synopsis: This command activates Router Discovery Protocol on a specified interface or range of interfaces, allowing hosts to discover the IP addresses of routers in the subnet.

summary: Configures the address for sending router discovery advertisements.
synopsis: This command sets the multicast address used for router discovery advertisements from the interface, allowing it to be configured to either 224.0.0.1 or 255.255.255.255.

summary: Configures the holdtime for router advertisements.
synopsis: This command sets the duration (in seconds) that the system holds the router advertisement before discarding it, with valid values ranging from 4 to 9000 seconds.

summary: Configures the maximum advertisement interval for router signals.
synopsis: This command determines the longest interval (in seconds) allowed between router advertisements sent from the interface, with a range from 4 to 1800 seconds.

summary: Configures the minimum advertisement interval for router signals.
synopsis: This command sets the shortest interval (in seconds) between router advertisements sent from the interface, with valid values spanning from 3 to 1800 seconds.

summary: Configures the destination for router advertisements.
synopsis: This command sets the destination address for router advertisements to 224.0.0.1 by default, with an option to change to 255.255.255.255.

summary: Sets preference for default router address.
synopsis: This command allows you to define the preference of the address as a default router address on the subnet, where the value can range from -2147483648 to 2147483647.

summary: Configures load-sharing behavior.
synopsis: This command sets the load-sharing mechanism for routing traffic across multiple paths, with options for balanced, per-packet, or per-destination methods.

summary: Enables local proxy ARP for an interface.
synopsis: This command allows an interface to respond to ARP requests for all IP addresses within its own subnet and to forward traffic between those hosts. Executed in Interface Config mode.

syntax: ip management {vlan number | port unit/slot/port} {dhcp | ipaddr {prefix-length | subnet-mask}}
summary: Creates and configures an IPv4 management interface.
synopsis: This command is used to create an IPv4 management interface, enable DHCP, delete a previous interface, and set the source interface for applications like RADIUS and SysLog.

syntax: ip management source-interface {serviceport | vlan number | port unit/slot/port | loopback number}
summary: Specifies the source IP for all applications on the management interface.
synopsis: This command sets the source IP address for various applications, enabling the switch to identify itself for protocols such as RADIUS and SNMP based on the specified source interface.

summary: Adds an administrative scope multicast boundary.
synopsis: This command sets up a multicast boundary based on the given group IP address and mask, applicable for a single interface or a range of interfaces in Interface Config mode.

syntax: ip mroute src-ip-addr src-mask rpf-addr preference
summary: Configures a static multicast route for a source address.
synopsis: This command sets up a static multicast route, allowing incoming multicast traffic from specified sources to be routed properly. The preference value controls administrative distance.

summary: Sets the IP Maximum Transmission Unit (MTU) on an interface.
synopsis: This command defines the size of the IP MTU for a routing interface, which represents the largest packet size that can be transmitted without fragmentation. It must be set in interface configuration mode, with values ranging from 68 to 12270 bytes, defaulting to 1500 bytes.

summary: Enables the IP multicast forwarder on the router.
synopsis: This command activates the IP multicast forwarding capability of the router, allowing it to process multicast traffic.

summary: Applies a Time-to-Live threshold value to a routing interface.
synopsis: This command configures the TTL threshold for multicast data packets, determining the maximum allowed TTL value for forwarded packets on the interface in Interface Config mode.

summary: Configures the available name servers.
synopsis: This command enables the configuration of up to eight DNS servers, allowing the switch to resolve domain names according to user-defined preferences.

syntax: ip name source-interface {unit/slot/port | loopback loopback-id | tunnel tunnel-id | vlan vlan-id}
summary: Specifies the source interface for DNS client management.
synopsis: This command defines which network interface should be used as the source IP address for DNS queries, enhancing security and packet identification.

summary: Enables forwarding of network-directed broadcasts on an interface.
synopsis: This command enables the forwarding of network-directed broadcasts on specified interfaces, allowing such broadcasts to be forwarded to other networks. By default, this feature is disabled and must be configured in interface configuration mode.

summary: Enable OSPF and set the area ID for an interface.
synopsis: This command configures the specified interface or range of interfaces to participate in OSPF and assigns an area ID formatted as either a 4-digit dotted-decimal number or a decimal value. It can also control advertising secondary addresses into the OSPFv2 domain.

syntax: ip ospf authentication {none | simple key | encrypt key keyid}
summary: Configures the OSPF authentication type for the interface.
synopsis: This command sets the OSPF authentication method for an interface. You can choose 'none', 'simple' with an 8-byte key, or 'encrypt' with a key up to 16 bytes and a key ID between 0 and 255. Unauthenticated interfaces do not need a key.

summary: Configures the cost on an OSPF interface.
synopsis: This command assigns a cost value to the OSPF interface, which ranges from 1 to 65535, affecting the OSPF routing decision process. The default cost is set to 10.

summary: Disables OSPFv2 LSA flooding on an interface.
synopsis: This command stops the OSPF interface from flooding link state advertisements (LSAs) to reduce unnecessary network traffic, applicable in Interface Configuration mode. The default is disabled.

summary: Sets the OSPF dead interval for the specified interface.
synopsis: This command configures the duration in seconds that Hello packets can go undetected before a router is declared down by its neighbors. Values must be between 1 and 65535, with a default of 40 seconds.

summary: Set OSPF hello interval for an interface.
synopsis: This command establishes the duration in seconds between OSPF hello packets sent by an interface, which is critical for maintaining neighbor relationships in OSPF.

summary: Disables OSPF MTU mismatch detection.
synopsis: This command allows OSPF to ignore mismatched MTU sizes on adjacent interfaces, enabling OSPF adjacency establishment even if the MTU values differ.

summary: Sets the OSPF network type.
synopsis: The command configures OSPF network types; broadcast is the default. In point-to-point mode, OSPF operates without electing a designated router, optimizing performance in networks with only two routers.

summary: Suppresses IPv4 prefix advertisements associated with an interface.
synopsis: This command controls the advertisement of IPv4 prefixes. When configured, only prefixes associated with secondary IPv4 addresses are advertised. The 'disable' option excludes specific interfaces from prefix suppression.

summary: Sets the OSPF priority for the interface.
synopsis: This command specifies the OSPF priority for the given interface. The priority level ranges from 1 (lowest) to 255 (highest). A priority of 0 makes the router ineligible to become the designated router.

summary: Sets the OSPF retransmit interval for the specified interface.
synopsis: This command configures the interval in seconds for link-state advertisement retransmissions, with acceptable values ranging from 0 to 3600 seconds. The default is set to 5 seconds.

summary: Sets the OSPF transmit delay for the interface.
synopsis: This command configures the estimated seconds it takes to transmit link-state update packets over an interface, ranging from 0 to 3600 seconds, with a default of 1 second.

summary: Enables PIM on the specified interface.
synopsis: This command allows PIM to be administratively enabled on a specified interface, facilitating multicast routing on that interface.

summary: Configures the interface as a BSR border.
synopsis: This command marks the interface as a boundary for Bootstrap Router (BSR) messages, managing multicast distribution across networks.

syntax: ip pim bsr-candidate interface {unit/slot/port | vlan vlan-id} hash-mask-length [bsr-priority] [interval interval]
summary: Configures the router as a BSR candidate.
synopsis: This command announces the router's candidacy as a Bootstrap Router (BSR), specifying the interface or VLAN and optional parameters for priority and advertisement intervals.

summary: Enables PIM Dense mode on the router.
synopsis: This command sets the router to use Protocol Independent Multicast Dense Mode, allowing multicast traffic to be routed effectively in dense traffic environments.

summary: Sets the DR priority for the router.
synopsis: This command configures the priority for which a router is elected as the designated router (DR), affecting multicast routing decisions.

summary: Configures the frequency of PIM hello messages on an interface.
synopsis: This command sets the transmission frequency of PIM hello messages for the specified interface, with the interval ranging from 0 to 18000 seconds.

summary: Sets the join/prune interval for PIM.
synopsis: This command configures the interval for sending join and prune messages, influencing how quickly multicast group memberships are updated.

syntax: ip pim rp-address rp-address group-address group-mask [override]
summary: Defines a PIM Rendezvous Point (RP) address.
synopsis: This command specifies the address of a PIM Rendezvous Point (RP) for a multicast group range, influencing multicast routing behavior.

syntax: ip pim rp-candidate interface {unit/slot/port | vlan vland-id} group-address group-mask [interval interval]
summary: Advertise the router as a PIM candidate rendezvous point for a multicast group range.
synopsis: This command configures the router to present itself as a PIM candidate RP to the BSR for specific multicast groups, using either physical interfaces or VLANs. It requires PIM-SM to be active.

summary: Enables PIM Sparse mode on the router.
synopsis: This command configures the router to use Protocol Independent Multicast Sparse Mode, which is essential for efficient multicast routing in sparse traffic environments.

summary: Enables Source-Specific Multicast (SSM) mode.
synopsis: Configures Protocol Independent Multicast (PIM) for Source-Specific Multicast (SSM) to allow receivers to receive traffic from specific sources.

summary: Enable PIM trap mode for multicast.
synopsis: Activates PIM trap mode for both Sparse Mode and Dense Mode multicast configurations, facilitating multicast routing operations.

summary: Applies a route map for policy-based routing on an interface.
synopsis: This command designates a route map for use in policy-based routing, ensuring that routing decisions are made based on defined policies rather than solely on standard routing protocols.

summary: Enables proxy ARP on a router interface.
synopsis: This command enables proxy ARP on a router interface or range of interfaces. Without proxy ARP, a device only responds to ARP requests for IPs configured on the interface. With it enabled, the device may respond if the target IP is reachable through other interfaces.

summary: Enables ICMP Redirect message generation by the router.
synopsis: Use this command to enable the generation of ICMP Redirect messages by the router. By default, this option is enabled and can be applied to an interface, a range, or all interfaces.

summary: Enables RIP on an interface or a range of interfaces.
synopsis: The 'ip rip' command is used to enable the Routing Information Protocol (RIP) on a specified router interface, facilitating route information sharing.

syntax: ip rip authentication {none | {simple key} | {encrypt key keyid}}
summary: Sets the RIP authentication type and key for interfaces.
synopsis: This command sets the RIP version 2 authentication type and key for the interface. Authentication types include none, simple, or encrypt.

syntax: ip rip receive version {rip1 | rip2 | both | none}
summary: Configures which RIP control packets are received.
synopsis: This command sets the versions of RIP control packets that the interface can receive, impacting routing protocol interoperability.

syntax: ip rip send version {rip1 | rip2 | rip-1c | none}
summary: Configures which RIP control packets are sent.
synopsis: This command defines the versions of RIP control packets the interface can send, determining outgoing routing advertisement formats.

syntax: ip route ipaddr subnetmask [nexthopip | Null0 | interface {unit/slot/port | vlan vlan-id}] [preference] [description description]
summary: Configure a static route.
synopsis: This command allows the configuration of a static route to a specified destination IP address using a defined subnet mask and specifying the next hop router's IP. Optionally, you can set a preference value to prioritize routes and add a description.

summary: Configures a default static route to a specified next hop.
synopsis: This command sets the default route for handling any traffic not matching other routes. It specifies the next hop and allows setting a preference for this route, which defaults to 1.

summary: Set the default distance for static routes.
synopsis: This command defines the default preference value for static routes, which influences routing decisions. Routes with lower distance values are preferred. The change applies only to routes created after the command.

syntax: ip route net-prototype prefix/prefix-length nexthopip num-routes
summary: Adds net prototype IPv4 routes to the hardware.
synopsis: This command allows the addition of IPv4 routes to the hardware by specifying the destination network along with the prefix length, the next-hop IP address, and the number of routes to add. It must be executed in global configuration mode.

summary: Enables IP Router Admin Mode for the switch.
synopsis: This command activates the router mode on the switch, allowing it to function primarily as a routing device, essential for inter-VLAN traffic management.

summary: Enables SSH access to the system.
synopsis: This command activates SSH functionality on the device, transitioning from other remote access methods to a more secure SSH connection method.

summary: Configures SSH server TCP port.
synopsis: This command sets the specific TCP port number the SSH server will listen on for incoming connection requests, allowing for custom port configurations.

summary: Enables the IP secure shell server.
synopsis: This command turns on the SSH server, allowing existing connections while preventing new connections until the server is temporarily disabled.

summary: Configures the TCP port for the Telnet server.
synopsis: This command sets the port number where the Telnet server listens for requests, with valid values ranging from 1 to 65535. Default is 23.

summary: Enables Telnet server functionality on the device.
synopsis: This command activates the Telnet server service, allowing remote users to access the device over the Telnet protocol.

summary: Configures acceptance of gratuitous ARP packets on unnumbered interfaces.
synopsis: This command enables the device to accept gratuitous ARP messages, aiding in IP address discovery in certain network environments.

summary: Uses the loopback interface for unnumbered IP addressing.
synopsis: This command allows the router to use the loopback interface's IP address as the source address for outgoing packets on an unnumbered interface.

summary: Enables ICMP Destination Unreachable message generation.
synopsis: Use this command to enable the generation of ICMP Destination Unreachable messages on an interface or range of interfaces. By default, the generation of these messages is enabled.

syntax: ip verify binding mac-address vlan vlan-id ipaddress interface interface-id
summary: Configures static IP source guard entries.
synopsis: This command establishes a static entry in the IP source guard database to enforce that only specified MAC and IP address combinations can communicate on designated VLANs and interfaces.

summary: Configures the IPSG source ID for data traffic filtration.
synopsis: This command configures IPSG source ID using IP and MAC addresses for traffic filtering, allowing settings on a single interface or a range of interfaces. By default, filtering is based on the IP address. The 'port-security' option enables filtering based on both IP and MAC addresses.

summary: Configures VRRP on an interface.
synopsis: This command sets up Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol (VRRP), allowing multiple routers to work together to provide redundancy for a virtual IP address.

summary: Allow the VRRP Master to accept ping packets.
synopsis: This command enables the VRRP Master to accept ICMP Echo Request packets sent to its configured virtual IP addresses. It only permits ICMP ping packets, with vrid specifying the virtual router ID, ranging from 1 to 255.

syntax: ip vrrp vrid authentication {none | simple key}
summary: Set authorization details for the virtual router.
synopsis: This command configures the authentication type for the specified VRRP interface. Use 'none' for no authentication or 'simple' with a key for a password. The vrid (virtual router ID) must be specified.

summary: Assigns a virtual IP address for VRRP.
synopsis: This command specifies the virtual IP address that will be shared among VRRP routers, allowing for seamless failover.

summary: Configures the operation mode for VRRP.
synopsis: This command allows setting the operation mode of VRRP, such as 'master' or 'backup', affecting how the device participates in the VRRP group.

summary: Set preemption mode for the virtual router.
synopsis: This command enables preemption for the specified VRRP interface, allowing a higher-priority router to take over as the master. The vrid (virtual router ID) must be provided, ranging from 1 to 255.

summary: Set the priority of a router within a VRRP group.
synopsis: This command configures the priority value for the specified VRRP interface, which determines its election as master. The priority can range from 1 to 254, with vrid specifying the virtual router ID.

syntax: ip vrrp vrid timers advertise seconds
summary: Set the frequency for sending VRRP advertisements.
synopsis: This command configures the time interval for sending VRRP advertisements from the specified interface, with seconds ranging from 1 to 255. The vrid (virtual router ID) is also required.

syntax: ip vrrp vrid track interface {unit/slot/port | vlan vlan-id} [decrement priority]
summary: Alter VRRP priority based on interface availability.
synopsis: This command allows the VRRP configuration to adjust its priority based on the state of tracked interfaces. Specify the vrid (virtual router ID) and the interface or VLAN to track, with an optional decrement priority argument.

syntax: ip vrrp vrid track ip route ip-address/prefix-length [decrement priority]
summary: Track route reachability for priority adjustments.
synopsis: This command tracks the specified IP route for reachability and adjusts the VRRP router's priority accordingly. The vrid (virtual router ID) and the IP route must be specified, with an optional decrement priority argument.

summary: Creates a new IPv6 Access Control List.
synopsis: This command initiates the creation of an IPv6 ACL with a specified name, enabling the definition of filtering rules. If an ACL with the same name exists, it enters configuration mode to update the ACL.

summary: Renames an existing IPv6 access list.
synopsis: The command allows you to change the name of a specified IPv6 access list to a new name, helping in better management and identification of access lists.

syntax: ipv6 access-list resequence {name | id} starting-sequence-number increment
summary: Renumbers the sequence of entries in an IPv6 access list.
synopsis: This command changes the sequence numbers of ACL rules in the specified IPv6 access list by starting from a defined sequence number and incrementing by a specified value, allowing rearrangement of rules.

summary: Configures an IPv6 address on an interface.
synopsis: This command assigns an IPv6 address to the specified interface and enables IPv6 processing. Multiple addresses may be assigned, and the optional eui-64 allows for automatic generation of the lower 64-bits.

summary: Enables the interface to acquire an IPv6 address via NDP.
synopsis: This command allows the interface to automatically configure an IPv6 address using Neighbor Discovery Protocol and Router Advertisement messages.

summary: Enable DHCPv6 client on an interface.
synopsis: This command activates the DHCPv6 client on the interface, allowing it to acquire IPv6 address and network information from a DHCP server.

summary: Sets the priority for packets destined for a specific IPv6 address.
synopsis: The command allows all packets with a specified destination IPv6 address into a higher priority queue (5) than the default queue for data packets and unicast packets to the CPU.

summary: Enables prefix delegation for IPv6 on an interface.
synopsis: This command configures the interface to act as an IPv6 DHCP client with prefix delegation, allowing the interface to request and assign addresses from the defined prefix. The 'rapid-commit' option enables quicker exchanges between client and server.

summary: Enters IPv6 DHCP Pool Configuration mode.
synopsis: This command is used to create or configure an IPv6 DHCP pool which will hold parameters for addresses to be distributed to clients. Use 'exit' to leave this mode.

syntax: ipv6 dhcp relay {destination [relay-address] interface [relay-interface] | interface [relay-interface]} [remote-id {duid-ifid | user-defined-string}]
summary: Configures an interface to relay DHCPv6 messages.
synopsis: This command sets up an interface for DHCPv6 relay, enabling the interface to forward DHCPv6 messages between clients and servers. You can specify relay server addresses and relay interfaces, with additional options for remote ID customization.

summary: Configures DHCPv6 server functionality on an interface.
synopsis: This command allows the specified interface to provide DHCPv6 server functionality. It can be linked to a defined pool for address allocation, and options include 'rapid-commit' for faster operations and a 'preference' value to dictate the priority of responses to clients.

summary: Enables IPv6 DHCP Snooping globally.
synopsis: This command activates DHCP snooping security features globally, which helps to prevent unauthorized DHCP servers on the network by validating DHCP messages.

syntax: ipv6 dhcp snooping binding mac-address vlan vlan-id ipaddress interface interface-id
summary: Configures static DHCP Snooping binding.
synopsis: This command allows the creation of a static binding for a specific MAC address, VLAN, IP address, and interface.

summary: Configures the location of the DHCP Snooping database.
synopsis: This command sets the persistent storage location for the DHCP Snooping database, allowing it to be stored locally or on a remote TFTP server.

syntax: ipv6 dhcp snooping limit {rate pps [burst interval seconds]}
summary: Control the rate of DHCP Snooping messages.
synopsis: This command configures the rate limiting for DHCP Snooping messages on the specified interface or range, defaulting to no limit.

summary: Enables logging of invalid DHCP messages.
synopsis: This command configures the DHCP Snooping application to log filtered DHCP messages, enhancing monitoring capabilities.

summary: Configures an interface as trusted for DHCP messages.
synopsis: This command marks an interface or a range of interfaces as trusted to receive DHCP DORA messages.

summary: Enables MAC address verification in DHCP messages.
synopsis: This command allows the validation of the source MAC address against the hardware address in DHCP messages to ensure integrity and prevent spoofing.

summary: Enables DHCP Snooping on specified VLANs.
synopsis: This command configures DHCP snooping for specific VLAN ranges, safeguarding these VLANs from malicious DHCP traffic while managing legitimate DHCP operations.

summary: Enables IPv6 routing on an interface.
synopsis: This command activates IPv6 routing on the specified interface or range of interfaces, automatically creating a link-local address if not explicitly configured.

summary: Configures the unicast hop count for IPv6 packets.
synopsis: This command sets the hop limit for unicast IPv6 packets originating from the node, with valid values ranging from 1 to 255. If not configured, zero is sent in advertisements.

summary: Maps a hostname to an IPv6 address.
synopsis: Defines static hostname-to-IPv6 address mapping in the host cache. Host names can include a variety of characters and should be enclosed in quotation marks when containing spaces.

summary: Limits the rate of ICMPv6 error messages sent.
synopsis: This command configures a token bucket to manage the rate at which ICMPv6 error messages can be sent, allowing for control over network traffic generated by error conditions.

syntax: ipv6 management {vlan number | port unit/slot/port} {autoconfig | dhcp | prefix prefix-length}
summary: Configures the IPv6 management interface.
synopsis: Use this command to set up an IPv6 management interface on a specified VLAN or port, enabling IPv6 and DHCPv6, or to delete a previously created interface. Defaults are not provided by the switch.

summary: Set the number of listener-specific queries before assuming no local members.
synopsis: This command configures the number of listener-specific queries sent, ranging from 1 to 20, before the router concludes there are no local members on an interface. The default value is 2.

summary: Set the last member query interval for MLD interfaces.
synopsis: This command sets the last member query interval for an MLD interface, which defines the maximum response time for group-specific queries sent out. Valid range for milliseconds is 0 to 65535, with a default of 1000 milliseconds.

summary: Sets the MLD query interval.
synopsis: Configures the interval for the MLD queries sent by the router. This value dictates how frequently the router queries multicast group members on the specified interface.

summary: Sets the maximum response time for MLD queries.
synopsis: This command defines the maximum response time for MLD queries on the specified interface, with a range from 0 to 65535 milliseconds; defaults to 10000 ms.

summary: Enables MLD on the router.
synopsis: This command is used to enable Multicast Listener Discovery (MLD) on the router in global configuration mode; it is disabled by default.

summary: Specifies the number of startup MLD queries.
synopsis: This command sets the number of MLD queries sent at startup, with a default of 2 and a range from 1 to 20 on the specified interface.

summary: Sets the startup query interval for MLD.
synopsis: This command sets the time interval between general MLD queries at MLP startup on the specified interface; range from 1 to 300 seconds with a default of 31 seconds.

summary: Configures the MLD version for the interface.
synopsis: This command sets the MLD version in use by the specified interface, with version 2 set as default. It can be reset by using the 'no ipv6 mld version' command.

summary: Enables MLD-Proxy on the interface or range of interfaces.
synopsis: To configure MLD-Proxy, this command sets the interface for multicast forwarding; ensure no other multicast routing protocols are active.

summary: Resets the status of MLD proxy.
synopsis: This command is used to reset the Multicast Listener Discovery (MLD) proxy status, which may be necessary for troubleshooting or reinitializing the MLD proxy settings.

summary: Sets the unsolicited report interval for the MLD-Proxy interface.
synopsis: The command adjusts the frequency at which the MLD-Proxy interface sends unsolicited reports, ranging from 1 to 260 seconds.

syntax: ipv6 mroute src-ip-addr src-mask rpf-addr [interface] preference
summary: Configures an IPv6 multicast static route for a source.
synopsis: This command sets up a static multicast route for an IPv6 source where src-ip-addr is the source IP, src-mask is its mask, rpf-addr is the next-hop router's address, optionally specifying an interface and preference value.

summary: Sets the Maximum Transmission Unit (MTU) size for IPv6.
synopsis: This command configures the maximum size of a packet that can be transmitted over an IPv6 interface, affecting performance and fragmentation.

summary: Set duplicate address detection attempts on an interface.
synopsis: This command configures the number of probes sent for duplicate address detection to ensure IPv6 address uniqueness on the interface.

summary: Sets the managed address configuration flag in router advertisements.
synopsis: This command configures the managed address configuration flag in router advertisements on the interface, which determines whether end nodes use DHCPv6.

summary: Sets the MTU value for IPv6 router advertisements.
synopsis: This command sets the MTU value for IPv6 router advertisements on an interface, with permissible values between 1280 and the maximum MTU minus 18.

summary: Sets the interval between neighbor solicitations.
synopsis: This command sets the interval between router advertisements for advertised neighbor solicitations in milliseconds.

summary: Enable or disable the other configuration flag.
synopsis: This command manages the flag that signals if other configuration options are available through DHCP for IPv6.

summary: Configures parameters for advertised prefixes in router advertisements.
synopsis: This command configures parameters associated with prefixes in router advertisements, including valid and preferred lifetimes, applicable to a single or multiple interfaces.

summary: Configures router to send RAs with unspecified Hop Limit.
synopsis: This command sets the router to send Router Advertisements on an interface with an unspecified (0) Current Hop Limit value, instructing hosts on that link to ignore the Hop Limit from this router.

summary: Sets the transmission interval between router advertisements.
synopsis: This command sets the transmission interval between router advertisements on the interface within the range of 4–1800 seconds.

summary: Sets the value in the Router Lifetime field of advertisements.
synopsis: This command sets the value, in seconds, that is placed in the Router Lifetime field of the router advertisements sent from the interface.

summary: Enables IPv6 RA guard host mode on an interface.
synopsis: This command enables the IPv6 RA guard host mode on the specified interface, dropping all router advertisement and redirect packets received.

summary: Sets reachable time for neighbor discovery.
synopsis: This command specifies the time in milliseconds for the router advertisement to consider a neighbor reachable after neighbor discovery confirmation, with a range of 0–4294967295 milliseconds.

summary: Configures default router preference in RAs.
synopsis: This command sets the router preference advertised by the interface in router advertisement messages, with default set to medium.

summary: Suppresses Router Advertisements.
synopsis: This command disables the sending of Router Advertisement messages, effectively preventing devices from receiving IPv6 configuration information.

syntax: ipv6 neighbor ipv6address {unit/slot/port | vlan vland-id} macaddr
summary: Configures a static IPv6 neighbor.
synopsis: This command configures a static IPv6 neighbor with the specified IPv6 and MAC addresses on a routing or host interface.

summary: Enables periodic automatic renewal of IPv6 neighbor entries.
synopsis: This command automatically renews IPv6 neighbor entries by enabling/disabling periodic Neighbor Unreachability Detection (NUD) based on existing hardware activity. If enabled, it triggers NUD for 300 entries every 40 seconds, ensuring efficient neighbor management.

summary: Configures settings for Neighbor Unreachability Detection (NUD).
synopsis: This command allows configuration of NUD parameters, such as backoff multiple for timeout calculations and the maximum number of multicast/unicast solicits sent, to optimize neighbor discovery and reachability checks.

summary: Set the OSPF area for an interface.
synopsis: This command assigns a specific OSPF area to a router interface. If the area does not already exist, it is created with default values. The area ID must be a valid 32-bit integer or a 4-digit dotted-decimal number.

summary: Sets the OSPF cost for an interface.
synopsis: This command configures the cost associated with OSPF for the specified interface, affecting how routes are preferred within OSPF. The cost must be a positive integer between 1 and 65535.

summary: Sets the OSPF dead interval.
synopsis: This command sets the OSPF dead interval for the specified interface or range of interfaces, where the value represents the time in seconds before declaring a neighbor down; valid values are from 1-65535, default is 40.

summary: Set the OSPF hello interval for an interface.
synopsis: This command establishes the frequency of Hello packets sent by an OSPF router. The value must be consistent across all routers on the same network, adhering to a valid range of 1 to 65535.

summary: Enables Link LSA Suppression on an interface.
synopsis: The 'ipv6 ospf link-lsa-suppression' command disables the transmission of Link LSA packets on point-to-point interfaces, which can help reduce unnecessary traffic.

summary: Disable MTU mismatch detection for OSPF.
synopsis: This command alters OSPF behavior so that it does not reject Database Description packets based on differing MTUs between neighbors, which aids in establishing OSPF adjacencies.

summary: Changes the OSPF network type for an interface.
synopsis: This command alters the OSPF network type settings for an interface, allowing it to be set to broadcast or point-to-point, which can optimize OSPF operations and reduce overhead.

summary: Suppresses IPv6 prefix advertisement.
synopsis: This command suppresses the advertisement of IPv6 prefixes associated with an interface, while enabling, excluding secondary addresses; the disable option can be used to stop suppression even if it is enabled globally.

summary: Set the OSPF priority for an interface.
synopsis: This command determines the OSPF priority level for an interface, affecting the router's eligibility to be the designated router. Priority must be a value between 0 and 255.

summary: Set the OSPF retransmit interval for an interface.
synopsis: This command specifies the time to wait before retransmitting OSPF link-state advertisements, allowing fine-tuning of adjacency maintenance and overall OSPF performance.

summary: Sets the OSPF transmit delay for the specified interface.
synopsis: This command sets the OSPF transmit delay for the specified interface in seconds, which represents the estimated time to transmit a link state update packet. The valid range is 0 to 3600 seconds with a default of 1.

summary: Enables PIM on an interface or range of interfaces.
synopsis: This command administratively enables PIM (Protocol Independent Multicast) on designated interfaces, allowing multicast traffic to be managed correctly. By default, PIM is disabled.

summary: Prevents BSR messages on an interface.
synopsis: Use this command to configure an interface to not send or receive bootstrap router (BSR) messages. Effective only with PIM-SM enabled.

syntax: ipv6 pim bsr-candidate interface {unit/slot/port | vlan vland-id} hash-mask-length [bsr-priority] [interval interval]
summary: Configures a router's candidacy as a bootstrap router (BSR).
synopsis: This command defines the router as a candidate for becoming a BSR by specifying the interface or VLAN from which the BSR address is derived, including optional parameters for priority and advertisement interval.

summary: Enables PIM-DM administrative mode.
synopsis: This command activates the administrative mode of Protocol Independent Multicast - Dense Mode (PIM-DM) in the router. By default, this setting is disabled.

summary: Sets the DR priority value for router election.
synopsis: This command defines the priority of a router for DR (Designated Router) elections, influencing which router will assume the DR role based on its priority value.

summary: Configures the PIM hello interval for the specified interface.
synopsis: This command allows you to set the hello interval for PIM on an interface, which determines how often hello messages are sent. The interval can be set between 0 and 18000 seconds, with a default of 30 seconds.

summary: Configures the join/prune interval for the PIM-SM router.
synopsis: This command sets the time interval for join/prune messages to be sent by the PIM-SM router, thereby managing multicast group memberships more efficiently.

summary: Defines the address of a PIM Rendezvous point (RP) for a multicast group.
synopsis: This command allows the configuration of an RP address for a specific multicast group range, essential for managing multicast traffic efficiently.

syntax: ipv6 pim rp-candidate interface {unit/slot/port | vlan vland-id} group-address group-mask [interval interval]
summary: Advertise the router as a PIM candidate RP.
synopsis: This command allows the router to declare itself as a candidate RP for specific multicast groups, participating in PIM bootstrap processes.

summary: Enables PIM-SM administrative mode.
synopsis: This command activates the administrative mode of Protocol Independent Multicast - Sparse Mode (PIM-SM) on the router. Default setting is disabled.

summary: Defines the Source Specific Multicast (SSM) range of IPv6 multicast addresses.
synopsis: This command allows for setting the SSM range for multicast addresses on the router, facilitating source-specific multicast traffic management.

syntax: ip prefix-list list-name {[seq number] {permit | deny} ipv6-prefix/prefix-length [ge length] [le length] | renumber renumber-interval first-statement-number}
summary: Creates or modifies a prefix list to match specific route prefixes.
synopsis: This command is used in Global Configuration mode to establish a prefix list containing multiple entries that help match route prefixes with specified criteria, allowing for fine-tuned routing policies and entry management.

summary: Enables ICMPv6 Redirect message generation by the router.
synopsis: This command enables the generation of ICMPv6 Redirect messages by the router on specified interfaces. By default, this option is enabled.

syntax: ipv6 route ipv6-prefix/prefix_length {next-hop-address | Null0 | interface {unit/slot/port | vlan vlan-id | tunnel tunnel_id} next-hop-address} [preference]
summary: Configure an IPv6 static route.
synopsis: This command establishes a static IPv6 route, specifying a destination network and next-hop address, with optional parameters for routing preference and interfaces.

summary: Sets the default distance for IPv6 static routes.
synopsis: This command adjusts the preference value for IPv6 routes, allowing for finer control over routing decisions based on distance.

syntax: ipv6 route net-prototype prefix/prefix-length nexthopip num-routes
summary: Add net prototype IPv6 routes to hardware.
synopsis: This command allows users to specify a net prototype IPv6 route to the hardware with details about the destination and next hop.

summary: Enters Router OSPFv3 Config mode.
synopsis: This command allows you to configure settings for OSPFv3, a link-state routing protocol used to route traffic within a network by entering the router configuration mode.

syntax: ipv6 traffic-filter name {{control-plane | in | out} | vlan vlan-id {in | out}} [sequence 1-4294967295]
summary: Attaches a specific IPv6 ACL to an interface.
synopsis: The 'ipv6 traffic-filter' command associates an existing IPv6 ACL with an interface or VLAN in a desired direction. An optional sequence number indicates the rule's order relative to other ACLs, with the ability to specify control-plane as well.

summary: Enables forwarding of IPv6 unicast datagrams.
synopsis: This command activates the functionality for the switch to forward IPv6 unicast datagrams, which is disabled by default.

summary: Enables the generation of ICMPv6 Destination Unreachable messages.
synopsis: Use this command to enable the interface to send ICMPv6 Destination Unreachable messages, which facilitate communication troubleshooting by notifying peers of unreachable destinations.

summary: Controls the rate of incoming IPv6 data packets.
synopsis: This command sets a rate limit, expressed in packets per second, for the amount of IPv6 traffic that can reach the CPU, helping to prevent overload and maintain performance.

summary: Verifies IPv6 neighbor bindings.
synopsis: This command enables verification of IPv6 neighbor address binding, ensuring that binding information matches the intended configuration.

summary: Configure IPv6SG source ID attribute.
synopsis: This command sets the source ID for filtering data traffic, allowing filtering by either just IP address or both IP and MAC addresses with port security.

summary: Sets the aging time for iSCSI sessions.
synopsis: This command configures the duration for which iSCSI sessions are monitored before being timed out. An increase in value may lead to current sessions being retained longer, while a decrease removes dormant sessions immediately based on the new setting.

summary: Sets the quality of service profile for iSCSI flows.
synopsis: This command assigns a specified VLAN Priority Tag (VPT) or DSCP to iSCSI packets, enabling effective QoS treatment for iSCSI traffic based on its classification. It can also remark frames during egress.

summary: Enables the assignment of iSCSI flows.
synopsis: This command activates the QoS treatment for iSCSI flows, allowing for the configuration of traffic management rules that affect how iSCSI packets are processed and prioritized.

summary: Globally enables iSCSI awareness.
synopsis: This command allows the switch to start recognizing and managing iSCSI traffic. Enabling iSCSI awareness is essential for optimal processing and prioritization of iSCSI session packets.

summary: Configures an iSCSI target port with an optional IP address.
synopsis: This command defines a target port for iSCSI operations and can bind it to a specific IP address and IQN name, optimizing traffic handling by ensuring the switch only processes relevant iSCSI packets.

summary: Enables sending ISDP version 2 packets.
synopsis: This command allows the switch to send ISDP version 2 packets to supported devices, enabling more advanced discovery features.

summary: Enables ISDP on an interface.
synopsis: This command activates ISDP on a specified interface or range of interfaces, with the requirement that ISDP must also be enabled globally.

summary: Configures ISDP hold time.
synopsis: This command specifies the duration in seconds that a receiving device should maintain the information sent in ISDP packets before discarding it, with a valid range from 10 to 255 seconds.

summary: Enables the ISDP on the switch.
synopsis: This command allows the switch to utilize the industry standard Discovery Protocol (ISDP) for network discovery. By default, ISDP is enabled.

summary: Sets the ISDP packet sending interval.
synopsis: This command determines the frequency, in seconds, with which the switch sends ISDP packets, with an accepted range from 5 to 254 seconds.

summary: Enables loop protection on the switch.
synopsis: This command sets the time interval between keep-alive packets sent and the maximum number of packets the switch accepts before taking action. Default interval is 5 seconds and the packet count is 1.

summary: Configures the action to take when a loop is detected.
synopsis: This command defines the action when a loop is detected on a port. Options include logging the event, disabling the interface, or doing both.

summary: Specifies the authentication and encryption key for TACACS communications.
synopsis: In TACACS Configuration mode, this command sets the required key for communications between the device and the TACACS server. It supports both plaintext and encrypted key formats.

summary: Sets the TACACS+ server-specific authentication key.
synopsis: This command in TACACS Server Configuration mode configures the authentication key used for all TACACS+ communications from the server to the client.

summary: Configure the administrative value of the LACP actor admin key.
synopsis: This command establishes the admin key for the LACP actor on a specified interface or range of interfaces. The valid range for this key is between 0-65535, with a default corresponding to the internal interface number of the physical port.

syntax: lacp actor admin state {individual | longtimeout | passive}
summary: Configure the administrative value of actor state as transmitted by the Actor in LACPDUs.
synopsis: This command sets the administrative value of LACP actor state for one or more interfaces, with valid options including individual, longtimeout, or passive. The default state is 0x07.

summary: Sets the LACP actor admin state to individual.
