synopsis: This command configures the LACP actor state to operate in individual mode for the specified interface, impacting how it participates in LACP negotiation for the port-channel.

summary: Sets a long timeout for the LACP actor.
synopsis: Adjusts the LACP actor's timeout settings to long, allowing for longer durations before detecting link failures, enhancing stability in fluctuating environments.

summary: Sets the LACP actor admin state to passive.
synopsis: This command sets the LACP actor to passive mode on the specified interface, meaning it will only respond to LACP negotiation requests but not initiate them.

summary: Configure the priority value for the aggregation port.
synopsis: This command establishes the priority value assigned to the aggregation port for a specified interface, with a valid range of 0 to 65535. The default priority is 0x80.

summary: Configures the administrative value of the key for the port-channel.
synopsis: This command sets the LACP administrative key value for the port-channel, allowing you to specify a value between 0 and 65535. This is crucial for the proper operation of the LACP protocol.

summary: Configure the port-channel collector max delay.
synopsis: This command sets the maximum delay for LACP collectors on a port-channel interface, applicable to either a single interface or a range of interfaces. The valid delay range is 0-65535, and the default is 0x8000.

summary: Configure the administrative value of the Key for the protocol partner.
synopsis: This command sets the admin key for the LACP partner on a specified interface or range of interfaces, valid between 0 to 65535. The default value is 0x0.

summary: Set LACP partner admin state to individual.
synopsis: This command configures the LACP partner admin state to individual for a specified interface, applicable only to physical interfaces.

summary: Set LACP partner admin state to longtimeout.
synopsis: This command sets the LACP partner admin state to longtimeout for the specified interface, applicable only to physical interfaces.

summary: Set the LACP partner admin state to passive.
synopsis: This command configures the LACP partner admin state to passive for a specified interface, applicable only to physical interfaces.

summary: Configure the LACP partner port id.
synopsis: This command sets the partner port ID for the LACP protocol partner on a specified interface, valid between 0 to 65535, with a default value of 0x80.

summary: Configure the LACP partner port priority.
synopsis: This command allows configuration of the LACP partner port priority for a single interface or a range of interfaces. The valid range for priority is 0 to 65535. Applicable only to physical interfaces.

summary: Configure the LACP partner system id.
synopsis: This command sets the 6-octet MAC Address representing the LACP partner's System ID for a specified interface, valid within the range 00:00:00:00:00:00 - FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF, with the default being 00:00:00:00:00:00.

summary: Configure the LACP partner system priority.
synopsis: Set the administrative priority value associated with the Partner’s System ID for a single interface or a range of interfaces. Valid range is 0 to 65535. Applicable only to physical interfaces.

summary: Configures the lease duration for an IP address assigned from a DHCP server.
synopsis: This command sets the lease duration for DHCP clients. It must be between 1 and 86400 minutes, or can be set to infinite for 60 days.

summary: Sets pagination length for command output.
synopsis: This command configures the number of lines displayed per page in line configuration mode. The persistent setting can range from 5 to 48 lines, with the default being 24 lines per page.

summary: Enters Line Console mode for configuring access methods.
synopsis: This command provides access to the Line Console mode, allowing the configuration of console settings and authentication for Telnet or SSH access.

summary: Configures the debounce time for link flapping on an interface.
synopsis: This command sets the debounce time in milliseconds for link interferences on a per-port basis, enabling the switch to monitor the link state before forwarding notifications after a link-down event.

syntax: link state group group-id action {up | down}
summary: Sets the link status dependency for a group of interfaces.
synopsis: This command defines the behavior of downstream interfaces based on the upstream interface's status. By default, downstream interfaces mirror the status of upstream links. The action 'up' allows downstream interfaces to remain up even if all upstream links are down, while 'down' enforces the default behavior.

summary: Adds interfaces to the downstream interface list.
synopsis: This command adds specified interfaces to the list of downstream interfaces, meaning they will be administratively brought down until an upstream interface is defined for them. It's essential to configure upstream interfaces first to avoid unintentional shutdowns.

summary: Defines interfaces as upstream in the group.
synopsis: This command specifies interfaces that serve as upstream links for a group. An upstream interface cannot also be downstream within the same or a different group, preventing circular dependency configurations.

summary: Enables link-flap detection feature.
synopsis: This command enables the link-flap feature on the switch. Under this feature, the switch keeps a count of link flaps occurring on a port during a configured period. If the count exceeds a set threshold, the port will be placed in the D-Disable state until manually or automatically activated. Executed in Global Config mode.

summary: Configures the duration for link-flap detection.
synopsis: This command sets the maximum duration that a port is allowed to flap before being placed in the D-Disable state, with valid duration values between 3 to 200 seconds. Default is set to 10 seconds. Executed in Global Config mode.

summary: Configures the maximum count for link-flaps on a port.
synopsis: This command allows you to set a maximum number for link-flaps that can occur on a port during the configured duration before it is placed in the D-Disable state. Executed in Global Config mode.

summary: Enables LLDP-MED on an interface or a range of interfaces.
synopsis: Enabling this command allows the interface to transmit and receive LLDP-MED data, facilitating enhanced network device discovery and management.

summary: Configures LLDP-MED on all ports.
synopsis: This command enables LLDP-MED across all interfaces, allowing streamlined configuration and management for the entire switch.

summary: Enables LLDP-MED configuration notifications.
synopsis: This command allows the switch to send LLDP-MED configuration notifications when changes occur, helping devices to become aware of the network.

summary: Configures all ports to send topology change notifications.
synopsis: This command enables all interfaces to notify about topology changes, ensuring the whole switch reflects network modifications efficiently.

summary: Sets the fast start repeat count for LLDP PDUs.
synopsis: This command defines the number of LLDP PDUs transmitted rapidly when LLDP is activated, enhancing the device's responsiveness; count ranges from 1 to 10.

summary: Specifies which optional TLVs will be transmitted in LLDPDUs.
synopsis: This command allows configuration of optional Type Length Values to include in the LLDP packets sent from an interface, optimizing information shared.

summary: Specifies which optional TLVs to be transmitted in LLDP MED.
synopsis: This command allows you to configure the transmission of various optional Type Length Values (TLVs) within the LLDP Media Endpoint Discovery settings.

summary: Enables remote data change notifications.
synopsis: This command enables the notification feature on an interface or a range of interfaces for remote data changes. By default, this feature is disabled.

summary: Configures frequency of remote data change notifications.
synopsis: This command sets the interval in seconds for how often the system sends remote data change notifications. The valid range is 5 to 3600 seconds with a default of 5 seconds.

summary: Enables LLDP receiving on an interface.
synopsis: This command activates the LLDP receiving capability on the specified interface or a range of interfaces, allowing them to listen for incoming LLDP advertisements.

summary: Sets timing parameters for LLDP transmission.
synopsis: This command allows you to configure timing parameters for local data transmission on LLDP-enabled ports. It includes settings for interval, hold value, and reinitialization delay with specific ranges.

summary: Enables LLDP advertising on an interface.
synopsis: This command activates the LLDP advertising capability on the specified interface or a range of interfaces, allowing them to send local information.

summary: Includes transmission of local system management address in LLDPDUs.
synopsis: This command configures transmission of the local system management address within LLDPDUs for a specified interface or range of interfaces.

summary: Specifies which optional TLVs are transmitted in LLDPDUs.
synopsis: This command allows configuration of optional type length values (TLVs) that will be included in the LLDPDUs from the interface. No optional TLVs are included by default.

syntax: llpf {blockisdp | blockvtp | blockdtp | blockudld | blockpagp | blocksstp | blockall}
summary: Blocks specified LLPF protocols on an interface.
synopsis: This command allows the configuration of Link Local Protocol Filtering to block specific proprietary protocols on an interface. By default, this feature is disabled.

summary: Changes the load statistics computation interval.
synopsis: This command sets the time in seconds for which data is used to compute load statistics, requiring a value that is a multiple of 30 and falls within 30-600 seconds. The default is 300 seconds.

summary: Sets the locale for the captive portal.
synopsis: This command is primarily used by the show running config command and is not intended for direct user interaction.

summary: Enables logging of OSPFv2 neighbor state changes.
synopsis: Logs neighbor state changes with INFORMATIONAL severity. 'detail' option logs all state changes; otherwise, only transitions to FULL state and backwards transitions are logged.

summary: Configures buffered logging with a specified threshold and size.
synopsis: This command sets the size of the log buffer and the severity level of messages that are retained in the buffer. It helps in managing log data efficiently and ensuring that important messages are captured.

summary: Sets the percentage of log space that, if exceeded, triggers console logs and alerts.
synopsis: This command limits log storage by specifying a threshold percentage (1-100). When log usage exceeds this percentage, a console log is generated, and alerts are sent if configured. It applies only when 'logging buffered wrap' is disabled.

summary: Enables wrapping of in-memory logging when full.
synopsis: This command allows continuous logging by wrapping the log file when it reaches full capacity in Privileged EXEC mode, preventing logging from stopping.

summary: Logs specified CLI commands.
synopsis: This command enables logging for specific CLI commands executed on the switch, aiding in auditing and tracking configuration changes.

summary: Enables logging to the console with configurable severity levels.
synopsis: This command allows logging output to the console and lets you specify the severity level, which can be a numeric value (0-7) or one of the defined keywords (emergency, alert, etc.).

summary: Enables email alerting and configures severity levels for logging.
synopsis: This command activates email alerting and sets the minimum severity level for which log messages are sent via email. The severity level can be specified as an integer from 0 to 7 or using keywords like emergency, alert, or critical.

summary: Sets the sender address for email logs.
synopsis: This command specifies the email address used as the sender for log messages sent via email, allowing for authentication and identification.

summary: Configures frequency of non-urgent email messages.
synopsis: This command determines how often non-urgent log messages are sent in a batch email, with the time set in minutes ranging from 30 to 1440.

summary: Sets the subject line for email logs.
synopsis: This command customizes the subject line of log messages sent via email, providing context and relevance for recipients.

syntax: logging email message-type {urgent | non-urgent | both} to-addr to-email-addr
summary: Configures the email address for log message alerts.
synopsis: This command allows you to specify the email address(es) to which different types of log message alerts (urgent, non-urgent, or both) are sent.

syntax: logging email test message-type {urgent | non-urgent | both} message-body
summary: Tests email alerting functionality by sending a test email.
synopsis: This command sends a test email to the configured SMTP server to verify that the email alerting functionality is operational. You must specify the type of message (urgent, non-urgent, or both) along with the message body.

summary: Sets the severity level for urgent log emails.
synopsis: This command sets the lowest severity level at which log messages are emailed immediately. Use an integer from 0 to 7 or keywords like emergency (0) to debug (7). If 'none' is specified, logs are collected and sent in batches.

syntax: logging host {hostaddress | hostname} addresstype [tls {anon | x509name certificate-index}] {port-number severitylevel}
summary: Configures the parameters for logging hosts, allowing multiple host configurations.
synopsis: This command sets up logging hosts with details including address type, TLS options, port number, and severity levels. Up to eight hosts can be configured for centralized logging.

summary: Reconfigures settings for a specified logging host.
synopsis: This command enables reconfiguration of a previously defined logging host in Global Config mode based on the provided host index.

summary: Removes a logging host configuration.
synopsis: This command deletes the specified logging host from the configuration, ceasing all log message transmissions to that server.

summary: Sets the logging protocol version for syslog.
synopsis: This command configures the logging protocol to either version 0 (RFC 3164) or version 1 (RFC 5424), determining the format for syslog messages being sent.

summary: Enables syslog logging for system messages.
synopsis: This command activates syslog logging, allowing system events and alerts to be sent to a syslog server for centralized monitoring.

summary: Specifies the port for syslog logging.
synopsis: This command enables syslog logging on a specified port (range 1-65535) allowing tailored communication with syslog servers.

syntax: logging syslog source-interface {unit/slot/port | {loopback loopback-id} | {vlan vlan-id} {tunnel tunnel-id | serviceport}}
summary: Sets the source interface for syslog messages.
synopsis: This command configures the source IP address used in syslog packets. It allows selection from various interfaces for better packet identification by security devices.

summary: Configures a USB device for syslog message storage.
synopsis: This command directs syslog messages to be stored on a specified USB device, allowing for physical backups of logs.

summary: Configures severity level for SNMP traps.
synopsis: This command sets the minimum severity level for which SNMP traps are logged and sent via email, with severity levels ranging from 0 (emergency) to 7 (debug).

summary: Specifies the authentication method for a console.
synopsis: This command configures the authentication method for line access. You can use 'default' for the pre-defined list or specify a custom 'list-name' created with the aaa commands.

summary: Ends the current session.
synopsis: This command logs the current user out of the switch, ending their administrative session and returning to the prompt.

syntax: mac access-group name {{control-plane | in | out} vlan vlan-id {in | out}} [sequence 1–4294967295]
summary: Attaches a MAC Access Control List to an interface or VLAN.
synopsis: This command attaches a specified MAC ACL identified by name to an interface or range of interfaces in a specific direction, or associates it with a VLAN ID. A sequence number can be used to indicate order. The control-plane option applies to the CPU port, affecting control packets.

summary: Creates a MAC Access Control List (ACL) identified by name.
synopsis: This command creates a MAC ACL for Layer 2 Ethernet frames, allowing for the configuration of rules to permit or deny traffic based on MAC addresses. If an ACL with the same name exists, it enters MAC ACL configuration mode.

syntax: mac access-list extended rename name newname
summary: Renames an existing MAC Access Control List (ACL).
synopsis: This command allows changing the name of an existing MAC ACL to a new unique identifier, facilitating organization of access controls within the network.

syntax: mac access-list resequence {name | id} starting-sequence-number increment
summary: Renumbers the entries of a specified MAC ACL.
synopsis: This command alters the sequence numbers of entries within a given MAC access list by a specified increment, which changes the order of how the rules are applied, starting from a defined sequence number.

summary: Sets locally administered MAC addresses.
synopsis: This command allows for the configuration of a locally administered MAC address according to specific rules, ensuring that the address conforms to administrative standards. The MAC address must be unique and meet certain bit settings.

summary: Specifies the MAC address type to use.
synopsis: This command defines whether to use the burned-in MAC address or a locally administered MAC address for the switch operation. The default setting is to use the burned-in MAC address.

summary: Adds a static MAC filter entry on a specified VLAN.
synopsis: The 'macfilter' command allows users to configure a static MAC filter entry for a specified MAC address on a specified VLAN. Only packets from defined source ports are allowed, while egress can be sent through defined destination ports.

summary: Adds interfaces to the destination filter set for a multicast MAC filter.
synopsis: This command adds the specified interfaces to the destination filter set for the MAC filter with the given macaddr and VLAN (vlanid). Configuring a destination port list is only valid for multicast MAC addresses.

summary: Adds all interfaces to the destination filter set for the static MAC filter.
synopsis: With this command, all interfaces are added to the destination filter set of the static MAC filter associated with the specified MAC address and VLAN.

summary: Adds interfaces to the source filter set for a static MAC filter.
synopsis: This command enables the addition of specific interfaces to the source filter set for a defined MAC filter based on the MAC address and VLAN.

summary: Adds all interfaces to the source filter set for the static MAC filter.
synopsis: This command is used to configure the source filter by adding all interfaces for the specified MAC address and VLAN in the context of MAC filtering.

summary: Configures the SMTP server for email alerts.
synopsis: This command sets the SMTP server address for sending email alerts. The address can be in IPv4, IPv6, or DNS name format, and switches to Mail Server Configuration mode.

summary: Activates the configured management access list.
synopsis: This command restricts management connections based on the management ACL. You cannot update or remove a management ACL while it is active.

summary: Creates a management Access Control List (ACL).
synopsis: This command creates a management ACL. The management ACL name can be up to 32 alphanumeric characters. You must define access conditions with the deny and permit commands, defaulting to deny access if no criteria are defined.

summary: Marks packets with the specified CoS value.
synopsis: This command sets the Class of Service value for all packets within the associated traffic stream in the 802.1p header, allowing for level adjustments based on specified values, which can default to 1.

summary: Marks packets with a specified CoS value.
synopsis: This command is used within the Policy-Class-Map Config mode to mark the CoS (Class of Service) of packets, enabling prioritization for traffic streams according to the defined CoS settings.

summary: Marks packets with the specified IP DSCP value.
synopsis: Utilizing this command allows the marking of packets in the associated traffic stream with specified DSCP values, which can be numeric or symbolic, aiding in differentiated services.

summary: Marks packets with a specified IP Precedence value.
synopsis: This command sets the IP Precedence for all relevant traffic packets, permitting prioritization of network traffic with a value ranging from 0 to 7. Note that this command is not applicable for IPv6 classes.

summary: Considers all packets to belong to the class.
synopsis: This command adds a match condition that classifies all packets into the specified class. The not option can negate this condition.

summary: References match conditions from another DiffServ class.
synopsis: This command incorporates match conditions from an existing DiffServ class into the specified class. It cannot reference itself or violate specific rules regarding class combinations.

summary: Adds a match condition for the Class of Service value.
synopsis: This command adds to the specified class definition a match condition for the Class of Service value (0-7), which is the only tag in a single tagged packet or the first/outer 802.1Q tag of a double VLAN tagged packet.

summary: Matches packets based on destination MAC address.
synopsis: This command specifies a match condition based on a packet's destination MAC address. The MAC address is formatted as six two-digit hexadecimal numbers, and an optional bit mask can be specified.

summary: Adds a match condition based on destination IP address.
synopsis: This command creates a match condition for packets based on their destination IP address and the associated bit mask, allowing for precise traffic classification. The not option negates the match.

summary: Adds a match condition based on the destination IPv6 address.
synopsis: This command adds to the specified class definition a match condition based on the destination IPv6 address of a packet, allowing an optional negation.

summary: Matches packets based on destination layer 4 port.
synopsis: This command allows specifying a match condition for the destination layer 4 port using either keywords or numeric notation. There is an option to negate the match condition.

summary: Adds a match condition based on the ethertype value.
synopsis: This command adds a match condition for a class definition based on the ethertype value, which can be a keyword type or a specified range. The not option negates the condition.

summary: Matches routes based on IP access-list criteria.
synopsis: This command links an IP access-list to a route map, determining which conditions must be met for the route map to process its defined actions.

summary: Matches packets based on the IP DiffServ Code Point (DSCP) field.
synopsis: This command adds a match condition based on the DSCP field, which is indicated by the high-order six bits of the Service Type octet in the IP header. Various symbolic keywords or an integer from 0 to 63 can be used. The 'not' option negates the match condition.

summary: Matches packets based on the IP Precedence field.
synopsis: This command adds a match condition based on the IP Precedence value, represented by the high-order three bits of the Service Type octet. The value should be an integer from 0 to 7; the 'not' option negates the match.

summary: Matches packets based on the IP TOS field.
synopsis: This command adds a match condition based on the value of the IP TOS field, defined as all eight bits of the Service Type octet in the IP header. The values for comparison are specified as hexadecimal.

summary: Matches packets based on the IPv6 flow label.
synopsis: This command adds a match condition based on the IPv6 flow label value, which must be in the range of 0 to 1048575, and can be negated with the 'not' option.

summary: Matches packets based on Layer 3 length criteria.
synopsis: This command specifies minimum and maximum lengths for Layer 3 packets that should be matched in a route map, enabling filtering based on packet size.

summary: Configures a route map to match packets based on MAC address criteria.
synopsis: This command enables the route map to match packets based on criteria defined in a MAC access list. Any associated actions from the MAC ACL apply when the route-map is evaluated.

summary: Matches packets based on the IP Protocol field.
synopsis: This command allows for matching packets based on the IP Protocol field using either a keyword or a numeric value (0 to 255). The match can be negated with the 'not' option.

summary: Adds a match condition for the secondary Class of Service value.
synopsis: This command adds to the specified class definition a match condition for the secondary Class of Service value (0-7), representing the inner 802.1Q tag of a double VLAN tagged packet.

summary: Match based on layer 2 secondary VLAN Identifier.
synopsis: This command adds a match condition in a class definition based on the value of the layer 2 secondary VLAN Identifier for double VLAN tagged packets. The secondary vlan-id is an integer from 0 to 4093. Use the not option to negate the match condition.

summary: Adds a match condition based on the source MAC address.
synopsis: This command adds to the specified class definition a match condition based on the source MAC address of a packet, requiring the address and an optional mask.

summary: Adds a match condition based on the source IP address.
synopsis: This command adds to the specified class definition a match condition based on the source IP address of a packet, specifying both the address and an optional bit mask.

summary: Adds a match condition based on the source IPv6 address.
synopsis: This command adds to the specified class definition a match condition based on the source IPv6 address of a packet, providing an option to negate the match condition.

summary: Adds a match condition based on the source layer 4 port of a packet.
synopsis: This command facilitates the specification of a match condition in a class definition, using either a keyword or a numeric value for the source layer 4 port. The portkey can be domain, echo, ftp, etc., or you can specify a port number from 0 to 65535. The not option can be used to negate the match condition.

summary: Adds a match condition based on the VLAN Identifier field.
synopsis: This command defines a match condition for the layer 2 VLAN Identifier, which includes either the single or outer tag of double VLAN tagged packets. The vlan-id must be an integer from 0 to 4093, and the not option can negate the match condition.

summary: Configures the maximum download bandwidth for a client.
synopsis: This command sets the maximum rate at which a client can receive data from the network. A rate of 0 indicates that the limit is not enforced.

summary: Sets maximum upload bandwidth for clients.
synopsis: This command specifies the maximum upload bandwidth rate for a client in bits per second, allowing to limit their data upload capacity, with a value of 0 indicating no limit.

summary: Sets the maximum number of octets a user can transmit.
synopsis: This command configures the maximum number of octets the user is allowed to transmit. If the limit is reached, the user will be disconnected; if set to 0, then the limit is not enforced.

summary: Enters OSPFv3 stub router mode, setting maximum metric values for LSAs.
synopsis: This command configures OSPFv3 to operate in stub router mode, allowing it to set the metric for non-stub links to MaxLinkMetric. Additionally, it provides options to specify startup duration and summary LSA metrics.

summary: Sets the maximum number of octets a user can receive.
synopsis: This command configures the maximum number of octets the user is allowed to receive. If the user reaches this limit, they will be disconnected. A value of 0 indicates that the limit is not enforced.

summary: Configures the maximum total octets a user can transfer.
synopsis: This command allows you to set a limit on the total number of octets a user can transmit and receive. Reaching this limit will disconnect the user; setting it to 0 means no limit.

summary: Sets the number of OSPF paths reported for a destination.
synopsis: This command configures how many equal-cost paths OSPF can report for a single destination, with the allowed number varying depending on the platform.

summary: Configures memory buffer (MBUF) threshold limits and notifications.
synopsis: This command sets thresholds for memory buffer resource usage, enabling notifications when usage exceeds or falls below specified levels. It assists in monitoring memory buffer management effectively to avoid performance issues.

summary: Add a switch to the stack.
synopsis: This command adds a specified switch to the stack, identified by its unit and switch type index, issued on the Primary Management Unit.

summary: Configs notifications for low CPU free memory.
synopsis: Sets a threshold for CPU free memory below which notifications are generated. Notifications occur if the free memory falls below the threshold and again when it rises above a defined recovery level.

summary: Copies matched traffic to specified unit/slot/port.
synopsis: The `mirror` parameter enables traffic that matches the ACL rule to be duplicated and sent to a defined unit, slot, or port for analysis or monitoring purposes, useful for debugging or traffic analysis.

summary: Enables MMRP on the device.
synopsis: Activates the Multicast Registration Protocol (MMRP) in Global Config mode. MMRP must be enabled individually on interfaces for it to function.

summary: Enables MMRP periodic state machine.
synopsis: This command allows for periodic state updates within the MMRP, which can help in optimizing multicast address management and registration.

summary: Enables dot1q tunneling mode.
synopsis: This command sets the interface mode to dot1q tunneling, which allows for the encapsulation of VLAN-tagged frames, useful for preserving VLAN information across trunks.

summary: Enables Double VLAN Tunneling on the specified interface.
synopsis: This command designates an interface as a service provider port by enabling Double VLAN Tunneling, which is necessary for managing multiple customer VLANs in a shared environment.

syntax: monitor session session-id destination {interface {unit/slot/port} | remote vlan vlan-id reflector-port unit/slot/port}
summary: Adds a destination interface for a port mirroring session.
synopsis: This command specifies where the mirrored traffic should be sent. It allows configuring destination interfaces or remote VLANs with reflector ports for efficient traffic monitoring.

syntax: monitor session session-id source {interface {unit/slot/port | cpu | lag} | vlan vlan-id | remote vlan vlan-id} [rx | tx]
summary: Adds a source interface for a port mirroring session.
synopsis: This command configures the specific interface or VLAN to be monitored in a mirroring session, facilitating traffic analysis. Options allow for specifying rx or tx directions.

summary: Manages the movement of devices in a stacked configuration.
synopsis: This command is used in the stack global configuration to manage the physical relocation of devices and maintain their configuration integrity across a stack.

syntax: mrp {jointime seconds | leavetime seconds | leavealltime seconds}
summary: Sets MRP protocol timers on an interface.
synopsis: Configures the MRP protocol timing parameters: 'jointime' for registration intervals, 'leavetime' for unregister delays, and 'leavealltime' for deregistration notices, allowing for fine-tuning MRP operations on a per-port basis.

summary: Sets the Maximum Transmission Unit size.
synopsis: This command is used to specify the size of the largest packet that can be transmitted over the network, impacting network performance and fragmentation behavior.

summary: Enables Multicast VLAN Registration (MVR).
synopsis: This command activates MVR, which facilitates efficient multicast traffic forwarding over VLANs, utilizing a dedicated multicast VLAN to manage IGMP reports.

summary: Adds an MVR membership group for multicast traffic.
synopsis: Use this command to configure a specific multicast group for MVR. Specify the IP address of the multicast group and optionally add multiple groups by setting the count.

summary: Enable MVR immediate leave mode.
synopsis: This command configures the switch to immediately stop forwarding multicast traffic for a port when a leave message is received.

summary: Set the MVR mode type.
synopsis: This command changes the MVR mode to either compatible mode, which requires manual configuration of multicast groups, or dynamic mode, which allows the switch to learn multicast groups automatically from IGMP queries.

summary: Sets the MVR query response time.
synopsis: This command configures the time in deciseconds that the MVR will wait before sending a query response. The value can be set from 1 to 100 deciseconds.

summary: Sets the MVR port type for multicast traffic.
synopsis: This command designates a port as either a source (transmitting multicast) or receiver (receiving multicast), assisting in traffic flow management.

summary: Sets the MVR multicast VLAN.
synopsis: This command specifies the VLAN ID that should be used for multicast traffic within MVR. The VLAN ID must be within the acceptable range.

summary: Includes the port in a specific MVR group.
synopsis: This command allows a port to join a multicast VLAN group, allowing it to participate in multicast traffic receiving for the specified group IP.

summary: Configures MVRP (Multiple VLAN Registration Protocol).
synopsis: This command enables mutilple VLANs to dynamically register and deregister, enhancing VLAN management and reducing configuration complexity.

summary: Enables the MVRP periodic state machine.
synopsis: Use this command in Global Config mode to enable the MVRP periodic state machine which is disabled by default.

summary: Sets a name for the captive portal configuration.
synopsis: This command allows you to assign a custom name, up to 32 alphanumeric characters, to a captive portal configuration for better identification.

summary: Specifies the NetBIOS name server.
synopsis: This command is used to set the IP address of the NetBIOS name server, enabling networked devices to resolve names to IP addresses in a Windows environment.

summary: Defines the Node Type for NetBIOS.
synopsis: This command allows the configuration of the NetBIOS node type, influencing how name resolution and browsing is performed in a local area network.

summary: Configures DHCP Pool network settings.
synopsis: This command is used to define the network parameters for a DHCP pool, specifying address ranges and additional attributes for address assignment.

summary: Enables OSPFv2 on an interface and assigns an area ID.
synopsis: This command configures OSPF on a specific interface by tying it to a defined area ID if the interface's IP address matches the specified network and wildcard mask.

summary: Configures the next server in the boot process for DHCP clients.
synopsis: This command specifies the IP address of the next server, usually a TFTP server, which the DHCP client should contact during the boot process.

summary: Disable monitoring session.
synopsis: The 'no monitor' command disables the monitoring session that was previously configured on the switch, stopping the collection of network traffic metrics for that session.

summary: Enables OSPF graceful restart functionality on an interface.
synopsis: This command enables the OSPF graceful restart feature, allowing the router to continue packet forwarding during unplanned or planned restarts. The 'planned-only' option restricts the graceful restarts to only those initiated through the initiate failover command.

summary: Enables helper functionality for OSPF.
synopsis: This command enables the OSPF protocol to act as a helpful neighbor during restarts. It can be configured for both planned and unplanned restarts, with an option to restrict it to planned ones.

summary: Enables strict LSA checking for OSPF helper.
synopsis: This command enables strict link-state advertisement checking for OSPF. When enabled, it prevents the restarting router from updating its forwarding table immediately, which may introduce potential forwarding loops.

summary: Disables helpful neighbor functionality for OSPF.
synopsis: This command disables the helpful neighbor capability for OSPF, and is functionally equivalent to 'no nsf helper'. It is provided for compatibility with other network software CLIs.

summary: Configures the grace period before exiting helper mode.
synopsis: This command sets the number of seconds that the restarting router asks its neighbors to wait before exiting helper mode during a restart. The value must be between 0 and 1800 seconds, ensuring the router has enough time to reestablish adjacencies and complete database exchanges.

summary: Configures an OpenFlow controller with an IP address and optional port.
synopsis: This command specifies an OpenFlow controller's IP address and port number, using SSL by default. It applies to global configuration mode, with a default port of 6633.

summary: Configures the OpenFlow hardware table for flow targets.
synopsis: This command sets the hardware table as the target for flows from OpenFlow 1.0 controllers, with keywords applicable only in OpenFlow mode 1.0. Defaults to full-match and is used in global config mode.

summary: Enables OpenFlow on the switch.
synopsis: The 'openflow enable' command activates the OpenFlow functionality on the switch, allowing it to operate under the context of an OpenFlow architecture.

summary: Configures the IP address mode for OpenFlow.
synopsis: This command specifies how OpenFlow will use the IP address, either automatically, statically from user input, or from the service port, and can reset openflow functionality if changed.

summary: Sets OpenFlow to passive mode.
synopsis: This command configures the switch to operate in passive mode, meaning it will not initiate new flow requests but will respond to existing requests from the controller.

summary: Specifies a static IP address for OpenFlow.
synopsis: This command assigns a static IP address for OpenFlow, provided that the static IP mode is enabled and an operational IP interface matches this address.

summary: Configures OpenFlow variant to version 1.0 or 1.3.
synopsis: This command sets the OpenFlow protocol variant to either 1.0 or 1.3, with 1.3 being the default setting, allowing compatibility with different OpenFlow controllers.

syntax: option code {ascii string | hex string1 [string2...string8] | ip address1 [address2...address8]}
summary: Configures DHCP server options.
synopsis: This command sets specific DHCP options, enabling options such as ASCII strings, hexadecimal data, or IP addresses to be sent to DHCP clients.

summary: Sets a specified interface as passive for OSPF.
synopsis: This command designates a specified interface as passive, overriding any global passive configurations and preventing OSPF adjacencies over that interface.

summary: Sets all interfaces to passive by default.
synopsis: The 'passive-interface default' command enables a default passive setting for all interfaces, controlling OSPF announcements without manual configuration on each link.

summary: Sets the password for the current user.
synopsis: The password command allows the administrator to configure a password for user authentication. This increases security by ensuring that only authorized users can access the system.

summary: Implement aging on passwords for local users.
synopsis: When a user’s password expires, they are prompted to change it before logging in again. The days argument is a number in the range 1–365 days. Default is 0, meaning no aging.

summary: Sets the number of previous passwords that can be stored.
synopsis: This command configures the system to remember a set number of previous passwords to prevent users from reusing them frequently.

summary: Defines count for failed login attempts before account lockout.
synopsis: This command secures user accounts by locking them after a set number of failed login attempts, protecting against unauthorized access.

summary: Enforces a minimum password length for local users.
synopsis: This command sets the minimum password length for local accounts, applicable to both user and enable passwords, ensuring security compliance.

summary: Excludes specific keywords from passwords.
synopsis: This command configures the system to disallow specific keywords in passwords, enhancing the creation of secure authentication credentials.

summary: Sets limit on consecutive characters in passwords.
synopsis: This command restricts the number of consecutive characters allowed in any password, enhancing overall password complexity.

summary: Sets limit on repeated characters in passwords.
synopsis: This command limits how many times the same character can be repeated in a password, contributing to stronger password policies.

summary: Enforces a minimum number of character classes in passwords.
synopsis: This command requires passwords to consist of a specified minimum number of different character classes, such as uppercase, lowercase, numeric, and special characters.

summary: Sets the minimum required lowercase letters in passwords.
synopsis: This command enforces a minimum number of lowercase letters to be included in passwords, strengthening their security.

summary: Sets the minimum required numeric characters in passwords.
synopsis: The command ensures that passwords contain at least a specified number of numeric characters, contributing to their complexity.

summary: Sets the minimum required special characters in passwords.
synopsis: This command mandates the inclusion of a minimum number of special characters in passwords, increasing the difficulty of unauthorized access.

summary: Sets the minimum required uppercase letters in passwords.
synopsis: This command specifies the minimum number of uppercase letters that must be included in passwords to aid in creating secure login credentials.

summary: Enables password strength checking.
synopsis: The 'passwords strength-check' command activates the feature that verifies password strength against defined policies during password creation or changes.

summary: Sets a timer for unlocking passwords.
synopsis: This command configures the duration (in seconds) after which a password is unlocked. Useful in managing access controls during network operations.

summary: Configures the mode for the password unlock timer.
synopsis: This command sets the operational mode for the password unlock timer, enabling users to define how password unlocking will behave based on specified requirements.

summary: Adds a periodic time entry to a time range.
synopsis: Configures a schedule for the time range using specified days of the week and start/end times. Days can be defined in various formats such as daily, weekdays, or specific days.

syntax: permit ip host sender-ipaddress mac host sender-mac
summary: Configure validation rule for a valid IP and MAC address in ARP.
synopsis: Creates a rule within the ARP ACL that allows traffic from the specified IP address and MAC address combination, thus permitting ARP packets that match.

syntax: permit ip-source ip-address [mask {mask | prefix-length}] [service service] [priority priority]
summary: Sets permit conditions based on the source IP address.
synopsis: This command sets permit conditions for the management access list based on the source IP address of a packet, with options for subnet mask, service type, and priority.

summary: Assigns a permit priority to the rule in the management access list.
synopsis: This command is utilized in Management access-list configuration mode. Each rule must have a unique priority.

summary: Sets permit conditions based on access protocol.
synopsis: This command sets permit conditions for the management access list based on the access protocol, requiring a unique priority for the rule.

syntax: ping ipv6 interface {unit/slot/port | vlan vland-id | loopback loopback-id | serviceport | tunnel tunnel-id} {link-local-address link-local-address | ipv6-address} [size datagram-size]
summary: Sends ICMP echo requests to a specified target.
synopsis: Use this command to ping a target station from a specified interface or VLAN. You can send a specified number of pings using different source types like loopback or VLAN. Optionally, define the size of the ping packet.

syntax: ping ipv6 {ipv6-global-address | hostname | {interface {unit/slot/port | vlan vland-id | serviceport} link-local-address} [size datagram-size]}
summary: Determines if another computer is on the network using the ping utility.
synopsis: This command checks network connectivity and sends ICMP echo requests to a specified target using its IPv6 address or hostname. It can work with various source interfaces, and the default packet size and count can be adjusted.

syntax: ping ipv6 interface {unit/slot/port | vlan vland-id | loopback loopback-id | serviceport | tunnel tunnel-id} {link-local-address link-local-address | ipv6-address} [size datagram-size]
summary: Pings a target specified by interface or VLAN over the network.
synopsis: This command verifies connectivity by sending pings from a specified source interface or VLAN. It allows for customization of the ping packet size and the selection of the source and target addresses.

summary: Enables Power over Ethernet (PoE) functionality.
synopsis: This command enables Power over Ethernet functionality globally or on a per-interface basis, allowing for the safe transmission of electrical power along with data over Ethernet cabling.

summary: Configures PoE detection type for powered devices.
synopsis: Use this command to specify the detection type for powered devices on a global or per-interface basis, allowing the switch to detect and power devices according to the specified method (IEEE standard, legacy, or auto). Default is auto.

summary: Switches a port to high-power mode for PoE.
synopsis: This command allows a port to provide more power than the standard 802.3af, switching it to a high-power mode suitable for Class 4 devices or other high-power requirements. Default is dot3at.

syntax: poe power limit {class-based | none | user-defined maximum-power}
summary: Configures the power limit type for PoE ports.
synopsis: This command sets the type of power limit for PoE ports to class-based, none, or user-defined values. This configuration affects how much power can be drawn by connected devices.

summary: Configures power management mode for PoE.
synopsis: This command allows configuring power management modes (static or dynamic) based on individual PoE units or all units, affecting how power is allocated to connected devices.

summary: Sets the priority for PoE on specific ports.
synopsis: Use this command to configure the priority level for ports in a PoE environment, determining which ports receive power during low capacity circumstances.

summary: Reset the PoE state of ports.
synopsis: This command resets the PoE state for all ports globally or for a specific interface, useful for clearing errors and resetting power delivery.

summary: Schedules PoE power on and off times.
synopsis: This command configures a schedule for power delivery over Ethernet, allowing automated management of device power states according to time.

summary: Enables SNMP traps for Power over Ethernet events.
synopsis: The poe traps command configures the switch to send SNMP notifications for Power over Ethernet related events, aiding in monitoring and management.

summary: Sets a usage threshold for PoE on an interface.
synopsis: This command specifies a threshold for power usage on the interface, which helps in ensuring that power distribution remains within safe operating limits.

syntax: police-simple {1-4294967295 1-128 conform-action {drop | set-cos-as-sec-cos | set-cos-transmit 0-7 | set-sec-cos-transmit 0-7 | set-prec-transmit 0-7 | set-dscp-transmit 0-63 | transmit} [violate-action {drop | set-cos-as-sec-cos | set-cos-transmit 0-7 | set-sec-cos-transmit 0-7 | set-prec-transmit 0-7 | set-dscp-transmit 0-63 | transmit}]}
summary: Configures traffic policing with a single data rate and burst size.
synopsis: The police-simple command defines the traffic policing style and actions based on compliance with specified data rates and burst sizes, allowing various actions such as drop or transmit on conforming and violating packets.

syntax: police-single-rate {1-4294967295 1-128 1-128 conform-action {drop | set-cos-as-sec-cos | set-cos-transmit 0-7 | set-sec-cos-transmit 0-7 | set-prec-transmit 0-7 | set-dscp-transmit 0-63 | transmit} exceed-action {drop | set-cos-as-sec-cos | set-cos-transmit 0-7 | set-sec-cos-transmit 0-7 | set-prec-transmit 0-7 | set-dscp-transmit 0-63 | transmit} [violate-action {drop | set-cos-as-sec-cos | set-cos-transmit 0-7 | set-sec-cos-transmit 0-7 | set-prec-transmit 0-7 | set-dscp-transmit 0-63 | transmit}]}
summary: Establishes a single-rate traffic policing style.
synopsis: The police-single-rate command defines the policing strategy for managing traffic flows, specifying actions based on conformity, exceeding, and violation conditions with defined rate and burst sizes.

syntax: police-two-rate {1-4294967295 1-4294967295 1-128 1-128 conform-action {drop | set-cos-as-sec-cos | set-cos-transmit 0-7 | set-sec-cos-transmit 0-7 | set-prec-transmit 0-7 | set-dscp-transmit 0-63 | transmit} exceed-action {drop | set-cos-as-sec-cos | set-cos-transmit 0-7 | set-sec-cos-transmit 0-7 | set-prec-transmit 0-7 | set-dscp-transmit 0-63 | transmit} [violate-action {drop | set-cos-as-sec-cos | set-cos-transmit 0-7 | set-sec-cos-transmit 0-7 | set-prec-transmit 0-7 | set-dscp-transmit 0-63 | transmit}]}
summary: Establishes a two-rate traffic policing style.
synopsis: The police-two-rate command allows configuration of a traffic policing style that considers both conforming and exceeding rates, enabling fine-tuned control over packet handling based on established criteria.

summary: Establishes a new DiffServ policy.
synopsis: This command initiates a DiffServ policy map that can be applied to traffic classified as either inbound or outbound, changing the CLI mode to Policy-Map Config upon execution.

summary: Renames an existing policy map.
synopsis: This command allows you to rename a defined policy map in the Global Configuration mode. The 'policyname' is the current name of the policy being renamed, while 'newpolicyname' is the new name you want to assign. Ensure the new name is not already in use.

summary: Specifies the UDP port for detecting RADIUS requests.
synopsis: Use this command to specify the UDP port on which the switch can detect RADIUS requests from the configured dynamic authorization clients. The supported range for the port number is 1025–65535.

summary: Enable LACP on a port or range of ports.
synopsis: This command activates Link Aggregation Control Protocol (LACP) for specified ports, allowing for aggregated links.

summary: Enables LACP on all ports.
synopsis: This command activates Link Aggregation Control Protocol (LACP) globally across all ports on the device.

summary: Sets the timeout for LACP on a physical interface.
synopsis: This command configures the LACP timeout setting on a specific physical interface, determining whether it operates in long or short timeout mode.

summary: Configures a new port-channel (LAG) and generates a logical unit/slot/port number.
synopsis: This command creates a new port-channel with a specified name. The name can include alphanumeric characters and the dash character. To view the port-channel's unit/slot/port number, use the 'show port channel' command. Remember to set the physical mode of ports before adding them to the port-channel.

summary: Sets the administrative mode for a port-channel.
synopsis: This command configures the administrative mode for the specified port-channel interface, determining how it behaves in terms of link aggregation.

summary: Globally enables the Auto-LAG feature.
synopsis: This command enables the Auto-LAG feature that allows a dynamic Layer 2 link aggregation to form automatically between two compliant devices based on LACP, requiring at least two links with matching configurations.

summary: Sets the load balancing algorithm for port channels.
synopsis: This command specifies the load balancing method to be used across the defined port channels, optimizing performance and resource utilization based on traffic patterns.

summary: Enables link trap notifications for the port-channel.
synopsis: This command configures notifications for link traps on a specified port-channel or for all port-channels, enhancing monitoring and alerting for link status changes.

summary: Selects the load-balancing option used on a port-channel (LAG).
synopsis: This command selects the load-balancing option used on a port-channel (LAG). Traffic is balanced on a port-channel by selecting one of the links in the channel to transmit specific packets. The range of options may vary per device.

summary: Enables local-preference mode on a port-channel (LAG).
synopsis: This command enables the local-preference mode on a port-channel (LAG) interface. By default, this mode is disabled.

summary: Configures the minimum links for lag interfaces on a port-channel.
synopsis: This command configures the port-channel’s minimum links for lag interfaces. The number parameter can be in the range 1-8, with the default being 1.

summary: Defines a name for the port-channel interface.
synopsis: Establishes a user-defined name for a port-channel, allowing for alphanumeric strings of up to 15 characters. Can also be specified using a LAG interface number.

summary: Enable static mode on a port-channel (LAG) interface.
synopsis: This command configures a port-channel interface to static mode. If the maximum dynamic port-channels are in use, new port-channels will default to static mode. Applies only to port-channel interfaces.

summary: Configures the system priority for the port-channel.
synopsis: Sets the priority for the port-channel, impacting its distribution and management in a LAG configuration. Valid range is 0-65535, default is 0x8000.

summary: Enables port locking on interfaces or globally.
synopsis: This command activates port security, allowing the configuration of port MAC locking either system-wide or on specific interfaces to enhance network security by controlling allowed MAC addresses.

summary: Adds a static MAC address to the interface.
synopsis: This command allows the user to assign a specific MAC address to the list of statically locked addresses for a selected interface or range of interfaces, associated with a VLAN ID.

summary: Converts dynamically locked MAC addresses to statically locked addresses.
synopsis: This command converts all currently dynamically locked MAC addresses for an interface or range of interfaces to statically locked MAC addresses.

summary: Enables sticky mode Port MAC Locking on a port.
synopsis: This command enables sticky mode for Port MAC Locking, which allows dynamically learned MAC addresses to become statically locked under certain conditions. Sticky addresses can be specified with a MAC address and VLAN ID.

summary: Sets the maximum number of dynamic MAC addresses allowed.
synopsis: This command configures the maximum number of dynamic MAC addresses that can be learned on the interface to limit access and enhance security.

summary: Sets the maximum number of static MAC addresses allowed.
synopsis: Configures the maximum allowed static MAC addresses on the interface, helping prevent excessive static entries and maintain security.

summary: Enables interface shutdown on MAC address violation.
synopsis: This command configures the interface to be administratively disabled when a port security violation occurs, enhancing security management.

summary: Automatically readjusts power allocation on ports.
synopsis: Enables automatic power allocation adjustments for a switch model M4300-96X based on power budget changes or powered devices. Lower priority ports may be shut down if the budget is insufficient.

summary: Enables N+1 power redundancy feature.
synopsis: Enables the N+1 power redundancy feature on a switch with dual PSUs, allowing seamless power takeover by the redundant PSU upon failure. Defaults to Disabled.

syntax: prefix-delegation prefix/prefixlength duid [name hostname] [valid-lifetime seconds] [preferred-lifetime seconds]
summary: Defines prefix delegation settings for DHCPv6 clients.
synopsis: This command allows for configuring multiple delegated IPv6 prefixes within a pool for specific clients, including settings for lifetime durations and client identification.

summary: Suppresses advertisement of non-essential IPv4 prefixes.
synopsis: This command prevents the advertisement of IPv4 prefixes that are not linked to secondary addresses, loopbacks, or passive interfaces, optimizing OSPF announcements.

summary: Specifies the order of server usage for TACACS communications.
synopsis: This command in TACACS Configuration mode allows you to set the server priority (0–65535), where lower numbers represent higher priority.

summary: Enables or disables Priority-Flow-Control (PFC) on the specified interface.
synopsis: Use this command in Datacenter-Bridging Config mode to enable or disable Priority-Flow-Control on a given interface. PFC must be enabled before FIP snooping can operate, and VLAN tagging must be enabled to carry the dot1p value through the network.

summary: Configures drop or no-drop behavior for specified lossless priorities on an interface.
synopsis: This command allows you to set up to two lossless priorities on an interface, which must be consistent across the network. It requires PFC to be enabled and VLAN tagging to carry the dot1p values.

summary: Creates a private group with an optional name or ID and mode.
synopsis: This command allows for the creation of a private group, where the name can be up to 24 bytes long and the group identifier ranges from 1 to 192, with modes defined as community (default) or isolated.

syntax: private-vlan {association [add | remove] secondary-vlan-list | community | isolated | primary}
summary: Configures the private VLANs and associations between primary and secondary VLANs.
synopsis: This command allows administrators to establish associations between primary and secondary VLANs, designate a VLAN as isolated or community, or define a VLAN as a primary VLAN in configurations.

syntax: process cpu threshold type total rising threshold interval seconds [falling threshold interval seconds]
summary: Configure CPU utilization thresholds for notifications.
synopsis: This command sets CPU utilization thresholds to trigger notifications when CPU usage rises above or falls below specified levels for defined intervals. Ensure the falling threshold is not greater than the rising threshold, and these configurations persist across reboots.

summary: Configures the protocol for the captive portal.
synopsis: This command sets the protocol type for a captive portal instance, allowing the use of either HTTP or HTTPS for network communications, with HTTPS set as the default.

summary: Attaches a VLAN ID to a protocol-based VLAN group.
synopsis: This command attaches a vlanid to the protocol-based VLAN identified by groupid. A group can only be associated with one VLAN at a time, however the VLAN association can be changed.

summary: Adds interfaces to a protocol-based VLAN group.
synopsis: This command adds a physical interface or a range of interfaces to the protocol-based VLAN identified by groupid. If adding an interface to a group causes any conflicts with protocols currently associated with the group, this command fails.

summary: Adds all interfaces to a protocol-based VLAN group.
synopsis: This command adds all physical interfaces to the protocol-based VLAN identified by groupid. If adding an interface to a group causes any conflicts with protocols currently associated with the group, this command will fail.

summary: Defines parameters for cloud agent communication through a proxy server.
synopsis: This command sets up the proxy server details that the cloud management agent uses to access public networks. It requires the proxy's IP address, an optional TCP/UDP port, and valid credentials for authentication. Passwords can be stored in plain text or AES-encrypted.

summary: Enable the PTP E2E transparent clock.
synopsis: This command activates the Precision Time Protocol (PTP) end-to-end transparent clock feature, either at the global level or for specific interfaces, to ensure accurate time synchronization across network devices.

summary: Closes the current telnet or serial connection.
synopsis: This command disconnects the session similar to 'logout', prompting the user to save configuration changes before quitting.

summary: Enables RADIUS accounting function.
synopsis: This command activates RADIUS accounting, allowing the switch to keep track of user activities and resource usage via RADIUS.

summary: Specifies the NAS-IP Address attribute for RADIUS.
synopsis: This command configures the RADIUS client to utilize the NAS-IP Address attribute when sending requests, enhancing identification during communication with the RADIUS server.

syntax: radius server host {auth | acct} {ipaddr | dnsname} [name servername] [port number] [type server-type]
summary: Configures RADIUS server address and options.
synopsis: Sets the IP address or DNS name of the RADIUS server for authentication or accounting, along with optional parameters such as port number and server type.

syntax: radius server key {auth | acct} {ipaddr | dnsname} encrypted password
summary: Configures the RADIUS server key for authentication or accounting.
synopsis: This command sets the key used for RADIUS client communication with the specified server. The key can be entered in both encrypted and unencrypted formats, but stored in encrypted format.

summary: Configures message authentication for RADIUS server.
synopsis: This command specifies the method of message authentication used for RADIUS messages, ensuring integrity and authentication of the communication between the switch and the RADIUS server.

summary: Configures a primary RADIUS server for authentication.
synopsis: This command specifies which of the configured servers should be used as the primary server for RADIUS authentication. If the primary server cannot be reached, the system will attempt to contact backup servers.

summary: Sets the number of retransmission attempts for RADIUS requests.
synopsis: This command configures how many times the RADIUS client will retry to transmit messages before switching to a backup server if no response is received from the primary server. The retries range from 1 to 15.

summary: Sets the timeout period for RADIUS requests.
synopsis: This command specifies the time in seconds that the switch will wait for a response from the RADIUS server before considering the request failed, optimizing the efficiency of authentication transactions.

syntax: radius source-interface {unit/slot/port | loopback loopback-id | vlan vlan-id | serviceport}
summary: Configures the source interface for RADIUS communications.
synopsis: This command specifies the interface that will be used as the source for all RADIUS communications. If left unconfigured, the primary IP address of the outbound interface will be used.

summary: Configures the IP address of the RADIUS authentication server.
synopsis: This command interfaces with the designated RADIUS authentication server, allowing for user authentication requests to be directed correctly during the login phase.

summary: Enables WRED for the entire interface.
synopsis: This command activates weighted random early discard for all queues on the interface, optimizing traffic management. This command is available in Global or Interface Config modes.

summary: Sets the exponential weighting constant for random detection.
synopsis: This command allows the user to specify a weighting constant that influences how packet drop decisions are made during congestion scenarios based on the random-detect mechanisms.

summary: Configures WRED parameters for queue drop precedences.
synopsis: This command is used for setting the WRED parameters for each drop precedence level supported by a queue when per-COS queue configuration is enabled. Usable in Global or Interface Config modes.

summary: Forwards matched traffic to specified unit/slot/port.
synopsis: The `redirect` command allows for the rerouting of traffic that meets the ACL criteria to a specified unit, slot, or port, facilitating advanced traffic management and handling strategies.

summary: Configures the URL for traffic redirection.
synopsis: This command sets the URL to which traffic is redirected, allowing for management of web traffic or application flows in dynamic network environments.

summary: Configures OSPFv3 to allow redistribution of routes from specified source protocols.
synopsis: This command enables OSPFv3 to redistribute routes from static or connected sources with optional metric, metric type, and tag arguments. It helps in integrating different routing protocols within OSPF, allowing for effective route sharing among diverse networking environments.

summary: Releases the current DHCP lease.
synopsis: This command instructs the device to release its current DHCP lease, which can be useful for troubleshooting or reassignment of IP addresses in dynamic networks.

summary: Resets the switch without powering it off.
synopsis: This command resets the switch while maintaining the boot code execution. All network connections will be terminated, and the switch uses the stored configuration to initialize itself. A confirmation prompt will be displayed before proceeding with the reset.

summary: Adds a comment to an ACL rule.
synopsis: This command adds remarks to an ACL rule entry, allowing for documentation and clarity in configuration. Remarks are associated with the next ACL rule created and can help identify rule purposes.

summary: Configures remote spanning on the switch.
synopsis: This command sets up remote SPAN (sRemote Switch Port Analyzer) functionality, enabling traffic capture from remote switch ports for monitoring and inspection.

summary: Renews the current DHCP lease.
synopsis: This command requests a renewal of the current DHCP lease, allowing the device to maintain continuous network connectivity under a dynamic IP allocation scheme.

summary: Renew an IP address on a service port.
synopsis: This command is used to renew the DHCP lease for an IP address specifically on a service port. Issuing this command will prompt the DHCP client to request a new lease from the DHCP server.

syntax: rmon alarm alarm-number variable sample-interval {absolute | delta} rising-threshold value [rising-event-index] falling-threshold value [falling-event-index] [startup {rising | falling | rising-falling}] [owner string]
summary: Sets the RMON alarm entry in the RMON alarm MIB group.
synopsis: Configures alarm entries to monitor specific variables at defined intervals and thresholds, allowing diagnostics via sampled data with customizable parameters for rising and falling thresholds, sample intervals, and event indices.

syntax: rmon collection history index-number [buckets number | interval seconds | owner string]
summary: Sets the history control parameters for RMON collection.
synopsis: This command configures the history collection parameters for a specific interface, including the number of data buckets, sampling intervals, and ownership, while noting limitations on interface range.

syntax: rmon event event-number [description string | log | owner string | trap community]
summary: Sets RMON event entries in the RMON event MIB group.
synopsis: This command defines an RMON event associated with a unique index, allowing logging and SNMP trap notifications according to specified conditions and metadata like description and owner.

syntax: rmon hcalarm alarm-number variable sample-interval sample-type rising-threshold high low status value rising-falling owner string
summary: Configures a high capacity alarm with specified parameters.
synopsis: This command sets up a high capacity alarm entry in the RMON MIB, allowing monitoring of specific variables with defined sampling intervals, types, and thresholds, including startup alarm conditions and ownership details.

summary: Configures a route map for policy routing.
synopsis: This command creates or modifies a route map that defines policies for routing decisions based on specific criteria, optimizing traffic flow according to desired policies.

summary: Enters OSPF router configuration mode.
synopsis: This command activates the OSPF (Open Shortest Path First) routing protocol on the switch, allowing the user to manage OSPF-specific settings and parameters.

summary: Enters Router RIP configuration mode.
synopsis: This command allows you to enter the Router RIP configuration mode from the Global Config mode, enabling routing protocol configurations using RIP.

summary: Sets a unique router ID for OSPFv3.
synopsis: This command assigns a unique 4-digit dotted-decimal number to identify the router within the OSPF domain. The router ID is crucial for OSPF operations and helps in establishing OSPF sessions, ensuring proper route calculations and management.

summary: Enables IPv4 and IPv6 routing on an interface.
synopsis: This command activates routing capabilities for specified interfaces, allowing them to direct traffic at Layer 3, essential for establishing IP connectivity.

summary: Saves the current configuration.
synopsis: This command commits the active configuration to memory, ensuring that configuration changes will persist after a reload or reboot of the switch.

summary: Applies a specific script to the switch configuration.
synopsis: This command loads and executes a predefined script to automate configuration tasks or to adjust settings on the switch, increasing operational efficiency.

summary: Deletes a specified script or all scripts from the switch.
synopsis: This command removes a specified script by name or deletes all scripts stored on the switch, allowing for script management and cleanup.

summary: Lists all scripts on the switch.
synopsis: This command displays all scripts currently stored on the switch along with the remaining available script storage space. It is used in Privileged EXEC mode.

summary: Displays the contents of a specified script.
synopsis: This command allows users to review the contents of a specific script file by providing the script's name, displaying line numbers along with their corresponding text.

summary: Validates a script file for potential issues.
synopsis: This command checks the specified script file for syntax errors and potential problems without executing it. It is a tool for script development in Privileged EXEC mode.

summary: Defines the text for a script.
synopsis: This command specifies the actual text that will be executed by the script, critical for scripting automation and task management.

syntax: sdm prefer [dual-ipv4-and-ipv6 {data-center-generic | data-center-m4396only | data-center-mixed-native-m4396 | data-center-native} | ipv4-routing data-center {plus-generic | plus-m4396only | plus-mixed-native-m4396 | plus-native}]
summary: Configures the SDM template preferences on the switch.
synopsis: This command changes the running SDM preferences for the switch, which will take effect upon the next reload. It allows configuration of various SDM templates suitable for different network environments.

summary: Sets the security protocol for email alerts.
synopsis: This command enables or disables TLS authentication for email alerts sent to the SMTP server. If TLS mode is enabled but not supported by the SMTP server, emails will not be sent.

summary: Customize the separator bar color of the Captive Portal authentication page.
synopsis: Use this command to set the separator bar color of the Captive Portal authentication page using a known color name or RGB value. The color-code must be a valid color name or an RGB hex-code like #FF0000, ranging from 1 to 32 characters. Default color is #BFBFBF.

summary: Sets the communication rate of the terminal interface.
synopsis: This command sets the baud rate for serial communication, with supported rates from 1200 to 115200 bps. The default is 9600.

summary: Specifies maximum console connect time without activity.
synopsis: Use this command to determine how long a console session can remain connected without activity, with values ranging from 0 (indefinitely) to 160 minutes.

summary: Configures a global shared secret for RADIUS clients.
synopsis: This command allows the configuration of a shared secret for dynamic authorization clients. It can specify if the key is encrypted or unencrypted, affecting security.

summary: Enables DHCP service.
synopsis: This command activates the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) service on the device, allowing it to assign IP addresses dynamically to clients.

summary: Enables DHCPv6 configuration on the router.
synopsis: This command activates the DHCPv6 services, allowing the router to provide IPv6 addressing and configuration services to clients within its scope.

summary: Attaches a DiffServ policy to an interface.
synopsis: This command is used to apply a DiffServ traffic conditioning policy to an interface, either in the inbound or outbound direction, as specified. Each interface can have one policy attached, and this command creates a reference to the policy.

summary: Configures IP settings for the network management port.
synopsis: This command sets the IP address, netmask, and gateway for the network management port, with an option to clear these settings.

summary: Configures IPv6 address and settings for the service port.
synopsis: This command allows the manual configuration of IPv6 global addresses, enabling and disabling stateless global address autoconfiguration and DHCPv6 client protocol information on the service port.

summary: Enables IPv6 operation on the service port.
synopsis: This command activates IPv6 functionality on the service port of the switch, allowing for dual IPv4/IPv6 operation. By default, IPv6 operation is enabled.

summary: Configures the default IPv6 gateway for the service port.
synopsis: This command sets the default router address for IPv6 traffic on the service port, enabling management and routing functionalities.

summary: Adds a static IPv6 neighbor entry to the table.
synopsis: This command allows you to manually configure an IPv6 neighbor entry, which becomes static and is not modified by the neighbor discovery process.

summary: Sets the protocol for the network management port configuration.
synopsis: The serviceport protocol command defines the protocol for configuring the network management port's IP settings, with options for manual, BootP, or DHCP configurations.

summary: Enables the DHCPv4 client on a Service port.
synopsis: This command configures the switch to use DHCPv4 for obtaining an IP address on the specified service port. If the client-id optional parameter is included, the DHCP client messages will carry the client identifier option. The command serviceport protocol none disables DHCP.

summary: Initiates a console session to troubleshoot other units in a stack.
synopsis: This command starts a debugging session from the stack master or between member units, allowing detailed troubleshooting of issues directly on the relevant unit by executing commands and receiving outputs from it.

summary: Terminate a previously started session.
synopsis: This command stops a session that was started with the session start command, either from a member to a member, from a member to a manager, or from manager to member.

summary: Specifies maximum simultaneous outbound Telnet sessions.
synopsis: This command sets the limit on the number of concurrent outbound Telnet sessions, which can be adjusted from 0 to 5; a value of 0 disables all outbound sessions.

summary: Sets Telnet session timeout value.
synopsis: This command indicates how long a Telnet session can remain inactive, with a configurable timeout ranging from 1 to 160 minutes. The default is 5 minutes.

summary: Configures the prelogin CLI banner.
synopsis: This command allows the user to set a prelogin message displayed before the login prompt. The banner message can be up to 2000 characters long, and is used in Global Config mode.

summary: Sets the GVRP join time for one or more interfaces.
synopsis: This command configures the interval for GARP Protocol Data Units (PDUs) for VLAN/multicast group registration, with a range of 10 to 100 centiseconds, applicable when GVRP is enabled.

summary: Sets the GVRP leave time for specified interfaces.
synopsis: This command defines the duration to wait after an unregister request before deleting a VLAN/multicast entry, falling within a permissible range of 20 to 600 centiseconds.

summary: Sets frequency for generating Leave All PDUs.
synopsis: This command defines the time for generating Leave All PDUs, ensuring members rejoin to maintain registration, with permissible values from 200 to 6000 centiseconds.

summary: Enables GARP Multicast Registration Protocol (GMRP) on the system.
synopsis: This command activates the GARP Multicast Registration Protocol (GMRP), allowing the switch to manage multicast group memberships dynamically.

summary: Enables GARP Multicast Registration Protocol on interfaces.
synopsis: This command allows the enabling of GARP Multicast Registration Protocol on one or all interfaces, controlling multicast group memberships, unless the interface is part of a port-channel or in routing mode.

summary: Enables GVRP on the system.
synopsis: This command turns on GARP VLAN Registration Protocol (GVRP), which is disabled by default. GVRP allows dynamic VLAN creation on trunk ports.

summary: Enables GVRP for specified interfaces.
synopsis: This command activates GVRP on a specific interface, a range of interfaces, or all interfaces. Disabled by default and has no effect if GVRP itself is disabled.

summary: Enables IGMP Snooping on the system, interface, or VLAN.
synopsis: This command allows the enabling of IGMP Snooping on the system globally, for a specific interface, or for all interfaces in a specified VLAN.

summary: Configures the switch to control IGMP message forwarding based on membership.
synopsis: This command allows the switch to forward IGMP Join/Leave PDUs to an upstream mrouter interface, impacting multicast data streams based on IGMPv1 or IGMPv2 membership messages. It behaves differently for IGMPv3.
