synopsis: This command requires an area-id parameter to display details of a specific OSPF area. The output includes the area ID, external routing capabilities, and the number of SPF runs calculated for this area.

summary: Displays internal OSPFv3 routes to reach Autonomous System Boundary Routers (ASBR).
synopsis: The command provides information on the OSPFv3 routing paths towards Autonomous System Boundary Routers (ASBR), essential for understanding external routing interactions.

syntax: show ipv6 ospf [area-id] database [{external | inter-area {prefix | router} | link | network | nssa-external | prefix | router | unknown {area | as | link}}] [lsid] [{adv-router [rtrid] | self-originate}]
summary: Displays link state database information for OSPFv3.
synopsis: This command shows details about the link-state database when OSPFv3 is enabled. It can display LSA headers for all areas or specific area information, as well as types of link-state advertisements based on optional parameters.

summary: Displays the number of each type of LSA in the database and the total number of LSAs.
synopsis: This command provides an overview of the LSA types present in the OSPFv3 link state database, including the totals for router LSAs, network LSAs, inter-area prefix and router LSAs, and other LSA types.

syntax: show ipv6 ospf interface {unit/slot/port | vlan vlan-id | loopback loopback-id | tunnel tunnel-id}
summary: Displays detailed information for a specified physical or virtual interface related to OSPF.
synopsis: This command shows OSPF-related statistics for either a physical interface, a VLAN, or a loopback/tunnel interface, including IP address, area ID, priority, intervals for Hello packets, LSA retransmissions, and other operational parameters.

summary: Displays brief information for each OSPF interface.
synopsis: This command provides a summarized view of key metrics for OSPF interfaces, including admin mode status, area ID, router priority, and timing intervals for Hello messages and retransmissions.

syntax: show ipv6 ospf interface stats unit/slot/port
summary: Displays OSPF statistics for a specific interface.
synopsis: This command provides a comprehensive set of statistics for the selected OSPF interface including packet counts, state changes, errors, and LSA metrics, only applicable if OSPF is enabled on that interface.

summary: Displays the number of self-originated LSAs within LSA groups.
synopsis: This command shows the total number of self-originated LSAs, the average per group, and pacing limits. It provides insights into the management of LSAs across different aging groups, helping to balance the frequency of LSA redistribution.

summary: Displays the configured maximum metrics for stub-router mode.
synopsis: This command reveals the maximum metric values for OSPF, detailing the conditions under which these metrics are applied, such as on startup or when advertising external LSAs.

syntax: show ipv6 ospf neighbor [interface {unit/slot/port | vlan vlan-id | tunnel tunnel-id}] [ip-address]
summary: Displays information about OSPF neighbors.
synopsis: This command provides detailed information about OSPF neighbors, including their state, priority, and interface identifiers. If an IP address is specified, detailed info about that particular neighbor is shown; otherwise, a summary table for all neighbors is displayed.

summary: Displays OSPFv3 area ranges configured for a given area.
synopsis: This command is used to view the set of OSPFv3 area ranges configured for a specified area, providing crucial information about summary prefixes and their associated configurations.

summary: Displays OSPF routing statistics.
synopsis: This command shows the number of times the SPF algorithm has been executed, the time taken in various stages of route computation, and updates to the common routing table along with the reasons for these updates.

summary: Displays the OSPF stub table.
synopsis: This command shows the information related to the OSPF stub area configuration on the device, including area identifiers and metrics associated with the stub areas.

syntax: show ipv6 ospf virtual-link area-id neighbor
summary: Displays OSPF Virtual Interface information for a specific area and neighbor.
synopsis: This command is used to obtain detailed information about OSPF virtual interfaces, including hello and dead intervals, as well as state information for specified areas and neighbors.

summary: Displays summarized OSPFv3 virtual link information.
synopsis: This command gives a concise overview of the virtual links configured in OSPFv3, allowing for quick checks of the virtual link states and their associated parameters.

summary: Displays IPv6 PIM information.
synopsis: This command shows Protocol Independent Multicast (PIM) information for IPv6, including groups, interfaces, and their associated states, enabling multicast network management.

summary: Displays information about the bootstrap router (BSR).
synopsis: This command provides details about the BSR, including its address, priority, hash mask length, and advertisement interval. It can show information for either the candidate or the elected BSR.

syntax: show ipv6 pim interface [unit/slot/port | vlan vland-id]
summary: Displays PIM interface information for specified routing interfaces.
synopsis: This command displays PIM-related operational parameters for the specified interface or for all PIM-enabled interfaces if none is specified. Information includes mode, hello interval, join prune interval, and neighbor count.

syntax: show ipv6 pim neighbor [{unit/slot/port | vlan vland-id}]
summary: Displays PIM neighbors discovered through Hello messages.
synopsis: This command lists PIM neighbors along with their interfaces, uptime, expiry time, and DR priority if applicable. If no interface is specified, it shows all PIM-enabled interfaces.

syntax: show ipv6 pim rp mapping [rp-address | candidate | static]
summary: Displays the RP mapping for multicast groups.
synopsis: This command provides the mapping of PIM groups to their active RPs as recognized by the router, allowing for filtering by specific RP addresses or types of mapping (candidate or static).

summary: Displays the RP for a specified multicast group.
synopsis: This command reveals which rendezvous point (RP) is chosen for a given multicast group. The group-address argument must be defined to use this command.

summary: Displays the configured source specific IPv6 multicast addresses.
synopsis: This command shows the source specific multicast (SSM) addresses configured on the router. If no SSM Group range is configured, it will indicate that no SSM address range is configured.

summary: Displays statistics for received PIM control packets per interface.
synopsis: This command shows PIM control packet statistics (Rx/Tx) on interfaces where PIM sparse mode is enabled, including Hello, Register, Join/Prune messages, and more.

summary: Displays configuration and status of active IPv6 routing protocols.
synopsis: This command provides a summary of the active IPv6 routing protocols and their configurations, displaying information like OSPFv3 settings, router ID, and maximum paths, along with administrative status of OSPF.

syntax: show ipv6 route [ipv6-address [protocol] | {ipv6-prefix/ipv6-prefix-length | unit/slot/port | vlan vland-id} [protocol] | protocol | summary] [all] | all
summary: Displays the IPv6 routing table.
synopsis: This command shows the current IPv6 routing table, allowing specification of addresses, protocols, or interfaces. It details the best matching routes and includes route types such as connected, static, or OSPF, with associated routing metrics and next-hop details.

summary: Displays manually configured IPv6-over-IPv4 tunnels.
synopsis: Use this command to view IPv6-over-IPv4 tunnels that are manually configured in the switch, allowing for better insight into tunnel configurations.

summary: Displays all current ECMP (Equal Cost Multi-Path) groups in the IPv6 routing table.
synopsis: This command reports the ECMP groups, consisting of multiple next hops for one or more routes. It includes details about the number of next hops in each group and the routes that utilize those next hops, along with their respective IPv6 addresses and outgoing interfaces.

summary: Shows routes not added to hardware due to hash errors or table limits.
synopsis: This command provides details on routes that failed to be added to the hardware routing table, indicating issues like hash errors or limitations. It displays specific routes marked with a 'P' and their associated next hop information.

summary: Displays kernel routes, if available.
synopsis: This command outputs any existing kernel routes in the IPv6 routing table, allowing the user to inspect routes managed directly by the kernel.

summary: Displays net prototype routes in the routing table.
synopsis: This command reveals the net prototype routes, identified by a 'P' in the routing table, detailing connections and configurations linked to these specific routes.

summary: Shows preference values associated with different route types.
synopsis: This command displays the preference values for various route types, indicating which types are favored when routing. Lower values signify higher preference, with an emphasis on directly-connected, static, and OSPF routes.

summary: Provides a summary of the routing table's state.
synopsis: This command summarizes the routing table, including counts of different route types such as connected, static, OSPF, and reject routes. The optional 'all' keyword includes alternate routes, offering a more comprehensive view of the routing state.

summary: Displays IPv6 RA guard host mode counters.
synopsis: This command shows the number of dropped router advertisements and router redirections due to the IPv6 RA guard host mode, aiding in monitoring and management of IPv6 traffic.

syntax: show ipv6 source binding [dhcp-snooping | static] [interface unit/slot/port] [vlan-id]
summary: Displays the IPv6SG bindings for specified criteria.
synopsis: This command is used to display the IPv6SG bindings, which can be classified as either DHCP Snooping entries or static entries. It allows filtering by specific interfaces and VLANs, including details on MAC addresses, IP addresses, entry types, and associated VLANs.

syntax: show ipv6 traffic [{unit/slot/port | vlan vlan-id | loopback loopback-id | tunnel tunnel-id}]
summary: Displays traffic and statistics for IPv6 and ICMPv6.
synopsis: This command shows detailed statistics of IPv6 traffic on interfaces such as logical, loopback, or tunnel. If no interface is specified, it shows traffic on all interfaces. You can specify a VLAN ID directly with 'vlan vlan-id', where vlan-id is a number between 1 and 4093.

summary: Displays the IPv6 configuration on a specified interface.
synopsis: This command provides detailed IPv6 configuration information for a specific interface, including filter types, IP addresses, MAC addresses, and VLAN settings. It's useful for troubleshooting and ensuring correct interface settings.

summary: Displays IPv6SG configurations on all ports or a specified interface.
synopsis: This command shows the IPv6SG configurations on all switch ports. If an interface is specified, the output is limited to that particular unit/slot/port. It includes details like filter types, IP address, MAC address, and VLAN for each binding.

summary: Displays IPv6 VLAN routing interface addresses.
synopsis: This command shows the MAC address, VLAN ID, logical interface, and IPv6 prefix associated with each configured VLAN, providing insights into the IPv6 configuration of VLANs.

summary: Displays iSCSI settings.
synopsis: This command provides an overview of the iSCSI configuration, indicating whether it is enabled and the current settings for targets and ports.

summary: Displays the iSCSI sessions.
synopsis: The 'show iscsi sessions' command provides information about active iSCSI sessions. If detailed mode is specified, it shows additional session details, including initiator and target information, ISIDs, and session IP addresses.

summary: Displays ISDP information.
synopsis: This command outputs information collected via ISDP (Intelligent Switch Discovery Protocol), including neighboring devices and their capabilities.

summary: Displays details about individual ISDP entries.
synopsis: This command provides comprehensive information about a specific ISDP entry, including learnings about the device and its capabilities.

summary: Displays ISDP information for specific interfaces.
synopsis: This command gives insights into ISDP information per interface, helping in the management of device connections within the network.

summary: Displays a list of neighboring devices.
synopsis: This command presents information about neighboring devices recognized by ISDP, displaying their capabilities, platform information, and maintain time.

summary: Displays ISDP traffic statistics.
synopsis: This command provides detailed statistics about ISDP packets, including the total number of packets received, transmitted, and specific counts for different ISDP versions and error conditions.

summary: Displays keepalive status and configuration.
synopsis: This command shows the current status of keepalive messages and settings, which are critical for maintaining active sessions on network devices.

summary: Displays statistics related to keepalive messages.
synopsis: This command provides numerical details about the keepalive messages sent and received, facilitating the analysis of session stability.

summary: Displays LACP actor attributes for the port-channel.
synopsis: Outputs the administrative parameters of the LACP actor for specified interfaces, including system priority and state. Can specify all or an individual interface.

summary: Displays LACP partner information.
synopsis: This command shows the details related to the LACP partner, including its states and configurations, for monitoring link aggregation.

summary: Displays link dependency group configurations.
synopsis: This command reveals the status and definitions of all configured link-dependency groups or a particular group identified by group-id. It informs about downstream and upstream interfaces and their current link status.

syntax: show link state group group-id detail
summary: Shows detailed information about a specific link-dependency group.
synopsis: This command provides in-depth information for a particular link-dependency group, detailing the states of upstream and downstream interfaces along with transition counts of the group.

summary: Displays the current link-flap settings.
synopsis: This command outputs the existing configurations for the link-flap feature, including whether it is enabled, along with the duration and maximum count settings.

summary: Displays current LLDP configuration summary.
synopsis: This command provides a summary of the current Link Layer Discovery Protocol (LLDP) configuration on the device, detailing parameters such as transmit interval and hold multiplier.

summary: Displays current LLDP configuration for specific interfaces.
synopsis: This command provides a summary of LLDP configurations for a specified interface or all interfaces, detailing aspects like link status and whether LLDPDUs are transmitted or received.

summary: Displays summary information about the advertised LLDP local data.
synopsis: This command shows either summary information or detailed information for each interface transmitting LLDP data, allowing the review of local device advertisement.

summary: Displays detailed information about LLDP data transmitted by a specific interface.
synopsis: This command shows in-depth information regarding the LLDP data that a specific interface sends out, including chassis IDs and system capabilities for comprehensive monitoring.

summary: Displays a summary of the current LLDP MED configuration.
synopsis: Use this command to see the global configuration settings for the Link Layer Discovery Protocol Media Endpoint Discovery (LLDP MED), including parameters like Fast Start Repeat Count and Device Class.

summary: Displays LLDP MED configuration for a specific interface.
synopsis: This command shows the current LLDP MED settings for a specific interface or all valid LLDP interfaces on the switch, providing information on status and configuration.

summary: Displays detailed information about the local LLDP MED device.
synopsis: This command provides comprehensive details about the local device's LLDP MED (Media Endpoint Discovery) attributes, including system capabilities and media policies.

summary: Displays information about remote LLDP MED devices.
synopsis: This command lists other devices that are found on the network via LLDP MED, along with essential information about each remote device's capabilities and settings.

syntax: show lldp med remote-device detail unit/slot/port
summary: Displays detailed information about remote devices transmitting LLDP MED data.
synopsis: Use this command to get detailed insights about a specific remote device's LLDP MED data on a particular interface, including capabilities and network policies.

summary: Displays summary information about remote devices transmitting LLDP data.
synopsis: This command provides summary details of remote devices that send LLDP data to the switch, allowing users to view key identifiers and operational status across interfaces.

summary: Displays detailed information about remote LLDP data.
synopsis: This command allows users to access detailed information about the remote devices transmitting LLDP data to a specified interface, including chassis IDs, port IDs, and management addresses.

summary: Displays LLDP traffic and remote table statistics.
synopsis: This command shows current LLDP traffic statistics and data regarding the remote table for a specified interface or all interfaces, including insert and delete counts.

summary: Displays the status of LLPF rules on specified ports.
synopsis: This command shows the current status of Link Local Protocol Filtering rules, indicating whether specific proprietary protocol PDUs are being blocked on an interface or across all interfaces.

summary: Displays the current logging configuration and log messages.
synopsis: This command provides a view of the device's logging settings and any messages that have been logged based on the current configuration. It is useful for troubleshooting and monitoring system activity.

summary: Displays messages stored in the logging buffer.
synopsis: This command reveals the contents of the logging buffer, showing all messages that have been recorded according to the logging configuration, which is essential for diagnosing issues over time.

summary: Displays the current email alert configuration.
synopsis: This command shows detailed information about the email alert configurations, including the administrative status of the feature, sender address, severity levels for urgent and non-urgent messages, and recipient information.

summary: Displays statistics related to email alerting.
synopsis: This command provides operational statistics for the email alert feature, including the number of email failures, number of emails sent, and time since the last email was sent.

summary: Displays all configured logging hosts.
synopsis: This command lists the logging hosts configured on the switch along with details such as their index, IP address or hostname, severity level, port number, status, security mode, authentication method, and certificate number.

summary: Displays SNMP trap events and statistics.
synopsis: This command shows statistics about SNMP trap logs, including the number of traps since the last reset, trap log capacity, and trap details such as log number, system uptime, and the trap message content.

summary: Displays current Telnet, SSH, and serial port connections to the switch.
synopsis: This command shows the current user sessions on the switch, including information about the user name, connection type, and idle time. It provides a quick overview of active connections.

summary: Displays the complete usernames of users currently logged in to the switch.
synopsis: This command provides detailed information about all active login sessions on the switch, including full usernames, login session IDs, connection sources, idle times, session durations, and types.

summary: Displays summary information for all MAC access lists.
synopsis: The 'show mac access-lists' command displays MAC ACL summaries, packet matches, and detailed info using the ACL name. Key attributes include rule number, action, MAC addresses, VLAN ID, and more, reflecting the ACL configuration.

syntax: show mac-addr-table [macaddr vlan-id | all | count | interface unit/slot/port | vlan vlan-id]
summary: Displays the MAC address forwarding database.
synopsis: This command shows the entries in the MAC address table that indicate how the switch forwards frames, including MAC addresses associated with VLANs, their learned interfaces, and their status, vital for network management and performance.

summary: Displays GMRP entries in the Multicast Forwarding Database (MFDB) table.
synopsis: This command shows the GMRP (Generic Multicast Registration Protocol) entries in the Multicast Forwarding Database, including details about VLAN ID, MAC addresses, entry types, descriptions, and the interfaces responsible for forwarding and filtering.

summary: Displays IGMP Snooping entries in the MFDB table.
synopsis: This command presents the IGMP Snooping entries in the multicast forwarding database (MFDB), detailing learned MAC addresses, their types, associated VLAN IDs, and the interfaces designated for multicast forwarding or filtering.

summary: Displays MLD Snooping entries in the Multicast Forwarding Database (MFDB).
synopsis: This command lists entries in the MFDB table related to MLD Snooping, showing VLAN IDs, multicast MAC addresses, entry types (static or dynamic), descriptions, and the list of interfaces assigned for forwarding or filtering related to those multicast addresses.

summary: Displays Multicast Forwarding Database (MFDB) information.
synopsis: The 'show mac-address-table multicast' command displays multicast entries in the switch's forwarding table. It can be executed without parameters to show the entire table or with a specific MAC address to display the entry for that address.

summary: Displays Static MAC Filtering information for specified MAC addresses and VLANs.
synopsis: This command shows the Static MAC Filtering information for all Static MAC Filters. If 'all' is specified, all static MAC filters in the system are displayed. For specific MAC addresses, 'macaddr' and 'vlanid' must be provided.

summary: Displays Static Filtering entries in the Multicast Forwarding Database.
synopsis: This command shows entries in the Multicast Forwarding Database (MFDB) table for Static Filtering. It includes information about the VLAN, MAC address, type of entry, description, and the list of interfaces for forwarding and filtering.

summary: Displays statistics for the Multicast Forwarding Database (MFDB).
synopsis: This command provides statistics regarding the Multicast Forwarding Database (MFDB), including total entries, the highest number of entries ever used, and current entries in the table.

summary: Displays the email alert configuration details.
synopsis: This command provides detailed information about the current email alert configuration settings, including the number of configured SMTP servers, their addresses, ports, and security protocols.

summary: Displays information about the configured management access-class.
synopsis: This command provides information such as the list name, administrative mode, and the count of packets filtered by the configured management access-class.

summary: Displays the status of the management access-list.
synopsis: This command shows the details of the management access-list including the list name, administrative mode, packets filtered, and the rules configured within the ACL.

summary: Displays memory buffer (MBUF) utilization monitoring parameters.
synopsis: This command outputs the current configuration and state of memory buffer utilization monitoring, including defined thresholds and severity levels, to help manage buffer resources.

summary: Displays memory buffer (MBUF) information.
synopsis: This command provides an overview of the total number of message buffers available in the system, including utilization statistics and allocation attempts, which is essential for resource management.

summary: Displays MLD snooping configurations and status.
synopsis: This command provides details about the MLD snooping configurations along with the current state of MLD groups, enabling effective monitoring of multicast traffic in IPv6 settings.

summary: Displays information about statically configured multicast router attached interfaces.
synopsis: This command shows details about multicast router attachments on specified interfaces, including membership in VLANs and MLD Snooping settings.

summary: Displays information about statically configured multicast router-attached interfaces by VLAN.
synopsis: This command provides information on the multicast router status for interfaces based on VLAN configuration, helping to identify VLAN membership and router attachments.

summary: Displays the global admin mode of MLD snooping proxy-querier.
synopsis: This command shows the current operational status of the MLD snooping proxy-querier, including which interfaces have proxy querier enabled.

summary: Displays MLD Snooping Querier information.
synopsis: This command shows MLD Snooping Querier status and configurations, including admin mode, version, querier address, query interval, and timeout for both Global and VLAN specific settings. Use 'detail' for comprehensive data including all Querier-enabled VLANs.

summary: Displays the source specific multicast forwarding database built by MLD snooping.
synopsis: This command lists the entries in the source specific multicast forwarding database (SSMFDB) detailing source, group, and VLAN combinations for informed multicast traffic management.

summary: Displays MLD SSM group membership information.
synopsis: This command provides details about the MLD SSM groups, including the VLAN where the report is received, the IPv6 multicast group address, the interface receiving the report, the reporter's IPv6 address, and the source filter mode along with the list of requested source IP addresses.

summary: Displays statistics of MLD snooping's SSMFDB.
synopsis: This command shows the total number of entries in the MLD snooping's SSMFDB, the largest number of entries ever used, and the current number of entries. It provides a quick overview of the SSMFDB statistics without requiring any additional options.

summary: Displays the status of the MMRP.
synopsis: This command shows the status and information related to the Multiple Multicast Registration Protocol, which is important for multicast management.

summary: Displays MMRP PDU statistics for interfaces.
synopsis: Shows statistical information about MMRP messages received and transmitted, including any errors detected on a specified interface or globally.

summary: Displays the port monitoring information for a specific mirroring session.
synopsis: This command provides a comprehensive overview of the specified port mirroring session, including details about the source and destination interfaces, VLANs, and status.

summary: Displays MRP timer configurations on interfaces.
synopsis: This command provides an overview of the MRP leave, join, and leaveall intervals set on interfaces, allowing for monitoring of multicast membership management settings.

summary: Displays the message queues.
synopsis: This command gives an overview of the system’s message queue status, assisting in monitoring message handling and flow, crucial for network performance optimization.

summary: Displays global MVR settings.
synopsis: This command shows the global settings of MVR including the running state, multicast VLAN, maximum multicast groups, current multicast groups, query response time, and mode.

summary: Displays MVR-enabled interface configurations.
synopsis: This command retrieves the configuration details for interfaces with MVR enabled, showing the port type, status, and whether immediate leave is activated.

summary: Displays MVR membership groups.
synopsis: This command provides details about the MVR membership groups allocated, including the multicast IP address, status, and list of participating ports.

summary: Displays global MVR statistics.
synopsis: This command provides an overview of MVR traffic statistics, including counts of IGMP queries, reports, and failures in receiving/transmitting packets.

summary: Displays MVRP mode information.
synopsis: This command shows global MVRP information when 'summary' is used, or MVRP mode information for a specific interface when 'interface' is specified. The 'all' parameter provides a table containing both global and interface-specific MVRP modes.

summary: Displays MVRP statistics.
synopsis: This command provides global MVRP statistics when 'summary' is used, specific statistics for a defined interface when 'interface' is specified, or a comprehensive table of statistics for all MVRP-enabled interfaces when the 'all' parameter is utilized.

summary: Displays information regarding the nonstop forwarding configuration.
synopsis: This command provides insights about the NSF status, including administrative and operational statuses and details of the last management unit restart event.

summary: Displays OpenFlow status and configuration information.
synopsis: This command outputs the current administrative and operational status of OpenFlow on the switch, including possible reasons for disablement. Used in Privileged Exec mode.

summary: Displays a list of configured OpenFlow controllers.
synopsis: This command shows the IP addresses, ports, connection modes, and roles of the OpenFlow controllers configured on the switch, applicable when the OpenFlow variant (mode) is either 1.0 or 1.3.

syntax: show openflow installed flows [dest_ip ip-address | dest_ip_port 1–65535 | dest_mac macaddr | dscp 0–63 | ether_type 0–0xFFFF | ingress_port slot/port | ip_proto 0–255 | priority 1–65535 | source_ip ip-address | source_ip_port 1–65535 | source_mac macaddr | table {4 | 24 | 25 | 60} | vlan 1–4093 | vlan_prio 0–7]
summary: Displays the list of configured flows on the switch.
synopsis: This command lists all configured OpenFlow flows on the switch, detailing match criteria such as source/destination IPs, MACs, VLAN information, and associated actions for traffic management according to OpenFlow standards.

summary: Displays the list of configured groups on the switch.
synopsis: This command retrieves and displays information about the configured groups on the switch, including their types, IDs, reference counts, and bucket details, aiding in managing OpenFlow group configurations.

summary: Displays supported OpenFlow tables and usage information.
synopsis: This command provides detailed information about the OpenFlow tables, including their identifiers, names, sizes, and the count of both hardware and software entries, as well as flow insertion and deletion statistics. Use specific versions like openflow10 or openflow13 to see details relevant to those protocols.

summary: Displays the configured password management settings.
synopsis: This command shows various password settings, including minimum password length, age, history, allowed lockout attempts, and strength requirements. The output details the current configuration for uppercase, lowercase, numeric, and special character requirements.

summary: Displays the last password set result information.
synopsis: This command provides details on the most recent password set actions, including user details, whether password strength checking is enabled, and any reasons for failures in password set attempts.

summary: Displays vital product data for the switch.
synopsis: This command shows the vital product data for the switch, including the operational code, image file name, and software version release information. It provides insight into the system's build and specifications.

summary: Displays information about the PoE status of the switch.
synopsis: This command provides details such as unit number, firmware version, operational status of the PoE controller, total power outputs, power management mode, and configured traps.

summary: Displays MPSM and power bank values.
synopsis: This command shows the current active MPSM and power bank values for specified units. It applies when at least one module has PoE capability.

summary: Displays the PoE configuration for specific ports or all ports.
synopsis: This command allows users to view the configuration of PoE ports, including admin mode, priority, power limits, and detection types for each individual port or all ports collectively.

summary: Get the status information of PoE ports.
synopsis: This command retrieves detailed information about the status of PoE ports, including supplied power, output current, voltage, and operational status, either for a specific port or for all ports collectively.

summary: Displays configuration information for the specified policy.
synopsis: This command retrieves and displays configuration details for an existing DiffServ policy. If 'policyname' is provided, it shows detailed attributes like class members, policy type, and specific actions associated with that policy.

summary: Displays policy-oriented statistics information for a specified interface and direction.
synopsis: This command gives detailed policy statistics related to the specified interface, including current operational status and attached policy name. It is restricted to when DiffServ administrative mode is enabled.

summary: Displays the status and configuration of specified ports.
synopsis: The show port command provides detailed information about the administrative, physical status, link status, and mode of each port in the specified range.

summary: Displays the auto-negotiation state and operational local link advertisement for switch ports.
synopsis: This command shows local link advertisement and priority resolution fields for specified ports. If auto-negotiation is disabled, not all fields are displayed, and operational link information appears only if supported by both local and partner devices.

summary: Displays the interface description for a specified port.
synopsis: This command provides the alpha-numeric description, MAC address, and additional details of the specified interface. It can also refer to LAG interfaces using an alternative lag interface number.

summary: Displays the protocol status of ports.
synopsis: This command shows the operational protocol status for each port, essential for troubleshooting connectivity issues.

summary: Displays the status and state of specified networking ports.
synopsis: This command gives an overview of the operational state of ports, including status like link up/down, media types, spanning tree mode, and physical settings.

summary: Displays an overview of all port-channels (LAGs) on the switch.
synopsis: This command provides details about port-channels, including their names, link states, member ports, active ports, and maintenance types, indicating whether they are statically or dynamically managed.

summary: Displays information on LAGs with Auto-LAG enabled.
synopsis: This command shows details for all LAGs supporting Auto-LAG or for a specific LAG specified by its interface number. It provides information such as admin mode, global hash mode, and port status.

summary: Displays a summary of all port-channel (LAG) interfaces.
synopsis: This command displays the static capability of all port-channel interfaces on the device, along with a summary of individual port-channel interfaces.

summary: Displays port-channel counters for the specified port.
synopsis: This command provides information on the operational status of the port-channel, including link state and admin mode, as well as flap counts for member ports.

summary: Displays the port-channel system priority.
synopsis: This command shows the configured system priority for the port-channel, which affects how the switch determines master systems in a stacking configuration.

summary: Displays port-security settings.
synopsis: This command presents the current port-security configuration and status across interfaces or for a specified interface, detailing MAC address restrictions and settings.

summary: Displays dynamically locked MAC addresses for a port.
synopsis: This command shows the dynamically locked MAC addresses for the specified port. You can use 'lag lag-intf-num' as an alternate way to specify the LAG interface.

summary: Displays statically locked MAC addresses for a port.
synopsis: This command displays the statically locked MAC addresses for the specified port. The command allows the use of 'lag lag-intf-num' as an alternate option for identifying the LAG interface.

summary: Displays the source MAC of the last packet discarded on a locked port.
synopsis: This command shows the source MAC address of the last frame that was discarded at a locked port. An alternate method is to use 'lag lag-intf-num' to specify the LAG interface.

summary: Displays the switch power usage.
synopsis: This command displays the current power usage of the switch, including the model name, total available power, and the status of each power module in the system.

summary: Displays the power redundancy status.
synopsis: This command shows the current configuration of power redundancy, indicating whether N+1 is enabled or disabled, along with the active state and number of power supply units.

summary: Displays information for a redundant power supply (RPS) attached to the switch.
synopsis: This command shows detailed information about the redundant power supply (RPS) connected to the switch, including model name, total power available, input voltage, power modules, and their current status. It is applicable to M4300-52G-POE+ models.

summary: Displays information about a private group.
synopsis: The command can reveal details about all private groups or specific ones by name, identifier, or through a port specification in Privileged EXEC mode.

summary: Display user and system application processes.
synopsis: This command lists all applications running on the switch, providing identifiers, names, process IDs, administrative status, auto-restart capability, and running status for both system and user-defined applications.

summary: Display CPU utilization statistics by different tasks.
synopsis: This command reports on CPU utilization for specified intervals (5, 60, or 300 seconds) and can provide details for a specific process or all processes. Useful for diagnosing CPU resource consumption issues.

summary: Show memory consumption details of software components.
synopsis: This command provides insights into memory usage on the switch, including total memory, free memory, memory allocated to various components, and changes since the last execution. Valuable for resource management and monitoring.

summary: Display processes started by applications created by the Process Manager.
synopsis: This command lists active processes, including their IDs, associated application names, virtualization memory sizes, peaks, number of child processes, and file descriptor counts, useful for monitoring application behavior.

summary: Displays the operational and configuration status of PTP E2E transparent clock.
synopsis: Use this command to view the status of the PTP E2E clock at both the system and interface level, including configured and operational modes.

summary: Displays the RADIUS client configuration parameters.
synopsis: This command retrieves and displays the configuration of the RADIUS client, including the number of authentication and accounting servers, retransmit settings, and timeout values.

summary: Displays a summary of configured RADIUS accounting servers.
synopsis: This command shows an overview of RADIUS accounting servers, including their names, host addresses, ports, and whether they are configured with a secret. It can be used to check RADIUS accounting configurations quickly.

syntax: show radius accounting statistics {ipaddr | name servername}
summary: Displays RADIUS accounting statistics for a specific server.
synopsis: This command provides an overview of RADIUS accounting statistics, including details such as round trip time, requests, retransmissions, responses, malformed responses, bad authenticators, pending requests, timeouts, unknown types, and packets dropped, for a specific server identified by its IP address or name.

summary: Displays configured RADIUS servers and their details.
synopsis: This command provides a list of all configured RADIUS servers, including their current host addresses, names, ports, and types (primary or secondary). It helps network administrators verify RADIUS server configurations.

summary: Displays the configured RADIUS client source interface information.
synopsis: In Privileged EXEC mode, this command shows the RADIUS client source-interface information, indicating the IP address used by the switch to communicate with the RADIUS server.

summary: Displays summary statistics of the configured RADIUS authenticating servers.
synopsis: This command outlines important RADIUS metrics, including access requests, retransmissions, access accept/reject counts, malformed responses, bad authenticators, pending requests, and counts of timeouts, unknown types, and dropped packets for the specified RADIUS server.

summary: Displays entries in the RMON alarm table.
synopsis: This command provides visibility into configured RMON alarms, allowing users to view details related to specific alarm indices and their configurations.

summary: Displays entries in the RMON collection history table.
synopsis: This command retrieves and shows the configuration and status of RMON collection history for specific interfaces, including the sampling intervals and data storage status.

summary: Displays entries in the RMON event table.
synopsis: This command shows all RMON events defined in the event table, displaying attributes like event index, description, type, community, owner, and the last time an event was sent.

summary: Displays high-capacity alarm entries.
synopsis: This command lists all entries in the RMON high-capacity alarm table, showing the alarm index and associated owner information. You can also specify an index to view a particular alarm entry.

syntax: show rmon history index {errors [period seconds] | other [period seconds] | throughput [period seconds]}
summary: Displays specified entry in the RMON history table.
synopsis: This command retrieves historical data from the RMON history table for a specific index and type (errors, other, or throughput) allowing for time-based analysis over given periods.

summary: Displays entries in the RMON log table.
synopsis: This command displays the log entries generated for RMON events, including event index, description, and timestamp for each logged event, providing insights into network incidents.

summary: Displays RMON statistics for the specified interface.
synopsis: This command provides detailed statistics for packets, octets, errors, and collision counts for a specified interface. Information includes counts of dropped, broadcast, multicast packets, and various octet sizes, helping to monitor network performance.

summary: Displays a route map or its specific details.
synopsis: Use this command in Privileged EXEC mode to view the details of a route map including match and set clauses. Optionally, specify a route map name to see its specific configuration.

summary: Displays memory allocation summary from the routing heap.
synopsis: This command outlines the memory allocation for routing applications, detailing how much memory is allocated, in use, available, and the high water mark since the last reboot.

summary: Displays the current running configuration of the switch.
synopsis: The show running-config command provides a detailed output of the switch's active configuration, including settings for interfaces, VLANs, and other parameters. Users can apply output filtering for more precise information.

syntax: show running-config interface {unit/slot/port | lag lag-intf-num | loopback loopback-id | tunnel tunnel-id | vlan vlan-id}
summary: Displays running configuration for a specific interface.
synopsis: This command provides details on the running configuration for a designated interface type, which can include physical interfaces, LAG, loopback, tunnel, and VLAN interfaces.

syntax: show sdm prefer [dual-ipv4-and-ipv6 {data-center-generic | data-center-m4396only | data-center-mixed-native-m4396 | data-center-native} | ipv4-routing data-center {plus-generic | plus-m4396only | plus-mixed-native-m4396 | plus-native}]
summary: View the currently active SDM template and scaling parameters.
synopsis: Displays the active SDM template and its scaling parameters. If different, it also shows the template that will be active on the next reboot. Useful for understanding resource allocation for routing interfaces.

summary: Displays serial communication settings.
synopsis: This command provides information on the serial communication settings for the switch, including login timeout, baud rate, character size, flow control, stop bits, and parity.

summary: Displays a summary of policy-oriented statistics for all interfaces in the specified direction.
synopsis: This command provides an overview of the operational status and policies attached to interfaces. It repetitively shows details for each interface such as its operational status and policy name, applicable for the specified direction (in or out).

summary: Displays service port configuration information.
synopsis: This command outputs the current configuration and status of the service port, displaying details such as IP address, subnet mask, default gateway, and protocol information for operational insights.

summary: Displays DHCPv6 client statistics on the serviceport management interface.
synopsis: This command retrieves statistics related to DHCPv6 for the service port, including counts of packets received, transmitted, and discarded. It helps in monitoring the performance and issues of DHCPv6 operations.

summary: Displays information about the IPv6 neighbor entries cached on the service port.
synopsis: This command outputs cached IPv6 neighbor information, including IPv6 addresses, MAC addresses, router status, neighbor states, entry age, and type (static or dynamic).

summary: Displays sFlow agent information.
synopsis: This command outputs the details of the sFlow agent, including the version, organization, software revision, and the IP address associated with the agent. It provides key insights into the sFlow implementation on the device.

summary: Displays the configured sFlow pollers.
synopsis: This command lists the sFlow polling instances that have been created on the switch, detailing the data sources and their corresponding configurations, including the polling intervals.

summary: Displays information about sFlow receivers.
synopsis: This command shows the configuration details for the sFlow receivers, including the receiver index, owner string, timeout settings, maximum datagram size, and associated IP address and port configuration.

summary: Display instances of sFlow sampling configured on the switch.
synopsis: This command lists the configured sFlow sampling instances, detailing the data source, receiver index, sampling rate, and maximum header size for management purposes.

summary: Display the configured sFlow source interface.
synopsis: This command shows the details of the sFlow source interface that has been configured, including its ID and associated source IPv4 address, if applicable.

summary: Displays card information and status for each slot in the chassis.
synopsis: The show slot command provides details about the power status, vendor names, serial numbers, and PoE capabilities for each slot in the chassis. It helps in identifying which cards are installed and their operational states.

summary: Displays the SNMP server's UDP port configurations.
synopsis: This command shows the current UDP port to which the SNMP server is connected and the port used for sending SNMP traps, providing insight into SNMP configuration.

summary: Displays SNMP community information.
synopsis: This command presents a list of SNMP community entries, including allowed IP addresses and community strings, aiding in the management of SNMP access.

summary: Displays SNMP trap receivers.
synopsis: This command shows the SNMP trap receivers configured on the switch. Trap messages notify the SNMP network manager of events occurring on the network. The command supports displaying up to six trap receivers simultaneously.

summary: Displays SNTP settings and status.
synopsis: This command provides a view of the current SNTP configuration, showing operational parameters like the last update time, the last attempt time, and broadcast counts relevant to SNTP transactions.

summary: Displays SNTP client settings.
synopsis: This command reveals the current configuration of the SNTP client on the switch, including supported modes, SNTP version, and port information, aiding in troubleshooting and verification.

summary: Displays SNTP server settings and configured servers.
synopsis: This command provides detailed information regarding all configured SNTP servers, including IP addresses, server types, stratum levels, and the number of servers currently active.

summary: Displays the SNTP client source interface configuration.
synopsis: This command outputs the currently configured SNTP client source interface, including the interface ID and its associated IPv4 address, which aids in verifying SNTP client setup.

summary: Displays spanning tree configuration and status.
synopsis: Use this command to view essential spanning tree settings, including bridge priority, topology change counts, and path costs, useful for troubleshooting network issues.

summary: Display spanning tree values on active ports.
synopsis: This command shows current spanning tree values for active ports in modes like xSTP and PV(R)STP, detailing states, priorities, costs, and roles.

summary: Displays spanning tree information for backbonefast.
synopsis: This command provides statistics related to the number of transitions and the quantities of BPDUs and RLQ PDUs received or sent across all VLANs in the context of backbonefast.

summary: Displays spanning tree settings for the bridge.
synopsis: This command provides an overview of the spanning tree configuration, showing parameters like Bridge Priority, Identifier, Max Age, Max Hops, Hello Time, Forward Delay, and Hold Time, helping to assess STP configurations quickly.

summary: Displays settings for a specific switch port within the spanning tree.
synopsis: This command reveals STP parameters for a designated switch port or LAG interface, including Hello Time, Port Mode, and various guard settings, assisting in monitoring the status and configuration of individual ports.

summary: Displays detailed settings for an MST instance.
synopsis: This command provides detailed information for a specified multiple spanning tree instance by showing parameters such as MST Instance ID, Bridge Identifier, and Topology Change count, facilitating deeper analysis of MST configurations.

syntax: show spanning-tree mst port detailed mstid [unit/slot/port | lag lag-intf-num]
summary: Displays detailed settings for a specific switch port within an MST instance.
synopsis: This command shows detailed parameters for a specific port in an MST instance, including Port Identifier, State, Role, Path Cost, and loop states, which aids in troubleshooting and optimizing the spanning tree performance.

syntax: show spanning-tree mst port summary mstid {unit/slot/port | lag lag-intf-num | all}
summary: Displays settings of one or all ports in the specified MST instance.
synopsis: This command allows you to view the configuration settings for either a specific port or all ports within a specified multiple spanning tree (MST) instance. You can specify ports using their unit/slot/port notation, or reference a LAG interface. The status summary displays various attributes including port role and STP state.

syntax: show spanning-tree mst port summary mstid active
summary: Displays settings for active ports in the specified MST instance.
synopsis: This command provides information only about the active links within a designated multiple spanning tree (MST) instance, revealing the configurations and status of the active ports.

summary: Displays summary information about all MST instances in the switch.
synopsis: This command presents an overview of all configured multiple spanning tree (MST) instances on the switch, enumerating associated forwarding database identifiers and VLAN IDs for each instance.

summary: Displays spanning tree settings and parameters for the switch.
synopsis: This command reveals various spanning tree settings, including protocols, administrative modes, and configuration identifiers currently applied. It also indicates the presence of multiple spanning tree instances configured on the device.

summary: Displays status of uplink fast feature for the spanning tree.
synopsis: This command presents the configuration settings for the uplink fast feature, which helps improve convergence time in STP by facilitating quicker recovery from link failures.

summary: Displays spanning tree information per VLAN including port roles and states.
synopsis: This command shows the spanning tree status for specific VLANs, including protocol used, bridge ID, and port details, allowing the user to monitor VLAN-specific spanning tree information.

summary: Displays summary information for all stack ports.
synopsis: This command presents an overview of stack port modes and link statuses across all interfaces, detailing whether each is operating in stack or Ethernet mode.

summary: Displays statistics for stacking ports of specified units.
synopsis: This command in Privileged EXEC mode shows statistics, including data and error rates for specified units in the stack or all units. Outputs Tx/Rx rates, error counts, and link flaps.

summary: Displays front panel stacking diagnostics for each port.
synopsis: This command is primarily for field engineers and displays detailed diagnostic information for stacking ports, including transmitted and received packets, error counts, and diagnostic strings.

summary: Displays the route packets take to reach their destination.
synopsis: Use this command to reveal the stack path for packets, helping to identify potential errors or packet loss. Options allow specifying a source unit, displaying all units, or designating a specific destination unit.

summary: Displays stack unit's heartbeat message timings and dropped statistics.
synopsis: This command allows the user to view the heartbeat message timings and any statistics related to dropped or lost messages for a specific stack unit or all units in the stack. The optional 'clear' keyword can be used to reset these statistics.

summary: Displays configuration and statistics for the flow-based rule.
synopsis: This command reveals the details of flow-based statistics, such as parameters set for the rule, the time range utilized, and the interfaces tagged to the flow, allowing for comprehensive monitoring insights.

summary: Displays configured time range and statistics for a specified group.
synopsis: This command provides details on the specified statistics group, including the configured time range, interfaces involved, and the collected statistics after the time range has elapsed.

summary: Displays current storm control configurations.
synopsis: This command provides detailed switch configurations related to storm control. It shows the overall storm control parameters, including broadcast, multicast, and unicast settings. Using 'all' reveals per-port configurations, while specifying a unit/slot/port shows details for that specific interface.

summary: Displays information about supported card types in the switch.
synopsis: This command shows details regarding all supported card types in the switch or specific information for a given card index when provided. This includes identifiers and descriptions of each card type.

summary: Displays information about supported switch types for stack configuration.
synopsis: This command can show all supported switch types or can be limited to a specific type by providing a switch index. Information includes switch index, model identifier, management preference, and code version.

summary: Shows the status of the sw reset command.
synopsis: This command checks whether the sw reset feature is currently enabled, which is important for managing switch stability and recovery options.

summary: Displays information on all units in the stack or a specific unit.
synopsis: The show switch command shows details for all switch units in the stack or a specific unit if specified, including management status, model identifiers, and switch status indicating various conditions such as STM Mismatch or Code Mismatch.

summary: Displays the status of all interfaces pertaining to protected ports.
synopsis: This command provides an overview of the status of interfaces configured as protected or unprotected based on the specified groupid.

summary: Displays information about the switch.
synopsis: This command retrieves and presents key information related to the switch's operational status and configuration, including its name, location, uptime, and supported MIBs.

summary: Displays TACACS+ client configuration and statistics.
synopsis: The show tacacs command presents a detailed view of the TACACS+ client's configuration, including interface details and server statistics. It allows for filtering by IP address, hostname, client, or server.

summary: Displays the source interface used for TACACS+ communications.
synopsis: This command shows the global source interface configuration for TACACS+ client communications, indicating the interface's IP address that is used as the source for TACACS+ requests.

syntax: show tech-support [dot1q | dot1s | dot1s | dot3ad | isdp | layer3 | lldp | log | routing | sim | stacking | switching | system] [line]
summary: Provides system and configuration information for troubleshooting.
synopsis: The 'show tech-support' command aggregates data from various commands to assist technical support, yielding comprehensive details about the switch's configuration and operational status.

summary: Displays current outbound Telnet settings.
synopsis: This command provides an overview of the active outbound Telnet settings, including timeout durations, session limits, and connection permissions.

summary: Displays current inbound Telnet settings.
synopsis: This command reveals the settings related to inbound Telnet connections, including timeouts, session limits, and the status of new connections.

summary: Displays configured terminal length values.
synopsis: This command allows the user to see the current terminal length settings for various session types, such as current, serial console, Telnet, and SSH.

summary: Displays defined time ranges and their entries.
synopsis: When a name is provided, this command shows details of that specific time range; otherwise, it lists all time ranges currently configured on the device.

summary: Displays the trap conditions of the switch.
synopsis: This command shows all enabled trap flags, such as OSPFv2 and OSPFv3 trap flags. It indicates which traps the switch generates when a condition is detected; some traps like cold/warm start cannot be disabled.

summary: Displays the UDLD status of specified ports or all ports.
synopsis: The command shows the operational states of various ports on a NETGEAR switch indicating their administrative mode, UDLD mode, and UDLD status such as Shutdown, Undetermined, and Bidirectional. It helps in troubleshooting UDLD configurations.

summary: Displays USB flash device details.
synopsis: This command provides information on the status of plugged USB devices, detailing their current status, whether they're active, inactive, or invalid.

summary: Display configured user names and their settings.
synopsis: This command shows the list of users configured on the switch along with their access mode. The details are truncated, and additional detailed views are available using 'show users long'.

summary: Shows details about local user accounts including status and lockout.
synopsis: This command lists user accounts and their current statuses, including details on password aging and lockout conditions.

summary: Display the login history of users.
synopsis: This command lists the login history for users, including time, username, protocol, and location. An optional 'long' argument provides extended detail.

summary: Displays specific user's login history.
synopsis: Use this command to see the login history of a specified user for auditing and tracking purposes.

summary: Display complete user names and their configurations.
synopsis: Use this command to view the complete names and settings for all user accounts configured on the switch. This command provides a detailed overview compared to the truncated version.

summary: Displays inventory information for the switch.
synopsis: This command provides essential inventory details for the switch, including its system description, machine model, serial number, software version, boot code version, and other key attributes. It will replace the show hardware command in future updates.

summary: Displays information about configured private VLANs.
synopsis: This command displays information about the configured private VLANs, including primary and secondary VLAN IDs, type (community, isolated, or primary) and the ports which belong to a private VLAN.

summary: Displays VLAN associated with a specific configured MAC address.
synopsis: This command provides the mapping of a specific MAC address to its VLAN, or all address associations if no specific address is provided.

summary: Displays VLAN associated with a specific configured IP address.
synopsis: This command shows VLAN associations for the specified IP address and subnet mask, or all configured IP subnets if none are given.

summary: Displays information about VLAN ID allocation on the switch.
synopsis: This command helps in understanding how VLAN IDs are allocated internally within the switch, revealing allocation policies and base VLAN ID.

summary: Displays VLAN port information.
synopsis: This command shows VLAN port details, including Port VLAN IDs and ingress filtering settings for specified interfaces.

summary: Displays the configured RSPAN VLAN.
synopsis: This command provides information about the configured Remote SPAN VLAN. It allows the user to verify the settings that enable remote traffic monitoring across network switches.

summary: Display information about the voice VLAN.
synopsis: This command shows the status of the Voice VLAN, including administrative mode, VLAN ID, and priority settings, allowing you to check configurations at global or interface levels.

summary: Disables a port or range of ports.
synopsis: This command disables a port or range of ports in Interface Config mode. It can be used on physical and port-channel interfaces but not on VLAN routing interfaces.

summary: Disables all ports.
synopsis: This command disables all ports in Global Config mode, affecting both physical and port-channel interfaces but not VLAN routing interfaces.

summary: Configure a slot in the system.
synopsis: This command assigns a specified type of card to a designated slot while removing previous configurations if necessary.

summary: Dumps current multicast debug information.
synopsis: This command provides a snapshot of the multicast state on the switch, essential for monitoring multicast performance and issues.

summary: Dumps current OSPF debug information.
synopsis: This support mode command captures the current state of OSPF for diagnostic purposes, outputting extensive information to the console.

summary: Captures the routing table information.
synopsis: This command captures the current state of the routing table, allowing network administrators to review and troubleshoot routing issues.

summary: Dumps current system debug information.
synopsis: Executing this command captures the current state of the entire system for diagnostics, delivering potentially extensive information about system performance.

summary: Enables SNMP traps for link status changes.
synopsis: This command is used to configure SNMP traps that inform designated managers of changes in link status, enhancing network monitoring capabilities.

summary: Enables link status traps for all interfaces.
synopsis: This command activates link status traps across all interfaces, allowing comprehensive notifications on any link state change on the switch.

syntax: snmp-server {sysname name | location loc | contact con}
summary: Sets the name and physical location of the switch.
synopsis: This command is used in Global Config mode to define the switch's system name, location, and contact information, with parameters that can be alphanumeric characters ranging from 1 to 31.

summary: Adds a new SNMP community.
synopsis: This command defines a new SNMP community associated with the switch and its SNMP managers. The community name must be unique and can be up to 16 case-sensitive characters.

summary: Sets a client IP address for an SNMP community.
synopsis: This command specifies the client IP address that can access the specified SNMP community, allowing communication from a range of addresses defined by the given mask.

summary: Sets a client IP mask for an SNMP community.
synopsis: This command establishes which client IP addresses can use the community based on the specified IP mask, supporting enhanced access control.

summary: Sets the mode of an SNMP community string.
synopsis: The command allows administrators to specify the access level (read, write) for a given SNMP community string, facilitating controlled SNMP access.

summary: Restricts access to switch information to read-only.
synopsis: This command sets the access mode for the specified SNMP community to read-only, allowing SNMP managers to view information but not modify it.

summary: Configures a read-write SNMP community.
synopsis: In this configuration, the SNMP community string allows both read and write access, enabling comprehensive management of the device.

summary: Enables the Authentication Flag.
synopsis: This command activates the Authentication Flag in Global Config mode, allowing the switch to send traps concerning authentication events.

summary: Enables SNMP traps for captive portal events.
synopsis: This command configures the device to send SNMP traps regarding captive portal status, aiding in user access management.

summary: Enables Link Up/Down traps for the entire switch.
synopsis: This command allows the switch to send link status traps, contingent on individual port configurations for link traps being enabled.

summary: Enables multiple user traps.
synopsis: This command configures the switch to send traps when multiple users log in to the terminal interface, aiding in session tracking.

summary: Enables traps for STP mode changes.
synopsis: This command activates SNMP traps that report changes in Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) modes, assisting in network topology management.

summary: Enables switch to send violation traps.
synopsis: This command configures the switch to send traps when it receives packets with disallowed MAC addresses on locked ports, facilitating security monitoring.

summary: Modifies the port the switch uses for SNMP messages.
synopsis: This command changes the UDP port used by the switch to listen for SNMP messages, ensuring compatibility with network configurations.

summary: Sends an SNMP trap.
synopsis: This command initiates the immediate sending of an SNMP trap, useful for manual notifications of specific events.

syntax: snmp-server user username groupname [remote engineid-string] [auth-sha512 authentication-password|auth-sha512-key sha512-key] {[priv-aes128 encryption-password|priv-aes128-key aes128-key]}
summary: Creates an SNMPv3 user with access to the switch.
synopsis: This command creates an SNMPv3 user that can access the switch, allowing management via SNMP. It requires a username, groupname, and optional parameters for authentication and encryption.

syntax: snmptrap name {ipaddr ipaddr | ip6addr ip6addr} [snmpversion snmpversion]
summary: Adds an SNMP trap receiver.
synopsis: This command adds an SNMP trap receiver with a specified version and address. The name parameter does not need to be unique, but must be unique in combination with the IP address.

summary: Sends SNMP traps to a specified IP address.
synopsis: The command is used to configure the SNMP trap sender to target a specific IP address. This allows SNMP traps to be sent to the specified address for monitoring and alerting purposes.

summary: Sets the mode for SNMP traps.
synopsis: This command specifies the operational mode of SNMP traps, which can affect how traps are processed or sent based on the selected mode.

summary: Specifies the SNMP version for traps.
synopsis: Use this command to define which SNMP version should be used when sending traps. This ensures compatibility with the SNMP management system receiving the traps.

syntax: snmptrap source-interface {unit/slot/port | loopback loopback-id | tunnel tunnel-id | vlan vlan-id}
summary: Configures the global source interface for SNMP communication.
synopsis: This command configures the source IP address for all SNMP communication between the client and the server, using specified interfaces such as unit, slot, tunnel, or VLAN.

summary: Sets the polling interval for SNTP broadcast clients.
synopsis: Defines the interval at which the SNTP client will poll for broadcast time information. This affects how often the client synchronizes its clock with the network time source.

summary: Enables SNTP client mode as either broadcast or unicast.
synopsis: This command enables Simple Network Time Protocol (SNTP) client mode and may set the mode to either broadcast or unicast. The default mode is disabled.

summary: Sets the SNTP client port ID.
synopsis: This command configures the SNTP client to use a specific port ID ranging from 1025 to 65535. The default setting is 0, indicating no user-defined port.

summary: Configures an SNTP server.
synopsis: This command configures an SNTP server with a maximum of three possible entries. The server can be specified by IP address, IPv6 address, or hostname, with optional parameters for priority, version, and port ID.

syntax: sntp source-interface {unit/slot/port | loopback loopback-id | vlan vlan-id}
summary: Configures the source IP address for SNTP communications.
synopsis: This command specifies the interface to be used as the source interface (IP address) for SNTP unicast server configuration. If not specified, the primary IP of the outbound interface is utilized. Various interface types such as VLAN or loopback can be configured.

summary: Sets the poll interval for SNTP unicast clients.
synopsis: This command sets the poll interval for SNTP unicast clients in seconds, as a power of two where poll-interval can be a value from 6 to 10. The default value is 6.

summary: Sets the number of retries for SNTP polling.
synopsis: This command determines how many times the unicast SNTP client will retry sending a poll request if it does not receive a response from the SNTP server.

summary: Configures the timeout for unicast SNTP polling.
synopsis: Sets the timeout duration for the unicast SNTP client to wait for a response from the server before considering the request failed.

summary: Configure Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) settings.
synopsis: The spanning-tree command allows configuration of STP settings to prevent loops in network topologies. Various options like edgeport, max-age, and vlan specifications can be adjusted according to network design.

summary: Configures the interface to become an edge port under certain conditions.
synopsis: This command enables the interface to automatically become an edge port if it does not receive any BPDUs within a specified timeframe, defaulting to enabled.

summary: Enables BackboneFast to improve convergence time.
synopsis: This command is used to enable BackboneFast on the switch. BackboneFast allows the switch to quickly detect loss of connectivity to the root bridge and reduces the time required to re-establish a new path.

summary: Enables BPDU filtering on a port.
synopsis: This command allows for the configuration of BPDU filtering on a switch port, preventing BPDUs from being sent or received, which can help to isolate edge devices.

summary: Enables BPDU Filter on all edge ports.
synopsis: This command enables BPDU Filter for all edge port interfaces on the switch, preventing the sending and receiving of BPDUs on these interfaces.

summary: Enables BPDU flooding on a port.
synopsis: This command configures a specific port to flood BPDUs, allowing them to be sent out all other ports, which can assist in topology discovery in specific network designs.

summary: Enables BPDU guard on a port.
synopsis: With this command, BPDU guard is activated on designated ports, which will errdisable them when BPDUs are detected, protecting against accidental topology changes.

summary: Forces transmission of RSTP and MSTP BPDUs.
synopsis: This command forces the switch to transmit rapid spanning tree (RSTP) or multiple spanning tree (MSTP) BPDUs from a specified interface or all interfaces.

summary: Sets the Configuration Identifier Name.
synopsis: This command sets a custom Configuration Identifier Name for the switch, which can help identify the current spanning tree configuration.

summary: Sets the Configuration Identifier Revision Level.
synopsis: This command sets the Configuration Identifier Revision Level to a specified number, helping to identify the switch's configuration version among its peers.

summary: Configures the external path cost for the port.
synopsis: This command sets the path cost for a port used by an MST instance, with auto determining the cost based on the interface speed or a manual value from 1 to 200000000.

summary: Enables the edge port feature for the specified interface.
synopsis: The 'spanning-tree edgeport' command designates the port as an edge port which directly connects to end devices and prevents participation in Spanning Tree Protocol (STP).

summary: Sets the Bridge Forward Delay parameter.
synopsis: This command sets the Bridge Forward Delay parameter for Spanning Tree Protocol to a specified value in seconds, controlling the time interfaces spend in the Listening and Learning States.

summary: Configures spanning-tree protection features.
synopsis: The 'spanning-tree guard' command is used to enable features like loop guard or root guard, providing additional protection against topology changes.

summary: Sets the Bridge Max Age parameter.
synopsis: This command updates the Bridge Max Age parameter, which dictates how long BPDUs are considered valid, thus controlling the timing of STP reconvergence.

summary: Sets the Bridge Max Hops parameter to a new value.
synopsis: This command modifies the Bridge Max Hops parameter for the common and internal spanning tree within a specified range of 6 to 40.

syntax: spanning-tree mode {mst | pvst | rapid-pvst | rstp | stp}
summary: Configures the global spanning tree mode.
synopsis: This command manages the global spanning tree mode, allowing only one mode at a time, which impacts the operational status of MSTP, RSTP, and STP.

syntax: spanning-tree mst mstid {{cost number | auto} | port-priority number}
summary: Configures Path Cost and Port Priority for a port in multiple spanning tree instances.
synopsis: Sets the Path Cost (1-200000000 or 'auto') and Port Priority (0-240) for a given port within the specified multiple spanning tree instance or the common internal spanning tree.

summary: Adds a new multiple spanning tree instance.
synopsis: This command creates a new multiple spanning tree instance identified by a specific mstid ranging from 1 to 4094, with a maximum of 4 instances allowed.

summary: Sets the bridge priority for a multiple spanning tree instance.
synopsis: This command sets the Bridge Priority parameter to a new value for the common and internal spanning tree, with a valid range from 0 to 4094. If mstid is 0, it sets the priority for the common and internal spanning tree.

summary: Associates VLANs with a multiple spanning tree instance.
synopsis: This command adds an association between a specified multiple spanning tree instance and one or more VLANs, detaching them from the common and internal spanning tree. VLAN IDs can be specified as single, list, or range.

summary: Configures the spanning tree port mode.
synopsis: The 'spanning-tree port mode' command sets the operating mode of the port to either access or trunk for Spanning Tree Protocol operations.

summary: Enables all ports for spanning tree use.
synopsis: This command sets the Administrative Switch Port State for all ports in the switch to enabled, allowing collective participation in spanning tree.

summary: Sets the priority value for a port in the spanning tree.
synopsis: This command changes the priority value for a port, allowing the operator to influence the forwarding process. Valid values range from 0 to 240, with the default set to 128 for all LAN ports.

summary: Enables TCN guard on the interface.
synopsis: When activated, TCN guard prevents the interface from sending Topology Change Notifications (TCNs) received through that interface, enhancing network stability.

summary: Configures the Bridge Transmit Hold Count.
synopsis: This command sets the hold count for transmitting Bridge Protocol Data Units (BPDUs), which helps manage how often the switch communicates changes in the network topology.

summary: Enables uplinkfast on PVSTP switches to improve convergence.
synopsis: This command configures the rate at which gratuitous frames are sent after switching to an alternate port, enabling faster spanning tree convergence. The default max-update-rate is 150 packets per second.

summary: Enables or disables spanning tree on specified VLANs.
synopsis: This command allows the user to enable or disable spanning tree functionality for specific VLANs, thereby influencing how they interact with spanning tree protocol processes.

summary: Sets the path cost for a port in a VLAN.
synopsis: This command configures the path cost for a specified port in a VLAN, with valid values ranging from 1 to 200000000, or 'auto' for automatic adjustment based on link speed.

summary: Configures the forward delay time for a VLAN.
synopsis: This command sets the spanning tree forward delay time for specified VLANs, which can range from 4 to 30 seconds, influencing the time taken for transitioning into the forwarding state.

summary: Configures the hello time for a VLAN.
