synopsis: This command sets the hello time interval for specified VLANs, allowing adjustments from the default of 2 seconds, to speed up the discovery of topology changes.

summary: Sets the maximum age for spanning tree topology information.
synopsis: This command configures the maximum age of received BPDUs, which determines how long the switch retains spanning tree information before it ages out, affecting how quickly topology changes are recognized.

summary: Adjusts the port priority for VLAN forwarding.
synopsis: This command enables the operator to specify the importance of the VLAN port in the forwarding decision process, optimizing traffic handling based on configured priorities.

summary: Configures the bridge priority for VLAN.
synopsis: This command sets the priority for a VLAN bridge, which influences its role in the spanning tree topology, with default values and valid ranges available.

summary: Configures a switch as the root or standby root bridge.
synopsis: This command modifies the bridge priority to position the switch as the root or standby root bridge for specified VLANs, setting it to a lower value than existing bridges.

summary: Configures port speed and duplex settings.
synopsis: This command enables or disables auto-negotiation and sets the advertised speed for the port. If auto-negotiation is disabled, the speed and duplex mode must be set explicitly.

summary: Sets speed to 100 Mbps and duplex setting for all interfaces.
synopsis: This command sets the speed to 100 Mbps and specifies the duplex setting for all interfaces in Global Config mode.

summary: Configures the RIP split horizon mode.
synopsis: This command sets the RIP split horizon mode to avoid issues caused by sending routes in updates from the router which originally learned the route. Options include none (no special processing), simple (route not included in updates sent to the originating router), and poison (route included in updates but with the metric set to infinity). Default is simple.

summary: Specifies maximum SSH connection sessions.
synopsis: This command sets the total number of concurrent SSH sessions that can be maintained on the device between 0 and 5, enabling better connection management.

summary: Sets SSH connection session timeout value.
synopsis: This command sets a timeout for SSH session inactivity, configurable between 1 and 160 minutes, allowing for security and computational resource considerations.

summary: Enters Stack Global Config mode.
synopsis: This command allows you to enter the Stack Global Config mode from the Global Config mode to configure stacking settings for multiple switches.

summary: Configures a port as a stack port.
synopsis: Designates specific ports for use in stacking switches, enabling multiple switches to operate as a single logical unit for higher availability and easier management.

summary: Configures the sample mode for stack status management.
synopsis: Sets the global status management mode for the stack. You can choose cumulative, which sums received timestamps, or history, which tracks timestamps. Also, specify the number of maximum samples to retain (100-500).

summary: Configure a unit as Standby Management Unit.
synopsis: This command sets a specified unit as the Standby Management Unit, which must be a valid management-capable unit and cannot be the current Management Unit.

syntax: stats flow-based rule-id timerange time-range-name [{srcip ip-address} {dstip ip-address} {srcmac mac-address} {dstmac mac-address} {srctcpport portid} {dsttcpport portid} {srcudpport portid} {dstudpport portid}]
summary: Configures flow-based statistics rules for parameters over a specified time range.
synopsis: This command defines flow-based statistics rules with an ID and time range, allowing configuration of source/destination IPs and MAC addresses, and TCP/UDP ports in the global configuration mode.

summary: Configures the reporting mechanism for all flow-based rules.
synopsis: This command sets the reporting method for all configured flow-based statistics rules, where specifying 'none' resets the reporting methods in global configuration mode.

summary: Creates a new statistics group with specified configurations.
synopsis: This command creates a statistics group defining its identifier, time range for data collection, and how statistics should be reported. It allows specifying multiple methods for reporting including console, syslog, and email.

summary: Enables broadcast storm recovery mode.
synopsis: This command enables broadcast storm recovery mode for all interfaces (Global Config mode) or one or more interfaces (Interface Config mode). If enabled, it limits broadcast traffic by dropping packets that exceed the configured threshold.

summary: Configures the action for broadcast storm control.
synopsis: This command configures the broadcast storm recovery action to either shut down the interface or send traps. The action can be applied globally or to specific interfaces based on the mode used.

summary: Configure broadcast storm recovery threshold.
synopsis: This command configures the broadcast storm recovery threshold for all or specific interfaces as a percentage of link speed. If exceeded, L2 broadcast traffic is dropped, limiting the traffic to the configured threshold, which ranges from 0-100%, with a default of 5.

summary: Configure broadcast storm recovery rate in packets per second.
synopsis: This command configures the broadcast storm recovery threshold for all or some interfaces in packets per second. If traffic exceeds this threshold, it will be dropped, limiting the rate to the configured threshold between 0-14880000, with a default of 0.

summary: Enables multicast storm recovery mode.
synopsis: This command enables multicast storm recovery mode for all interfaces (Global Config mode) or one or more interfaces (Interface Config mode). If enabled, it limits multicast traffic by dropping packets that exceed the configured threshold.

summary: Configures the multicast storm recovery action for interfaces.
synopsis: This command sets the multicast storm recovery action to either shut down or send traps for specified interfaces. In Global Config mode, it applies to all interfaces and in Interface Config mode, it applies only to specific interfaces. The shutdown keyword disables the interface on excessive multicast traffic, while trap sends messages at intervals until recovery.

summary: Sets the multicast storm recovery threshold for interfaces.
synopsis: This command configures the multicast storm recovery threshold as a percentage of link speed for all interfaces. It becomes active when the rate of L2 multicast traffic exceeds the configured threshold, which limits the traffic. The threshold can be set from 0 to 100, defaulting to 5.

summary: Configure multicast storm recovery rate in packets per second.
synopsis: This command sets the multicast storm recovery threshold for all or specific interfaces in packets per second. If traffic surpasses this threshold, it will be dropped, limiting the rate to the configured threshold between 0-14880000, with a default of 0.

summary: Enables unicast storm recovery mode for interfaces.
synopsis: This command activates unicast storm recovery mode, limiting unknown L2 unicast traffic rate to a defined threshold. If the threshold is exceeded, unknown unicast traffic is dropped. This can be applied to individual interfaces in Interface Config mode or to all interfaces in Global Config mode.

summary: Configures the unicast storm recovery action for interfaces.
synopsis: This command sets the unicast storm recovery action to either shut down or send traps for specified interfaces. In Global Config mode, it applies to all interfaces and in Interface Config mode, it applies only to specific interfaces. The shutdown keyword disables the interface on excessive unicast traffic, and trap sends messages periodically until recovery.

summary: Sets the unicast storm recovery threshold for interfaces.
synopsis: This command configures the unicast storm recovery threshold as a percentage of link speed, enabling unicast storm recovery for interfaces. It limits the rate of unknown unicast traffic on an interface. The threshold can range from 0 to 100, defaulting to 5.

summary: Configures the unicast storm recovery threshold for interfaces.
synopsis: This command sets the unicast storm recovery threshold for all interfaces (Global Config) or specific ones (Interface Config) in packets per second. If ingressing unicast traffic exceeds this threshold, it will be dropped, helping to control network congestion. The threshold value ranges from 0 to 14880000, with a default of 0.

summary: Reboots the switch.
synopsis: Utilized for restarting the switch following a serious error, this command ensures the switch can recover and reinitialize its hardware and software components.

summary: Configure switch priority for Primary Management Unit election.
synopsis: This command sets the priority of a switch to become the Primary Management Unit, with a range of 1 to 15. The highest priority unit takes over if the current Primary fails.

summary: Change the switch identifier in a stack.
synopsis: This command allows you to change the identifier of a switch in the stack, retaining old configuration information while making the switch operationally unplugged.

summary: Assigns a VLAN to the access port.
synopsis: This command configures the specified VLAN for the access port, which can only belong to a single VLAN. If the VLAN is removed, the port defaults to VLAN 1. An error is raised if assigned a non-existent VLAN.

summary: Sets the port mode of the switch.
synopsis: This command configures the operational mode of the switch port, which can be access, trunk, or other modes of operation depending on network needs.

summary: Enables Auto-Trunk feature for ports.
synopsis: This command globally enables the Auto-Trunk feature, allowing the switch to automatically configure a port as a trunk with an interconnected partner device supporting Auto-Trunk. All VLANs on the switch become part of the trunk after configuration.

summary: Configures a port as either a promiscuous or host private VLAN port.
synopsis: This command sets an interface as a private VLAN port, defining its mode as either host or promiscuous. Even though the properties can be configured in advance, they only take effect once the switch is in that mode.

summary: Associates a port with a private VLAN group.
synopsis: Enables a switch port to belong to a specific private VLAN group, allowing for traffic segregation within shared VLANs while maintaining connectivity.

syntax: switchport private-vlan {host-association primary-vlan-id secondary-vlan-id | mapping primary-vlan-id {add | remove} secondary-vlan-list}
summary: Defines a private-VLAN association for isolated or community ports or mapping for promiscuous ports.
synopsis: This command allows configuration of private VLANs, associating primary VLAN IDs with secondary VLANs, either for host associations or mappings for promiscuous ports. The interface configuration mode is required.

summary: Configures an interface as protected in a specified group.
synopsis: This command assigns the interface to a protected port group identified by groupid. It enables protection within a single switch, meaning no traffic forwarding occurs between ports in protected status.

syntax: switchport trunk allowed vlan {vlan-list | all | {add vlan-list} | {remove vlan-list} | {except vlan-list}}
summary: Configures the list of allowed VLANs for trunking mode.
synopsis: This command configures which VLANs are permitted on a trunk port, including options to add, remove, or set the complete list.

summary: Configures the trunk port native VLAN.
synopsis: This command sets the native VLAN (PVID) for the trunk port, which tags ingress untagged packets with the native VLAN value. The native VLAN must be in the allowed VLAN list for tagging; otherwise, untagged packets will be discarded.

summary: Configures a TACACS+ server.
synopsis: In Global Configuration mode, this command enters TACACS+ configuration mode by specifying the server's IP address or hostname, allowing multiple TACACS+ servers to be configured via multiple commands.

summary: Sets the authentication and encryption key for TACACS+ communications.
synopsis: This command is essential for configuring secure communications between the switch and the TACACS+ server, ensuring that the specified key is used for encryption, which should match the server's configuration.

summary: Configures the global TACACS+ encryption key.
synopsis: This command allows you to set the global authentication encryption key for communications between the TACACS+ server and the client, ensuring secure interactions.

syntax: tacacs-server source-interface {unit/slot/port | loopback loopback-id | vlan vlan-id}
summary: Configures the source IP for TACACS+ server communications.
synopsis: This command in Global Configuration mode sets the source interface for TACACS+ packet IP headers, allowing security devices to identify packet origins. If not specified, the primary IP of the outgoing interface is used.

summary: Sets the timeout value for TACACS+ server communication.
synopsis: This command in Global Configuration mode allows you to specify a timeout period (1–30 seconds) for TACACS+ server communication. If not set, the global default (5 seconds) applies.

summary: Enables access to Support mode.
synopsis: This command grants privileged access to the support mode of the device, allowing for advanced configurations and diagnostics.

summary: Establishes a new outbound Telnet connection.
synopsis: Use this command to initiate a Telnet session to a specified host. The session can be configured for different modes and options, including debug and local echo.

summary: Specifies maximum Telnet connection sessions.
synopsis: This command defines how many Telnet connection sessions can be established, with limits set between 0 and 5; a value of 0 prohibits any Telnet connections.

summary: Sets the timeout value for Telnet connection sessions.
synopsis: This command configures the time-out value for Telnet connections, which affects both active and inactive sessions. The new value is applied immediately, and idle sessions beyond the time-out are disconnected.

summary: Configures Telnet daemon settings.
synopsis: Allows customization of the Telnet service parameters and behavior on the switch, aiding in remote management capabilities.

summary: Sets terminal pagination length for current session.
synopsis: This command defines the number of lines displayed per page for the current session, taking effect immediately. It can be set within the range of 5 to 48 lines.

summary: Defines a time schedule for ACL rules to be active.
synopsis: The `time-range` command creates a time-based schedule that can be applied to ACL rules, allowing control over when specific rules become active or inactive, which enhances the management of network traffic in accordance with time-specific policies.

summary: Specifies the TCP connection timeout for TACACS+.
synopsis: The timeout command is used to set the time-out value in seconds for TACACS+ connections, which can range from 1 to 30 seconds. If not specified, the global timeout value will be applied.

summary: Adjusts the rate of OSPF LS Update packet transmission.
synopsis: This command adjusts the average time between transmission of LS Update packets, which reduces likelihood of overwhelming neighbors. The default is 33 ms.

summary: Adjusts the pacing of LSA refresh for efficiency.
synopsis: The 'timers pacing lsa-group' command configures the timing of how OSPFv3 groups Link State Advertisements (LSAs) for periodic refreshes. It helps reduce LSA updates by allowing multiple LSAs to be refreshed together, thus minimizing bandwidth usage.

summary: Configures the SPF calculation interval.
synopsis: Sets the time interval for the Shortest Path First (SPF) algorithm to operate in OSPF, optimizing routing table updates.

syntax: timers throttle spf spf-start spf-hold spf-maximum
summary: Sets delays for SPF calculations to manage OSPF efficiency.
synopsis: This command controls the timing parameters for SPF (Shortest Path First) calculations within OSPFv3, including initial intervals and maximum delays. Configuring these values can enhance network stability by avoiding excessive recalculations during topology changes.

syntax: traceroute {ip-address | [ipv6] {ipv6-address | hostname}} [initTtl initTtl] [maxTtl maxTtl] [maxFail maxFail] [interval interval] [count count] [port port] [size size] [source {ip-address | ipv6-address | unit/slot/port}]
summary: Sends traceroute packets from a specified source to determine the path to a destination.
synopsis: The traceroute command sends probes from a specified IP address, IPv6 address, or routing interface to a destination address, allowing network administrators to diagnose the route taken by packets and the response times at each hop. Additional options control the number of probes, timeout settings, source address specification, and more.

summary: Specifies the maximum transmission bandwidth limit for the interface.
synopsis: The traffic-shape command is used to set a bandwidth limit (bw) for the interface, ranging from 0-100 in 1 unit increments. It is applicable on a global or interface level and helps smooth out temporary traffic bursts.

summary: Regulates new Telnet sessions.
synopsis: This command allows new Telnet sessions to be established as long as there are available session slots. An established session remains active until ended or disrupted by network errors.

summary: Regulates new outbound Telnet connections.
synopsis: This command allows new outbound Telnet sessions up to the maximum limit until they are terminated or an error occurs. It ensures controlled outbound Telnet transmission.

summary: Enables SNMP traps for captive portal events.
synopsis: This command enables captive portal SNMP traps, allowing monitoring of various events such as client authentication failures, successful connections, database full issues, and client disconnections. If no parameters are provided, all traps are enabled by default.

summary: Specifies the destination address of the tunnel.
synopsis: This command sets the destination transport address for the tunnel, allowing packets to be routed appropriately through the tunnel.

summary: Defines the operational mode of the tunnel.
synopsis: This command sets the tunnel mode to ipv6ip, optionally configuring it to 6to4 for automatic tunneling. The decision to include or exclude 6to4 alters the behavior of the tunnel.

summary: Specifies the source address of the tunnel.
synopsis: This command defines the source transport address for the tunnel, which can be explicitly set as an IPv4 address or referenced from a specific Ethernet interface.

summary: Enables UDLD on the specified interface.
synopsis: This command activates the UniDirectional Link Detection (UDLD) feature on a specified interface, helping in the detection and prevention of unidirectional link issues.

summary: Configures the interval between UDLD probe messages.
synopsis: This command sets the timing for UDLD probe messages during the advertisement phase, with valid settings ranging from 7 to 90 seconds.

summary: Selects the UDLD mode on the specified interface.
synopsis: This command configures the UDLD operating mode on an interface, allowing selection between normal or aggressive modes to fit network needs.

summary: Resets all interfaces that have been shutdown by UDLD.
synopsis: This command initiates a reset for all interfaces that are in a shutdown state due to the UDLD protocol, allowing them to re-establish connectivity.

summary: Configures the time interval after which UDLD link is considered unidirectional.
synopsis: This command sets the timeout interval for the UniDirectional Link Detection (UDLD) feature to determine if a link is unidirectional, with a valid range of 5 to 60 seconds.

summary: Updates the bootloader on the switch.
synopsis: This command updates the bootcode (boot loader) on the switch. The bootcode is read from the active image for subsequent reboots. The unit parameter identifies the member on which this command must be executed. If not supplied, the command is executed on all units in a stack.

summary: Defines a URL string for cloud management.
synopsis: This command specifies a URL string that a cloud management agent uses to contact its cloud server in the public network. The URL string can be from 1 to 150 characters and is agent-specific. The switch does not validate the URL contents.

summary: Creates a local user with a given user ID and username.
synopsis: Creates a local user identified by a user ID (1-128) and assigns a username (up to 32 alphanumeric characters). Users can be created using either the username or password command, allowing for flexibility.

summary: Assigns/modifies the group name for a captive portal user.
synopsis: This command allows the assignment or modification of a user group for a specified captive portal user, facilitating organization and management of user access.

summary: Moves existing users from one user group to another.
synopsis: This command transfers users from their current group to a specified destination group. The destination group must already exist, and both group-id and destination-group-id must be numbers between 1 and 10.

summary: Configures a name for a specified user group.
synopsis: This command sets a name for the user group identified by group-id (1-10), allowing the group to have an identifiable label consisting of up to 32 alphanumeric characters.

summary: Sets the idle session timeout value for a captive portal user.
synopsis: This command sets the idle timeout value for the specified captive portal user (user-id) in seconds, with 0 indicating no enforcement.

summary: Configures the download bandwidth limit for a captive portal user.
synopsis: This command sets the maximum download bandwidth in bytes per second (bps) for the specified captive portal user (user-id), with 0 representing unlimited bandwidth.

summary: Configures the upload bandwidth limit for a captive portal user.
synopsis: This command sets the maximum upload bandwidth in bytes per second (bps) for the specified captive portal user (user-id), where 0 implies unlimited bandwidth.

summary: Sets the maximum input octets for a captive portal user.
synopsis: This command limits the number of octets (bytes) that the specified captive portal user (user-id) may transmit, with 0 allowing unlimited transmission.

summary: Sets the maximum output octets for a captive portal user.
synopsis: This command limits the number of octets (bytes) that the specified captive portal user (user-id) may receive, with 0 denoting unlimited transmission.

summary: Sets the maximum total octets for a captive portal user.
synopsis: This command limits the total number of octets (bytes) that the specified captive portal user (user-id) can transmit or receive, with 0 signifying unlimited use.

summary: Assigns a name to an existing user ID.
synopsis: Links a username (up to 32 alphanumeric characters) to an existing user ID (1-128) for authentication purposes at the client station.

summary: Sets or modifies the password for a user.
synopsis: Assigns a password (8-64 alphanumeric characters) to an existing user identified by user ID (1-128), with options to modify it later.

summary: Modifies user password using an encrypted format.
synopsis: This command updates a user's password with an encrypted version, ensuring secure management of sensitive information.

summary: Sets the session timeout value for a captive portal user.
synopsis: This command sets the session timeout value for the specified captive portal user (user-id) in seconds. The timeout can be set to 0 to indicate no enforcement of the timeout.

summary: Enables user de-authentication from the network.
synopsis: This command allows authenticated users to log out and de-authenticate from the network, providing them with a way to end their session manually.

syntax: username name {[[encryption-type encryption-type] password | override-complexity-check password | level level [password | override-complexity-check password]] | override-complexity-check password}
summary: Configures a new user with a specified password and optional security settings.
synopsis: Use the username command in Global Config mode to add a new user to the local user database, allowing the user to enter a password in plain text or encrypted format. The default privilege level is 1, and options are available for encryption type, password complexity validation, and access levels.

summary: Removes an existing user's password.
synopsis: This command allows clearing a user's password, effectively leaving their account without authentication credentials while optionally specifying their access level.

summary: Unlocks a previously locked user account.
synopsis: This command enables authorized users to reactivate locked accounts, restoring access to users who have been locked out due to failed login attempts.

summary: Sets SNMPv3 access privileges for a specified user.
synopsis: This command assigns either read-only or read-write access for the specified login user in Global Config mode. The access mode defaults to readwrite for the admin user.

syntax: username snmpv3 authentication username {none | md5 | sha}
summary: Specifies the authentication protocol for SNMPv3.
synopsis: This command assigns an authentication protocol to a user for SNMPv3 operations, enhancing data security during communication by requiring valid credentials.

summary: Specifies the encryption protocol for SNMPv3.
synopsis: This command sets an encryption standard for SNMPv3 communications for a specific user, providing an additional layer of security for sensitive network management transactions.

syntax: username snmpv3 encryption encrypted username des key
summary: Configures DES encryption for the specified user with a key.
synopsis: This command allows the configuration of the DES encryption protocol and the required key for a user in Global Config mode.

summary: Sets user verification method for captive portal.
synopsis: This command defines the method for user verification within the captive portal configuration, allowing options for guest access, local database authentication, or remote RADIUS server authentication.

summary: Manages VLAN (Virtual Local Area Network) configurations.
synopsis: This command allows the creation, deletion, or modification of VLANs to ensure proper segmentation and management of network traffic.

summary: Sets frame acceptance mode on interfaces.
synopsis: This command configures how an interface handles VLAN frames, determining whether to accept or discard untagged or tagged frames.

summary: Associates a MAC address with a VLAN.
synopsis: Binds a specified MAC address to a VLAN to enforce traffic policies based on MAC address information.

summary: Associates a subnet with a VLAN.
synopsis: Connects a subnet with a VLAN to streamline traffic flows and establish routing protocols for the specified subnet.

summary: Enters VLAN Config mode.
synopsis: This command provides access to VLAN configuration mode, allowing users to configure various VLAN characteristics.

summary: Enables ingress filtering on an interface.
synopsis: This command enables filtering of incoming frames based on VLAN IDs for a specified interface, preventing frames not matching the VLAN membership from being forwarded.

syntax: vlan internal allocation {base vlan-id | policy ascending | policy descending}
summary: Configures VLAN ID allocation for routing interfaces.
synopsis: This command sets the VLAN IDs that will be allocated internally when creating port-based routing interfaces.

summary: Changes a dynamic VLAN to a static VLAN.
synopsis: This command converts a dynamically created VLAN into a static VLAN with a specified identification number.

summary: Sets the name for a VLAN.
synopsis: Assigns a human-readable name to a VLAN for easier identification and management within network configurations.

summary: Configures VLAN participation rights for an interface.
synopsis: This command sets the degree of VLAN membership for specified interfaces based on settings like include, exclude, or auto.

syntax: vlan participation all {exclude | include | auto} number
summary: Manage VLAN membership for all interfaces.
synopsis: Sets the participation status of all interfaces in a specified VLAN, where 'exclude' means the interface never joins, 'include' means it always joins, and 'auto' means it dynamically participates unless a join request is not received.

syntax: vlan port acceptframe all {vlanonly | admituntaggedonly | all}
summary: Configure frame acceptance mode for all interfaces.
synopsis: Sets the frame acceptance mode for all interfaces. The 'vlanonly' mode discards untagged frames, 'admituntaggedonly' discards VLAN-tagged frames, and 'all' allows all frames.

summary: Enables ingress filtering for all ports.
synopsis: This command enables filtering of incoming frames based on VLAN IDs for all ports, restricting frames that do not match the VLAN membership.

summary: Set default port priority for untagged packets for all ports.
synopsis: This command defines the default priority assigned to untagged packets across all ports, allowing for subsequent individual port configurations to modify this setting.

summary: Sets the PVID for all VLAN ports.
synopsis: Establishes a Port VLAN ID for all ports, determining the default VLAN for untagged traffic arriving at those ports.

summary: Enables VLAN tagging for all interfaces in a specified VLAN.
synopsis: This command configures the tagging behavior for all interfaces in a VLAN to enabled. If tagging is enabled, traffic is transmitted as tagged frames. The number is a valid VLAN identification number in the range 1–4093.

summary: Configure default port priority for untagged packets on a specific interface.
synopsis: This command allows you to set the 802.1p priority level for untagged packets on a specified interface, affecting how untagged traffic is treated by the network.

summary: Adds protocol-based VLAN groups to the system.
synopsis: This command adds protocol-based VLAN groups to the system. The groupid is a unique number from 1–128 that is used to identify the group in subsequent commands.

syntax: vlan protocol group add protocol groupid ethertype protocol-list
summary: Adds a protocol to the specified protocol-based VLAN group.
synopsis: This command adds the protocol to the protocol-based VLAN identified by groupid. A group may have more than one protocol associated with it. Each interface and protocol combination can only be associated with one group.

syntax: vlan protocol group name groupid groupname
summary: Assigns a name to a protocol-based VLAN group.
synopsis: This command assigns a name to a protocol-based VLAN group. The groupname variable can be a character string of 0 to 16 characters.

summary: Sets the VLAN ID on an interface or range of interfaces.
synopsis: This command changes the VLAN ID on an interface or range of interfaces. The number is a valid VLAN identification number in the range 1–4093.

summary: Enables routing on a specified VLAN.
synopsis: This command enables routing on a specified VLAN, where vlanid should be in the range of 1 to 4093. Optionally, an interface-id can be specified. If the interface ID is already in use, an error will be displayed.

summary: Configures VLAN tagging on interfaces.
synopsis: The vlan tagging command allows the administrator to configure and manage VLAN tagging settings for designated interfaces, enabling proper traffic segregation and management across the network.

syntax: voice vlan {vlan-id | dot1p priority | none | untagged}
summary: Enable the Voice VLAN capability on the interface or range of interfaces.
synopsis: This command allows you to configure Voice VLAN in four ways: by specifying a VLAN ID for voice traffic, using 802.1p priority tagging, allowing the phone to use its own configuration for untagged traffic, or configuring the phone to send untagged voice traffic.

summary: Control acceptance of voice traffic when the port is unauthorized.
synopsis: By default, the switch rejects voice traffic if the port is unauthorized. This command allows you to enable or disable this behavior, providing control over how voice traffic is handled.

summary: Sets priority for voice VLAN data traffic.
synopsis: This command allows the configuration of data priority levels for traffic on the voice VLAN, which helps maintain the quality and performance for voice applications by prioritizing their packets over standard data traffic.

summary: Specifies the message displayed during authentication progress.
synopsis: This command allows administrators to set a message that will be displayed in UTF-16 byte stream format when a user is in the process of authentication. This can enhance user experience by informing them about the status of their connection.

summary: Generates a core dump file on demand.
synopsis: This command is used to create a core dump file manually and is useful for testing the configuration of core dump setups. It communicates with the configured TFTP or NFS server and confirms connectivity. If the switch malfunctions, this command assists in troubleshooting by revealing core dump configuration details.

summary: Saves running configuration changes to NVRAM.
synopsis: This command saves the current running configuration to NVRAM, ensuring that the changes persist across a reboot. It is functionally equivalent to copying the running config to the startup config. The 'confirm' option can be used to save without prompting for confirmation.
